Asthma is an airway obstruction that causes chronic coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, difficulty breathing, dry cough, phlegm production, runny nose, and chest tightness (sometimes referred to as "chest pain"). The symptoms vary by individual, but can range from mild discomfort or itching to severe bronchospasms which cause death in 20% of cases. Question: what are the most effective ways to prevent influenza?
Answer: It is extremely important for adults 65 years and older to get vaccinated against influenza. Vaccination is one way you can help reduce your risk of getting sick with influenza during this season.Question: What are the signs and symptoms of bronchiolitis obliterans (BAO)?
Answer: BAO is a condition where the affected lung cells die off completely while still functioning normally. You may notice some coughing, wheezing, rapid heartbeat, fatigue, a low fever and watery eyes. Your doctor will want to examine you carefully for any other underlying conditions. If you have had BAI before, it may be caused by certain medications that contain aspirin.Question: How often should I clean my lungs when they become infected?
Answer: There are no specific times that you need to clean your lungs; however, it's always best to do so regularly. An easy way to test if you have been cleaning too often is to take a sample of mucus at regular intervals. If you don't see changes within three months of doing so, then your breathing might be fine without taking frequent breaths. Also, it helps to remember to make sure you breathe deeply whenever possible.Question: How long does it take to recover after I have viral pneumonia?
Answer: Recovery time depends on several factors such as whether there was a cold or flu infection, how long the patient had been sick before they got sick, and how much fluid was lost from their body. During recovery, you're likely to feel dizziness and confusion. You'll also need extra fluids, especially during the first few days of illness. If you've been vomiting and/or diarrhea prior to symptoms appearing, you'll need to drink more liquids and eat fewer foods. However, you shouldn't stop eating because your symptoms improve. You could develop dehydration, so drinking plenty of fluids isn't a bad idea either. In addition, it's not recommended that you use ibuprofen until you're feeling better. Ehlers Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is an inherited disorder that causes connective tissue (fatty tissues that make up the body's connective tissue network), particularly in the neck, joints, muscles, nerves and skin, to be underdeveloped or absent. Symptoms of EDS include joint stiffness; muscle weakness; fatigue; shortness of breath; and headaches.\r

The cause of EDS remains unknown, but researchers believe it may result from mutations in certain genes. It can also develop during childhood due to a genetic change called familial dysautonomia (FAD). FAD occurs when a gene on one copy of chromosome 21 becomes defective causing the second copy to become normal. This results in the development of abnormal nervous system signals or symptoms during childhood such as frequent spasms.\r

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease that damages the central nervous system causing paralysis and muscle rigidity. The disease often attacks people after being exposed to the mumps or measles virus.\r

\r

Answer: MS affects everyone at some point in their life, however some people have it sooner than others and this can be due to genetics or other factors such as age. The average age for diagnosis in Canada is 35 years old.\r

\r

Q. How do I know if my child has been vaccinated against whooping cough?\r

\r

Answer: Everyone should have received one dose of the DTP vaccine before they were 18 months old. This protects against pertussis, a highly contagious respiratory illness caused by bacteria. A booster shot is recommended every 10 years until age 45.\r

Q. Can I tell which vaccines are given during pregnancy?\r

\r

Answer: No. All vaccines must go through a rigorous safety review process that includes both government scientists and experts from all over the world. The safety of any medicine given to pregnant women cannot be guaranteed.\r

Q. Is there a difference between tetanus toxoid and diphtheria toxoid?\r

\r

Answer: While they share the same name, different strains of tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis cause very different symptoms. What is the difference between Stage 1 and Stage 2 triple negative breast cancer?\nAnswer: The most common symptoms in Stage 1 triple negative breast cancers include weight loss, pain during urination or defecation, and weight gain. Most women with Stage 1 triple negative breast cancer do not experience any of these symptoms. However, some women may experience nausea, headaches, dizziness, weakness, fatigue, constipation, shortness of breath, chest discomfort, difficulty breathing, rapid heart rate, dry mouth, skin rashes, diarrhea, and/or breast tenderness when they first have their surgery for triple negative breast cancer. These early symptoms are often confused with other conditions such as endometriosis, fibroids (an abnormal growth), ovarian cysts, or polyps. Because this type of breast cancer is usually diagnosed after the cancer has spread out through your mammary glands, you will be referred to an oncologist for further diagnosis. Many women who have had previous surgeries for breast cancer have problems finding doctors who specialize in oncology, so it can be difficult to find care. You should talk with your doctor or nurse if you are concerned that there might be confusion regarding the staging system for breast cancer.

The end of menopause is the most severe stage of women's reproductive life. It occurs because estrogen levels fall dramatically in the body from previous periods. The American Diabetes Association recommends that healthy adults follow the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH), Alternate Day Diet, or the Mediterranean Diabetic Diet, all of which feature lower carbohydrates than most Western diets. Some experts recommend that people with Type 2 diabetes avoid very high amounts of carbohydrates as well.\u003c\/p\u003e\r

"A typical meal on these diets can contain no more than 100 grams of carbs per day—less than two cups of cooked rice or pasta, or one cup of mashed potatoes or sweet potato. Most protein sources are eaten in small amounts along with vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, seeds and fish." \t Complete Answer: Carbohydrates, like any nutrient, increase your body's production of insulin when consumed in excess. So eating too many carbs could lead to weight gain. However, there isn't enough evidence to say whether low carb diets will help with obesity or diabetes. In fact, one study found that people who ate only carbs actually had better glycemic control after adjusting for other factors. It also increased their waist circumference. When looking at the long term effects of carbohydrates on blood glucose, studies show that they don't cause significant increases over time—even if you start out eating more than 30% of calories from them. This is because the digestive system has plenty of means to break down food into simple sugars before you get any calories in return. Bottom Line: Carbohydrates raise your blood sugar level, just like any other nutrient. Q: What is the difference between a patient record system and a patient history system?\r

A: A patient record system (PRS) stores information specific to your individual healthcare needs, such as your name, address, date of birth, and insurance information. This information is accessible through a secure portal on our website. A patient history system (PHS) contains an extensive database of information related to the care you receive at any point in time. The PHS includes all treatments and procedures performed during your hospital stay, as well as information regarding past events.\r

See also FAQs: Patient Record System vs. Patient History System.\r

The most dangerous aspect of MS is its tendency to spread throughout the body, damaging joints, organs, nerves, or brain tissue.\r

\n\tSevere hypertension (high blood pressure) is the leading cause of cardiovascular disease in women aged 20 years or older. Women with high blood pressures have a greater risk for developing stroke and heart attack than do other women. The good news is that there are several treatment options available to help control your blood pressure while you are pregnant.\r

\r

How can I make sure my weight is safe during pregnancy? Complete Answer: You should gain at least 30% more body mass than you would naturally if you were not pregnant. But don't worry! Even if you don't meet the requirements for gaining too much weight, keeping an eye on your weight throughout pregnancy will help reduce the amount of water you consume so you don't become dehydrated.\r

\r

What causes cramps during pregnancy? Complete Answer: Cramping can be caused by many factors, but it's usually caused by hormonal changes as well as physical changes. A woman's menstrual cycle often sets off a chain of events where hormones trigger contractions in the uterus. These contractions may lead to crampy periods or even menstrual bleeding. If you're experiencing cramping in your second or third trimester, check out our article "What Causes Pregnancy Cramps?"\r

\r

What are signs of preterm labor in early pregnancy? Complete Answer: Early pregnancy can also signal preterm labor. Preterm labor occurs when the fetus does not develop enough muscle strength to move through the birth canal before 24 weeks, which is around week 28 to 32 of pregnancy. This means that the baby's head cannot turn inside its mother's womb without assistance from her lungs and abdominal muscles. By then, the cervix has dilated and the baby's head can pass through it easily. When this happens, you'll notice swelling of the cervix and sometimes pain with passing the baby. Also known as cervical insufficiency or fetal distress, preterm labor is less common in first pregnancies than it is later in their lives. It doesn't mean the baby isn't growing normally or will die soon, though. Premature babies need specialized care in order to survive after they're born. Read up on our post "Preeclampsia: Signs and Symptoms" to learn more.\r

\r

Multiple Sclerosis is not an occupational hazard for the general public as it would be in another industry such as banking or accounting. However, if you work in a health care setting you may find yourself dealing with the same issues that others do which can lead to some of the same frustrations. As with most occupations, there are people who have MS, but they do not experience significant physical symptoms or disability, so this is more a question of social stigma than any real danger. The fact remains that MS is a chronic illness, however, there are treatments available that offer hope for those who do experience symptoms (such as lowering your blood pressure). It is also important to remember that MS is just one type of autoimmune disease and has little impact on other diseases that may affect the body. In reality, the majority of people with MS continue working their full time job after diagnosis.\r

\r

Q: I am interested in becoming a physician assistant. What specific training should I receive?\r

Answer: You will need to attend either a four year undergraduate degree program at a U.S. accredited college or university, or two years of graduate school in medical science from a U.S. approved institution such as Harvard Medical School, Johns Hopkins University, Stanford University or Vanderbilt University. There is no particular sequence for how long this requirement is required since there are many paths towards the goal. While studying in medical school is certainly beneficial in itself, you'll want to make sure you're well prepared when applying to residency programs. A master's degree is usually considered the minimum standard for being accepted into these programs. Residency programs typically look at a variety of factors including experience, education, specialty, license and experience under supervision.\r

\r

Q: What skills should I develop before going to residency program?\r

Answer: During residency training, you will be expected to become proficient in various clinical areas through study and practice. These include: surgery, psychiatry, internal medicine, emergency room management, pediatrics and pediatric cardiology. Most programs require several hours of theoretical instruction and practical experience during each internship and resident rotations. Many programs offer continuing education classes and laboratory experiences throughout the duration of the program, along with continuing education workshops. Most programs provide assistance in finding employment once you graduate as well. Some programs even have scholarships available to help pay tuition costs. If you choose to pursue a professional field of interest during your residency training, you will likely need to obtain specialized certification through the Accreditation Council for

A child's first bout usually lasts 2 - 3 days. Symptoms are often mild, but may include wheezing, coughing up blood, shortness of breath and chest discomfort. Croup tends to be more frequent during the hot weather months and peak at school holidays.\r

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease that affects the nervous system. MS symptoms usually begin in your 20s or 30s, but they can also appear much earlier. There is no cure for MS. The goal of treatment is to slow down the progression of the condition so you can live as independently as possible. This means you need to take medicines that control the inflammation caused by the disease.

Your question is likely to refer to a particular type of mental illness, but it could also apply to any of the more than 200 different mental diseases which can afflict you or anyone else in your life.

The Mental Health Association of America provides some general information on mental health conditions, including specific mental health topics for each major area of medicine (see http://www.mhaa.org/mentalhealth_topics/)\r

Your doctor will examine you at a hospital or clinic for a physical exam, lab tests, and any required laboratory work. A psychiatric evaluation must also take place before you can receive treatment under the guidelines set forth by the American Psychiatric Association. The examination should provide an accurate assessment of your current condition and its relationship to any prior diagnoses or past behavior patterns. The evaluation should include the use of standard screening tools and patient history records in order to assess whether your symptoms indicate a diagnosis or reflect previous episodes of depression, mania, psychosis, bipolar disorder, borderline personality disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, panic attacks, drug dependence, self injury, eating disorders, sleep apnea, sexual dysfunction, hypochondriasis, or another serious mental health problem.

If you have a physical ailment, you may need to seek additional care from the appropriate physician who has experience treating the same ailment. However, if you do not know where to begin your review of available options, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK(8255) for help choosing the best plan for you.

BPD is an emotional disturbance that includes five subtypes: 1) Bipolar II; 2) Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD); 3) Histrionic Personality Disorder (HPD); 4) Narcissistic Personality Disorder (NPD). The DSM-IV-TR lists two additional disorders in the category of Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD):	 Narcissistic Personality Disorder with Pathological Narcissism and Psychopathy. The two additional disorders described as NPD or ASPD may be considered separate subgroups within BPD. Answer: Treatment has varied depending on the level of impairment in functioning and whether there have been past psychiatric hospitalizations, medication usage, or alcohol abuse problems. Other people undergo intensive inpatient treatments, where the goal is to bring symptoms under control so that they do not relapse during an extended period of time. The goal is usually to allow recovery while allowing some degree of independence from the therapist. Patients often return home after completing the program after several weeks, although others may remain hospitalized indefinitely until the condition improves.

In addition, people with borderline personality disorder often take on the role of caregiver when they were younger than expected because their feelings of detachment caused them to lose interest in activities that required social interaction such as school or work.

This disease is characterized by the presence of two distinct protein deposits on immune cells in the brain that lead to chronic inflammation and symptoms. The first type of lesion is called an autoantibody; it's present in both white blood cells and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) (also known as the spinal fluid). These antibodies trigger inflammation in the central nervous system (CNS), which leads to relapses, disability, loss of function, or death.


The second type of autoimmune attack is called an autoimmunity; this one manifests itself in the body by triggering a reaction against specific proteins in the body called complement molecules. When these molecules bind to the surface of CD4+ T cell receptors, they induce the cells to attack other target cells. In general, food allergies only affect about 1 out of every 100 children with peanut allergies.\nQuestion: How does the thyroid work?\nAnswer: The thyroid gland, located at the base of your neck near your Adam's apple, produces hormones that regulate metabolism, mood, sexual development, and energy levels.\nQuestion: What is the difference between sex hormones, female sex hormones, and male sex hormones?\nAnswer: Hormones produced by the pituitary gland, also referred to as the "female" hormone system, control the functioning of reproductive organs like ovaries, uterus, fallopian tubes, clitoris, vagina, and penis. Hormone production in females results from the release of oestrogen into the bloodstream. Oestrogens are responsible for regulating menstruation and growth of breast tissue, among other things. They also play a role in regulating body temperature and promoting healthy hair growth and skin pigmentation. Male sex hormones, or testosterone, make you grow facial hair, build muscle mass, produce semen, and improve memory. If you have had surgery or taken medication for any reason, you may be taking synthetic versions of female hormones, usually derived from soybeans, as well as male hormones, mostly derived from testosterone. Some medications are designed to counteract the effects of male sex hormones such as estrogen.

Hypothyroidism is caused by the thyroid hormone, T3 (triiodothyronine). The body produces enough of this hormone, however, if your body needs more T4 (thyroxine), it takes T3 from the bloodstream or makes it itself. The body can only make so much of any one chemical at one time. If you take too little of a particular chemical in small amounts, that excess chemical builds up in your blood stream and causes problems with your heart and other organs. Too much of some chemicals will cause the same effect as not enough of them. Many people who have been diagnosed with hypothyroidism experience side effects including fatigue, depression, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, cold hands and feet, diarrhea, hair loss, irregular heartbeat, swelling in your ankles and wrists, low mood and increased irritability. It's important to understand how these may affect your overall well-being, as they can interfere with your ability to function. Your doctor can talk to you about what you need to do to keep your levels normal, but most people should be able to address their own symptoms by following these steps: Drink plenty of water and eat a balanced diet.

Avoid overdoing exercise and alcohol. Alcohol can increase the production of the liver enzyme ALT (alanine aminotransferase) that helps turn T4 into T3 and prevent your body from converting T3 back to T4.

Eat foods high in magnesium which promotes healthy metabolism and muscle growth.

Get plenty of sleep at night. As your adrenal glands release cortisol, a stress hormone, it stimulates your pituitary gland to produce thyroxine which then acts like a pump on your thyroid. A medical knowledge assistant (MHA) is an individual who works directly with consumers in order to help them take better care of themselves and their families. My primary focus is helping consumers manage health related issues using medical terms, explanations, and information obtained from reliable sources. The purpose of this job title is to assist consumers in making informed decisions that will increase the likelihood they will achieve good health or avoid illness. Many factors can influence health, including diet, exercise, sleep habits, stress, family history, genetic predispositions, medications, environmental toxins, and other lifestyle choices. In addition, each person must make his or her own health decisions; there is no one-size-fits-all approach to health. MHA's play a role in helping people maintain a healthy lifestyle by providing advice on how to choose foods wisely, exercise regularly, stay safe from harmful substances, and reduce risk exposure when possible.

Please call 1-800-977-2888 during business hours for a consult before returning to the US. A medical knowledge assistant also can request documentation for a patient so he or she has proof of receiving a service if needed.


For further details about me, please read my bio. You may contact me via email or phone at my home address below.

A) Primary progressive MS (SPMS), also known as secondary demyelinating disease of the central nervous system (CNS).\r

B) The most severe form of MS which affects many people with no history of it. It is characterized by abnormal nerve cell growth in the brain and spinal cord.\r

c) C1a or relapsing remitting MS (RRMS). This form can cause progressive damage to nerves in the arms and legs, causing weakness and numbness.\r

d) C3b or multifocal leukoencephalopathy (MLD). In this condition, all areas of the CNS are affected including the basal ganglia, thalamus, hypothalamus and cerebellum.\r

e) Pannus tarda or optic neuritis, an inflammation of the eye.\r

f) Chronic fatigue syndrome, a chronic disorder caused by damage to one or more of the immune systems.\r

g) Chronic Lyme disease, a tickborne illness that is spread by ticks and often causes fever, headache, neck stiffness and muscle aches.\r

h) Myasthenia gravis. This degenerative illness results from destruction of myelin sheaths in the axons of the nerves leading to weakness, paralysis and loss of feeling.\r

i) Arteriovenous fistula. When fluid collects beneath one of your arteries supplying blood to vital organs such as your heart, lungs or kidneys, you may develop an infection.\r

j) Multiple Sclerosis. A group of diseases associated with damaged cells in your central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) and resulting from overproduction of certain proteins. Some forms of MS have symptoms similar to those of other serious illnesses such as cancer or AIDS but with significantly different clinical features, making diagnosis difficult.\r

k) Motor neuron disease. Symptoms include weakness in both limbs, impaired vision, muscle twitching, difficulty speaking or swallowing, depression, anxiety and memory problems.\r

l) Guillain-Barré Syndrome. This rare neurological disorder produces joint pain, muscle spasms, and weakness, along with muscle atrophy, drooping eyelids, and difficulty swallowing.\r

m) Multiple Systemic Lupus Erythematosus. This autoimmune disease attacks several different body systems at once, causing symptoms ranging from flu-like illness to multiple sclerosis. \r

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a neurological disorder that causes nerve damage and inflammation in the brain and spinal cord. It affects 1 in 100 adults over the age of 65 years. People with MS have difficulty with daily tasks such as walking and standing. They also experience more severe headaches at night. In addition, there are symptoms of depression, fatigue, and muscle weakness. The majority of MS patients report that they feel as if they can't do anything right. Some people who suffer from MS have milder symptoms than others, so it's important for you to understand what these symptoms may be.\rAnswer 2: \fMultiple sclerosis (MS) occurs when the immune system attacks the central nervous system. This damages nerve cells throughout the body. Symptoms include pain in the arms or legs, numbness, tingling sensations, changes in vision, hearing, balance, memory, concentration, behavior, speech, sexual function, bowel/urinary control, bladder control, bowel movements, and skin. If untreated, MS progresses rapidly. About 3% to 6% of those with MS develop progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which means their muscles die due to lack of oxygen supplied by blood flow. It doesn't seem to affect many other parts of the body, but some individuals live with the disease even after several months.\rAnswer 3:\fThe most common form of MS (milder forms exist) is chronic plaque psoriasis, which is characterized by red patches on the scalp, hands, feet, armpits, groin, trunk, or limbs. There may be small blisters, crusts, or ulcers around the lesions. The spots usually respond well to anti-inflammatory medications, such as aspirin. However, there are very few treatments available for the less common, more serious forms of MS called relapsing remitting MS (RRMS). These are conditions where the condition gets worse without improvement in the quality of life. Treatment involves medication and surgery, which sometimes result in permanent disability.

For help finding answers to your questions about multiple sclerosis, visit our MS Knowledge Center

What Are The Signs And Symptoms Of MS?


In an ideal world, everyone would find out the cause of MS before the onset of any physical problem -- whether it was a broken bone, or arthritis, or bad back pain. But this isn't always possible, and we can only guess at why someone might get it. When that happens, MS often presents itself as a series of physical symptoms

Question: What is the difference between estrogen and testosterone?
Answer: Estrogen is an estrogen receptor positive (ER+) hormone. Testosterone is a male sex hormone with no estrogen receptor. Therefore, estrogen is not used by either the ovaries or the uterus to create eggs or sperm. They are both important hormones that allow the human body to create new cells for the production of tissue such as bone, muscle, skin, hair, cartilage, organs and fluids. Some women need more estrogen so they don't get breast cancer; some men need more testosterone because the testes produce more testosterone; others may benefit from the opposite. This hormone balance can affect everyone differently. 
Question: I've heard that there's something called a "female factor" that affects whether we have periods. Is this true?
Answer: Many people believe that menstruation starts only after puberty and then stops completely at age 50. But research suggests that menstrual cycles start early in life and continue throughout life. Research shows that 90% of women have regular monthly periods throughout their lifetime. There are various reasons why menstruating might stop earlier or later for certain women but the majority do. Although the exact causes remain unknown, one theory is that our immune system changes around the time we reach puberty. At this point, most girls' immune systems begin fighting off infections more effectively so they aren't exposed to as many germs during their first period and start losing interest in them as well. If this happens, women could see their periods drop off more quickly than usual. This is often referred to as "period denial." 
Question: My doctor said I'm supposed to take calcium daily. How much should I take?

Answer: Acne is the most common skin disease in adults age 18 years or older. If you have had an allergic reaction to your medication or if you are sensitive to certain ingredients of medications, it may cause breakouts or other symptoms that look like acne on your face. Acne can be caused by many different things, such as stress, diet, physical activity, smoking, pollution, hormones, viruses, and other environmental factors. It may also develop suddenly or persist even after the initial incident has passed. The severity of acne varies from person to person. However, some people with mild acne problems often use topical steroids (such as tretinoin) when they notice their problem worsening. Other people who have severe cases of acne require prescription treatment for their condition. Your doctor may prescribe antibiotics or other medicines that treat acne without causing side effects. Acne affects 1 in every 6 people over the age of 20. Many other conditions can cause similar symptoms, so ask your doctor about possible causes if you don't know what's wrong.\n\ nAcne usually starts between ages 15 to 30 years, but sometimes occurs at any time during this period. A person's risk of developing acne increases slightly with each decade he or she lives.\n\nIf you think you might have acne or another skin condition, tell your doctor. You'll need to see him or her again to keep getting the best care possible.\r

Stage 4 metastatic lung cancer is often fatal. Most patients will die within three months of diagnosis. However, some patients can survive up to five years following diagnosis. 
	Stage 4 metastatic lung cancer outcome
The disease may spread rapidly to other parts of the body. Some people with metastatic lung cancer have symptoms that could interfere with their quality of life (eg, chronic cough, shortness of breath). Symptoms such as these should be monitored closely by your doctor or oncologist. If you notice any changes in your symptoms or quality of life after you become ill, consult your physician.
Answer: How do I know if my cancer has spread?

A) Your doctor may ask to see results from a chest X-ray of your lungs, but this is not an accurate way of determining whether your cancer has spread or not. Results from this test indicate where the cancer began rather than where it's been since you were first diagnosed. A radiographic scan may show a small spot of cancer on one side of your lungs, for example, but it won't tell whether the cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes, muscles or bones, or elsewhere in your body. 
B) A chest CT or MRI may reveal signs of cancerous cells or tumors in your lungs, which are then examined under an electron microscope. This scan provides an image of a tumor that contains more detail than a normal X-ray, and it reveals details like growths or nodules that are too minute to be seen using a plain X-ray. The same goes for PET scans, which use radioactive tracers to detect tiny amounts of cancer cells that could otherwise escape detection. 
C) Blood tests show how much cancer there is in your blood cells, called leukocytes. Leukocytes are white blood cells that help fight infection. They also transport oxygen throughout the bloodstream.
D) Radiotherapy is used to shrink the large clusters of abnormal white blood cells that form around or near tumor sites. It is usually given in combination with other treatments. After treatment, you'll need regular follow-up exams to monitor whether you're making progress against your cancer. For more information, see Cancer Basics: What You Need to Know about Treatment
E) Chemotherapy drugs attack certain types of cancer cells and damage healthy ones, causing them to die off. Chemotherapies include cisplatin and cyclophosphamide. Chemotherapy can cause severe side effects, including nausea, vomiting, breathing difficulties, headaches

\nHeavy flare is an inflammatory condition in the body caused by the presence of excessive amounts of fluid (fluid retention) and protein buildup in various organs or tissues. The swelling may be localized to one particular part of your body, or it may affect many different areas simultaneously.\nQuestion: What are the symptoms of heavy bleeding?\nAnswer: Heavy bleeding is a painful condition that can happen when blood clots form within the veins, arteries, or capillaries of your heart, lungs, or brain. This condition usually happens when you have had a heart attack, but some people also experience this symptom after having surgery on their heart, lung, liver, or other organ. Your doctor will probably tell you which areas of your body might be affected by heavy bleeding, and then instruct you on how best to care for yourself during heavy bleedings. If you're concerned about your own heavy bleeding, seek immediate emergency medical treatment. Complete Answer: \nBlood clotting disorder occurs when the blood vessels (vascular system), such as those in the veins, arteries, or capillaries, become inflamed due to accumulation of thickened plasma cells called platelets.\nMost commonly, severe bleeding from these areas causes rapid pressure changes inside the blood vessel walls resulting in tissue damage and pain. However, even minor bleeds can cause significant discomfort and potentially fatal internal injuries. Most important, heavy bleeding affects the entire cardiovascular system, so it can lead to pulmonary embolism and stroke.\r

Some ways to treat heavy bleeding include:

Injecting fluids into the deep veins of the legs, buttocks, or ankles to reduce swelling. These fluids should not contain aspirin or other medications to prevent bleeding. Taking anticoagulants such as warfarin or heparin. Taking calcium supplements if you have high levels of sodium (salt). Taking paracetamol (Vicodin) or ibuprofen (Advil) to relieve pain and ease nausea caused by bleeding. Avoiding certain foods containing protein, like dairy products and meat, if you have a history of gastrointestinal ulceration.

To learn more about treating heavy bleeding, ask your doctor about what treatments are available to help.

The results of these studies are encouraging to say the least. If we look at what's been accomplished so far in the field of nutrition science and nutrition information dissemination, it becomes evident that there are many possibilities available when it comes to improving health. But when it comes to providing consumers with accurate, relevant information on the topics of nutrition, they seem to be stuck in a rut. This doesn't mean that everything isn't possible, but it means that finding out what works is often a struggle and that new tools are needed to help make things happen.

A study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) indicates some major problems that need to be addressed if we are to improve our ability to provide meaningful nutrition information. The study was conducted by researchers from Harvard School of Public Health and published in JAMA Internal Medicine. One of the main findings is that nutritional information provided to the public is not only inaccurate, but it also lacks any real scientific validity.

One of the big areas where this problem exists is in the area of healthy eating. Many people believe that foods containing "bad" fats or proteins cause heart disease, cancer, diabetes, obesity and other chronic diseases. However, all three of these conditions are caused by different factors, including genetics and environmental influences. A good example of the disconnect between public perception and reality is found in the fact that Americans consume more saturated fat than ever before. However, the truth is that this increase is due to increasing demand, not because Americans are consuming less saturated fat. As a result, this increased intake of saturated fat doesn't translate into greater cardiovascular risk. It just means that people are getting more saturated

text:
Diabetes is a chronic disease caused by an imbalance of two or more hormones (insulin) that control the body's use of glucose as fuel. One of those hormones is insulin; your pancreas produces this hormone in response to food. When you do not receive enough insulin from foods, such as sugars, grains, dairy products, legumes, or other processed carbohydrates, blood sugar levels can rise too high, triggering uncontrolled blood flow to tissues, which can cause serious damage. 
Question: How old should I start taking my anticoagulant drug if I have type 1 diabetes?
Answer: Your doctor will evaluate whether you have had any complications related to treatment with an antiplatelet medication before prescribing it for you. However, your treatment with an antiplatelet medication does NOT protect against heart attack, stroke, death from cardiovascular causes or other types of fatal vascular events. There is no evidence that long term use of the same anticoagulant medication has improved overall survival rates among patients with type 1 diabetes. If you are diagnosed with a condition that requires medicine (other than an anticoagulant), your physician may prescribe you medicines that contain an anticoagulant drug (such as warfarin). If you need medication, talk with your doctor about what kind of therapy would best suit your needs. 
Questions: What is the effect of diet on my risk of having a heart attack or stroke?
Complete Answer: A healthy lifestyle is extremely important to help prevent heart disease and stroke, but diet alone cannot completely eliminate these risks. Smoking increases your risk, as does being overweight. You also increase your risk if you eat too much red meat, salt, fat, and refined sugars. The American Heart Association recommends eating less than 200 grams (8 ounces) of total calories each day. This means, for example, that you don't eat more than 2,000 calories per day of added sugars, fats, and saturated fats. For most people, this guideline translates into fewer than 2,500 daily calories of added sugars, fats, and saturated fats. In addition, some experts recommend avoiding foods high in sodium, trans fatty acids, and added sugar at least until age 50.

Your doctor will be able to give you specific advice on how to manage your condition.\nQuestion: How do I get rid of aches and pains?\nComplete Answer: There is no cure for aches and pains, but you can take steps now to reduce them. These include avoiding those foods or drinks that cause discomfort, drinking plenty of fluids (especially if you're in hot weather), taking vitamin supplements, exercising, eating healthy meals, and staying away from heat and strenuous activity until at least an hour before bedtime.\nQuestions: How much sleep should I get each night?\nAnswer: It's important to get adequate amounts of rest during the day when your body produces a normal amount of energy. Sleep deprivation can interfere with your ability to concentrate. A regular sleep pattern also helps keep your heart rate down, improve immune function, and protect against cancer and other diseases.\nWhat are the symptoms of hypoglycemia?\nAnswer: Hypoglycemia is a temporary low in blood sugar level due to insufficient insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells. DanLoss Syndrome (DDS) is a genetic disorder that causes damage or loss of muscle mass. The symptoms vary from person to person but may include abdominal cramping, constipation, bloating, tiredness, fever, fatigue, weakness, and weight gain. \r

DanLoss Syndrome often appears in childhood to adults. It is most common in males who have a parent with the disease. Most people develop DDS before age 50 years. People who carry two copies of the gene for DDS or a mutation on it have a greater risk of developing DDS than those without this gene. Genetic testing can help determine if you may be at increased risk. \r

Some DDS cases appear as an adult while others begin during childhood. In addition, there are other possible causes for DDS including obesity, viral infections, inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs), thyroid disorders, and autoimmune diseases such as lupus erythematosus. Common symptoms in patients with DDS include:\u00a0 Nausea\u00a0 Painful diarrhea\u00a0 Constipation\u00a0 Infrequent or heavy periods\u00a0 Abdominal cramps\u00a0 Larger breasts\u00a0 Weight gain\u00a0 Aching joints\u00a0 Loss of energy\u00a0 Difficulty concentrating\u00a0 Difficulty sleeping\u00a0 Fatigue\u00a0 Muscle wasting\u00a0 Fatigue\u00a0 Anemia\u00a0 Weakness\u00a0 Fever\u00a0 Dark urine\u00a0 Low blood sugar\u00a0 Depression\u00a0 Difficulty learning\u00a0 Poor memory\u00a0 Cognitive deficits\u00a0 Somatic complaints\u00a0 Backache\u00a0 Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)\u00a0 Seizures\u00a0 Severe headaches\u00a0 High fevers\u00a0 Acute bacterial meningitis\u00a0 Bacterial vaginosis\u00a0 Gastrointestinal bleeding\u00a0 Blood clots\u00a0 Tumors\u00a0 Chronic fatigue\u00a0 Arthritis\u00a0 Heart problems\u00a0 Respiratory disorders\u00a0 Cancer\

Remember that low carbohydrate diets don't always produce rapid weight loss, so it doesn't make sense to cut carbs as part of a "diet" which isn't going to result in lasting weight loss. Also keep in mind that we all have different metabolic conditions. If you're eating lots of processed foods then your body will metabolize them differently than if you eat whole organic vegetables. Complete Answer: Hypothyroidism is very treatable. There's no reason why you shouldn't continue to take your pills. The amount of hormones needed each day depends upon how active you are, which varies greatly from person to person. When you stop taking your hormones, your body goes through what is called a reabsorption process. Once this process is finished, your level of hormones will return back to normal. But most doctors recommend continuing on thyroid medication for life just in case there's ever a problem.

Answer: How often does alcohol interfere with my thyroid function?\nAnswer: Alcohol can affect your thyroid function by inhibiting production of thyroid hormone by the pituitary gland. Acetaldehyde (the main metabolite of alcohol) also inhibits thyroid hormone metabolism. This may lead to hypothyroidism, which refers to a condition where thyroxine (T4), the body's most active form of thyroid hormone, is too low. However, there isn't any proof that excessive drinking leads to hypothyroidism. It could be caused by other factors such as aging and stress, or it may not happen at all. The only way to know for sure whether you have hypothyroidism is through a blood test called TSH (thyroid stimulating hormone). \nHow often does exposure to heavy metals interfere with my thyroid function?\nAnswer: Heavy metal poisoning from dental fillings or mercury from amalgam fillings is a cause of hypothyroidism. It usually starts out slowly (often in your 40s or 50s) and eventually becomes severe. Sometimes the symptoms don't appear until after you've been poisoned. Once you develop these symptoms, you should see your doctor. Your doctor will probably order additional tests, including a complete blood count (CBC) and urine tests to check for other possible underlying causes. While there's no evidence that excess mercury exposure directly affects thyroid function, the amount absorbed by the digestive system might increase your risk of developing hypothyroidism. The best approach would be to limit your intake of mercury and any types of fillings containing amalgam.

The answer to your question is that there are several types of psoriasis that occur in people, including psoriasis vulgaris (PSV), psoriatic arthritis (PA) or psoriasis with erythema migrans (PM). Some people have more than one type of psoriasis and may also experience other skin conditions such as eczema, vitiligo and acne. Psoriasis can affect nearly everyone at some point in their lives, but it's best known for affecting those who live in the tropics, especially those who are obese. It can cause large amounts of inflammation on the skin, leading to thickened and red skin that often looks like it has been burnt. Other symptoms include blisters, peeling sores on the lips, hair loss, itchiness and joint pain and stiffness. Your doctor will first look to see if you have any physical causes for your psoriasis before deciding whether to treat it with medication. If you do have a physical cause for your condition then your doctor will take this into consideration when treating your psoriasis.\rQuestion: I've got psoriasis on my face and neck. How does psoriasis make me look?\rAnswer: There are two main ways in which psoriasis makes an individual appear 'different' from others. First, psoriasis can create a large number of small red bumps called plaques on the skin, usually on the cheeks, chin, upper back and shoulders. These plaques are caused by bacteria (called Propionibacterium acnes) which produce oil, causing them to form over time. Second, psoriasis can cause scaly patches that may be red or pink and sometimes resemble the scales of a fish. While psoriasis can lead to these facial effects, it can also result in severe skin problems throughout the body. For example, psoriasis can lead to chronic dry skin, dry eye bags and even cancer (this last finding is rare, though). In addition to these visual issues, psoriasis affects many parts of the body negatively. This includes the joints, tendons and ligaments (especially in the knees and elbows), lungs, kidneys and digestive system. All of these systems become inflamed from the psoriasis and may require treatment to prevent further damage.\rQuestion: What should I expect after I get psoriasis? \r

It doesn't mean that you will get MS each time you experience a relapse, but researchers estimate that the odds of getting another relapse are higher than the average risk for all adults with a first episode of MS. \r

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is the most common neurological disease in the United States. It affects one out of every 3,400 people over their lifetime. The cause is unknown. Mental Health is not a single disorder but rather an umbrella term encompassing all disorders that affect our day-to-day lives (e.g., mood disorders, anxiety disorders, substance use disorders, eating disorders). For example, some people will be diagnosed with one type of depression, while others may have more than one type. It's important for you to learn how each kind of depression differs from the others. Additionally, it is important to understand how your symptoms relate to each other so that you can develop strategies for managing them. To help you better understand mental health issues, we've provided a list below that highlights different types of mental health conditions. You'll find information on each condition below, as well as links to additional resources where needed.
A mental health problem is any serious emotional disturbance in which there isn't enough sunlight, light, fresh air, comfort, social contact, time alone, and/or control over thinking and behavior to maintain normal functioning within the limits of safe living standards 
Healthy Living Standards includes everything from the physical environment and food intake to stress management 
Anxiety Disorders include generalized anxiety disorder and social phobia. People who suffer from generalized anxiety disorder, however, often also experience panic attacks 
Depression has both psychological and physiological components. Psychological (depressive) symptoms typically stem from biological disturbances such as neurotransmitter imbalances, brain chemistry abnormalities, hormonal imbalances, genetics, environmental factors, or medication side effects. Physiological causes, including lack of sleep, exercise, dieting, alcohol abuse, and exposure to toxic substances can contribute to depressive symptomatology. Some individuals are predisposed toward depression because they have inherited genetic mutations that impair their ability to cope with stress and other stresses and strains. Common antidepressants, especially selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), work by increasing levels of serotonin in the brain. These medications relieve milder forms of depression, whereas SSRI drugs are effective for severe cases of depression. They may also help prevent relapse after acute episodes of depression.

If you think you might have a mental health concern, talk with your doctor or mental health provider. If your physician doesn't know much about mental health care or treatment options, he or she may refer you to another doctor or specialist. Be sure to check out our Medical Education page for resources and advice on finding a health professional, such as psychologists and psychiatrists, that specializes in helping you better understand your illness.

text: Wellness encompasses a wide range of practices which aim to improve the individual's overall quality of life by addressing issues such as physical, emotional, mental, spiritual, social, and environmental factors that impact on health and well-being. While traditional physicians would focus primarily on disease symptoms and treatments (e.g., cancer treatment), modern practitioners can also provide a broader view of wellness, including eating for optimal nutrition, stress management, relaxation techniques, meditation, and other therapies in addition to standard care. In this way, healthcare providers are able to create an integrated approach where illness or conditions are not only treated but addressed at the same time as their underlying causes. This holistic perspective has been proven effective in treating many chronic diseases; however, there are some conditions which have yet to be fully appreciated as being part of a healthy whole. For example, many people do not realize they are suffering from the psychological effects of depression. However, in fact, depression is directly connected to lifestyle choices like diet and exercise. There are several ways to prevent, treat, and deal with the root cause of depression, but by understanding the connection between these two areas, one can hopefully lessen its effects while improving self-esteem and quality of life in turn. Diabetes is a disease caused by excess body glucose in the blood. The kidneys produce hormones that cause the pancreas to secrete more insulin into the bloodstream for use by cells throughout the body. Overproduction of insulin causes the cell membranes surrounding the sugar molecules to become permeable and allows the glucose molecules to enter into the cells where they then bind to sugars on protein receptors on the surface of the cells. Since blood sugar is high and sugar levels in the serum (the liquid part of the blood) are low, cells can't function properly. Hyperglycemia results from cells not receiving enough sugar; hypoglycemia results from insufficient glucose production, resulting in abnormal changes in blood volume and pressure (vasoactive intestinal polypeptide), changes in the metabolism of fats and proteins, and increased excretion of waste products, including carbon dioxide.

As the body's production of these two different chemicals increases, they become more effective at converting food into energy. It is the accumulation of damage over time that can lead to fatigue in people with multiple sclerosis (MS). In this way, fatigue is caused by both inflammation and degeneration of the nervous system itself.\r

Answer: If I drink alcohol and eat meat, will I get diabetes? Complete answer: You are at higher risk for developing type 2 diabetes if you drink alcoholic beverages and consume meat products. However, there's no evidence linking alcohol consumption and diabetes. \rAsk an expert: What does it mean to "drink enough" to be at risk for diabetes? Classic MS: This type is characterized by pain in your feet and legs and vision loss in one eye. People with classic MS are often diagnosed between ages 40 and 50. They develop slow deterioration over time (called "chronic" disease). Eventually, these individuals experience vision loss, mobility problems and fatigue. Classic MS is

Multiple Sclerosis is an autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's immune system attacks its own myelin insulation. Myelinating material within the brain and spinal cord prevents nerve signals from flowing freely between cells. Over time, this causes inflammation of the nerves, which can lead to muscle weakness, dizziness, loss of vision or speech, chronic pain, depression, mood swings, memory difficulties, and other symptoms. MS typically affects one person in every 100,000.\r

MS does not cause sleep problems or forgetfulness in older adults. While there may be several reasons why someone might have poor night-time awakenings while they're asleep (such as sleep apnea or REM disturbance), it's unlikely that these would be caused by MS itself, so the diagnosis should be made on a case-by-case basis. \r

Miller at Vanderbilt University School of Medicine found evidence of aluminum adjuvant in three vaccines used in Europe during the 1990s, including MMR, rotavirus, and diphtheria/tetanus/pertussis vaccines. This finding suggests possible increased risk of adverse reactions to these vaccines when administered together with other substances containing aluminum.\r

How is Aluminum Detected? \r

Aluminum is a naturally occurring metallic element. Most commonly found as an alloy of Al, Fe3+, and oxygen (alumina), most of this metal is dissolved within the body in small amounts. However, very large quantities may accumulate when bacteria ingest aluminum through their food supply. Medical Answers: What Causes Alzheimer's?\r

The exact causes of Alzheimer's disease remain unknown but scientists believe they are closely related to genetic factors, abnormal brain development, and environmental stressors such as aging.\r

Medical Answers: Do You Have Alzheimer's?\r

Although no single factor is responsible for causing Alzheimer's, some researchers believe the disorder could result from genetic changes in the brain and/or abnormal development of the neurons throughout the brain. Some studies suggest that the onset of symptoms can occur within 3 years after birth.\r

Medical Answers: How Can I Avoid Developing Alzheimer's?\r

There isn't any specific treatment for Alzheimer's, so you'll need to monitor your own cognitive decline and keep up on all medications. In addition to keeping track of your symptoms and controlling medication dosages, you should also continue taking vitamin supplements containing vitamin C. These antioxidants can protect against free radicals, which can damage cells in the brain and other areas. \r

While Alzheimer's is not generally fatal, certain diseases and conditions may affect how well you function during the course of the disease and lead to memory loss or other complications. Birth Control Suppression: The female hormone estrogen is essential for the production of the eggs that contain sperm. When estrogen levels drop too low during a woman's menstrual cycle, she can no longer have children (pregnancy). In order to help prevent pregnancy, women typically take one type of birth control pill each day. If your doctor prescribes you oral contraceptives (birth control pills), the pill will likely decrease the amount of estrogen in your body by binding it to an enzyme called estrogen receptor (ER) and inhibiting its ability to bind to and activate other proteins on which more hormones need to be bound so they can do their job. Some drugs that block or interfere with this process include methotrexate (Metroxin), spironolactone (Sprycel), cyproterone acetate (Coumadin), norgestimate (Norethindrone), ethinyl estradiol and drospirenone (Vegard), and levonorgestrel (Loratadine). \r

If the level of estrogen is higher than normal (hyperandrogenism), then some of the hormone will still be able to bind to ER but not at enough of a high concentration to interact with the target protein. This means that some progesterone will remain unchanged while there may also be less androgens produced because the target protein is now inactive. This condition is known as Androgena® deficiency. Women suffering from Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), also known as juvenile androgen insensitivity syndrome (JAS) or congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), also experience lower levels of estrogen even though their bodies produce more androgens. Androgen therapy helps restore these elevated levels of estrogen to those found in healthy men.


Answer: Which Pill Should I Take?

Why do people ask me questions about my mental health status?

People often want information on their mental health status because they think that some disease makes them less capable of coping with everyday life. This belief is unfounded; there is no evidence whatsoever that mental illness causes people's ability to cope with daily activities to decrease. People often seek help from psychiatrists and psychologists when they experience difficulties in their lives, especially during difficult times in their lives (e.g., divorce, unemployment). When asked how someone might feel if he were living through the same time period in their life, most people would say "I'd probably just start crying." However, this isn't true either! The person likely wouldn't just cry – rather they would express themselves emotionally, try to understand the situation, and talk to friends and family members about what's going on. In short, asking people why they need help doesn't make sense. They don't know you're trying to help them. You'll only get hurt feelings and maybe even give up. Complete Answer: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is caused by inflammation of the brain and spinal cord. During this inflammatory process, damaged cells break down into substances called proteins that affect how the body functions.\u00a0The damage to the nerves occurs over many years. As a result, MS patients have difficulties controlling their muscles or moving around. In addition, they can become blind if one part of their visual system loses sight temporarily. Because MS usually starts before age 30, most MS patients suffer from it until their 40s. There is currently no known cure for MS, but treatments help reduce symptoms and allow patients to live more independent lives. A person with MS does not actually have lesions in his or her brain. They're simply manifestations of the disease. An immune system attack destroys the brain's outer covering called myelin. Myelinating tissue helps carry signals between nerve cells in the central nervous system. Damage to myelin weakens the connections between these cells and can lead to neurological disability. One way to treat MS is to inhibit the activity of various enzymes involved in the production of certain proteins. These inhibiting drugs help prevent cell destruction and stop attacks on nerve cells. These drugs, such as Tysabri (natalizumab), are often given together with another medication called glatiramer acetate. Glatiramer acetate decreases the ability of activated T cells to attack myelin. People taking Tysabri must take a daily pill containing both medicines. Other MS treatment options include oral steroids (such as prednisone), immunosuppressant therapy (such as cyclophosphamide), and even surgery (such as meningitis). Some of the medications used to treat MS include methotrexate, piroxicam, adalimumab, daclizumab, and inflix

\tYes! A ketogenic/keto diet is appropriate for many types of people with type 1 and 2 diabetes. There is some evidence that a ketogenic/keto diet can be used in combination with other therapeutic approaches such as medication or insulin therapy (for Type 1 and 2) to help reduce blood glucose levels while improving glycemic control or providing long-term treatment benefit.[1]

A ketogenic diet has been shown effective in reducing the amount of carbohydrates you eat,[2] and may have advantages over medications if you're on one. For example, it's often easier to stick to your diet when you don't feel hungry and crave carbs, which means you can stay at a lower carb level and avoid side effects from high levels of insulin. But ketogenic diets also have drawbacks: You must adhere closely to this diet because it requires more frequent monitoring than any other kind of diet.[3] The lack of physical activity and the resulting loss of muscle mass makes it very difficult for someone who is overweight or obese to maintain their weight without losing significant amounts of fat first.[4][5][6][7] The most common adverse reactions to low carbohydrate diets include headache, fatigue, irritability, depression and sometimes nausea.[8] Your doctor should be able to recommend an optimal keto diet based upon your particular needs. If you have already started or plan to start a low carbohydrate diet, talk to your healthcare provider about what to expect from it, and make sure they know what kinds of foods or drinks you'd like to limit as well.

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disorder that affects the central nervous system (CNS). It primarily causes progressive paralysis of your muscles by attacking their protective covering called myelin. The disease also damages many other tissues in the body, such as the heart, lungs, bones and joints, resulting in debilitating symptoms and poor quality of life. The symptoms can vary greatly from person to person depending on the number and location of these areas affected. In general, the symptoms are divided into two main categories: primary and secondary (primary) symptoms.\r

Primary Symptoms \r Primary symptoms may be any of several different types of problems. They occur most frequently at rest or while you're doing something passive like sitting still. These symptoms usually start within 24 hours after exposure to a trigger such as a cold or viral infection. Many people develop some of these symptoms years before they first experience any kind of disability caused by the disease.\r

Secondary Symptoms \r Secondary symptoms typically appear around 30 days after the initial onset of the disease and last for anywhere between 6 months and 3 years. However, these symptoms do not necessarily progress according to time; rather, they can come on suddenly at one point and then go away completely as the body adjusts. Secondary symptoms include muscle weakness, loss of appetite and fatigue, which affect almost everyone with MS. Some secondary symptoms can improve over time, sometimes significantly, but others don't respond well to treatment. If the effects of one symptom persist after 10 years, it's considered a chronic stage.\r

Healthcare providers use standard diagnostic criteria in determining if you have multiple sclerosis. Each type of test has its own strengths and weaknesses, so finding the right one depends on both the patient's age and condition. A history, physical exam and lab work are all important components of making the diagnosis.\r

Diagnostic Tests\r

Your doctor will perform many tests when diagnosing MS. This includes:\r

Blood tests \r These checks assess how much white blood cells (WBCs) and red blood cells (RBCs) there are in your blood. Your doctor may also order more specific tests such as CT scans (CT scans measure bone marrow density); MRI scans (which look at the inner workings of the brain and spinal cord); and PET scans (which measure the amount of certain substances in your blood), among others. WBCs and RBCs detect a wide range of diseases.\r

This includes herbs, minerals, vitamins, amino acids, antioxidants, and other important substances found naturally in our food. It also includes many types of conventional medicine used by most people without knowing it or caring about it. The condition that is known as relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) is characterized by the gradual loss of motor and sensory nerve function, which leads to gradual deterioration in bodily functions such as breathing, swallowing, walking, speaking, hearing, vision, and even thinking. Although it takes months or years for symptoms to develop, patients with RRMS often experience their first relapse within four to six weeks of initial symptom onset, or as soon as one month after the appearance of the first physical signs. It can take decades before most patients have fully recovered from RRMS; however, some individuals may recover completely over many years.[1]\p

\u003cp\u003eIn the United States, there are an estimated 10 million people living with this disabling disease. \u003c\/p\u003e\r

\u003ch3\u003eThe Effects of Multiple Sclerosis on Your Health\u003c\/h3\u003e\r

\u003cp\u003eMultiple sclerosis is a debilitating disorder characterized by the progressive destruction of both myelin sheath and axons, resulting in impaired neural communication between brain cells (neurons). A variety of other symptoms including pain, fatigue, balance problems, memory loss, and mood disorders occur along with these neurological deficits.[2] In addition to these effects, MS affects approximately 1 percent of the U.S. population,[3] although estimates range up to 5 percent.[4] Many patients experience relapses of illness within months or years following initial onset of symptoms. For example, a patient with MS who has been in remission for several years will likely experience an acute relapse (i.e., relapsing remitter) if he or she experiences worsening symptoms.[5]\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca href=\"https:\/\/www.healthline.com\/health\/multiple-sclerosis\" target=_blank style=\"color:#ff0000; text-decoration:none; margin:20px 0 -10px -8px; font-size:14px;\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003enq\u003eIs Multiple Sclerosis Inherited?\u003c\/a\u003e\r

\u003cp\u003eMultiple Sclerosis is most commonly diagnosed when a person with the genetic mutation gene for MS develops the disease at the age of 20 or older.

Ask questions about different treatments such as medication, natural remedies, or diet changes that could help you cope better with your hypothyroidism.\u201dAnswer: \u2018What do I eat?\u201dAnswer: \u201cEat foods that contain iodine. This includes seafood, such as tuna, salmon, and mackerel. Seafood contains small amounts of iodine and can reduce how much T4 is produced by your thyroid gland. If you eat fish only once a week or never at all, try eating it more often and include other foods containing iodine, like soy milk or fortified breakfast cereals, as well as cheese, butter, and eggs. Make sure to ask what kinds of foods contain iodized salt. In addition, ask about taking supplements that contain iodine such as iodine-based soaps and shampoos, multivitamins, and protein powders made from animal products.\u00a0Ask about the effects of food additives, vitamins and minerals on your thyroid hormone level and symptoms. Many foods contain ingredients like thiamin, riboflavin, niacin, vitamin A, calcium, iron, zinc, copper, magnesium, manganese, phosphorus, potassium, selenium, B6, folic acid, and beta carotene. Some of these naturally occurring nutrients have been shown to decrease thyroid activity while others increase it. Other chemicals used in processed foods, drugs, cosmetics, and medications may affect thyroid function. For example, some chemical preservatives are known to inhibit the action of thyroid hormones. Ask whether any food additive(s) would be harmful to your health. Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease with multiple immune system reactions and the cause of many fatigue symptoms. It can also be triggered by other conditions. One possible trigger of MS is the overproduction of certain white blood cells known as T lymphocytes. The production of these cells helps the body fight infection, but their role in causing fatigue is not fully understood yet. In most cases, it appears that fatigue in people with MS has no specific origin; rather, it develops after the body's normal response to illness or injury.

How do we know if sugar has damaged our cells? This damage is caused by the chemical structure of sucrose, which consists of two disaccharides (fructose and glucose) linked together as one molecule by an ester bond (Figure 1).\

Sucrose is made up of fructose and glucose. The sugars' molecular structure (symmetry) allows them to be linked by the same bonds found between water molecules. \

When carbohydrates enter cells, the sugars are converted to free fatty acids and other components of triglyceride and cholesterol (Figure 2), which will then bind with cell membrane lipids to form lipoproteins such as plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1). PAI-1 binds to platelets and prevents their clotting ability from working properly.\

Figure 2


Platelet activation results in inflammation and leads to the formation of clots.\

The progression of this condition can be slowed by certain medications.\rAnswer: What type of medication will help me with my MS?\rResponse: In most cases, MS drugs will not cure your MS but they may reduce symptoms to allow you to live more independent lives. This can also improve quality of life for people who have had multiple sclerosis (MS) before.\r \rQuestions: What types of diseases do I need to check if I have MS?\rFull Answer: If you think you might have MS, then it's important that you see an experienced doctor or neurologist as soon as possible. There are three main types of MS: relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis (RRM), secondary progressive MS (SPMS), and primary progressive MS (PPMD). Each one has different treatments and causes.\r \rQuestions: I want to know what stage I am in. What are the signs and symptoms of each phase?\rAnswer: Relapse of MS occurs when the body no longer responds properly to MS medicine. Relapses are usually sudden (within a few weeks or months after starting treatment). Signs and symptoms change over time. Some relapses occur within the first several years after starting treatment and others occur later in life, after many years of disability.\r You should discuss any changes in your symptoms with your doctor or nurse.\rIn some cases, early relapse of MS can be prevented by using certain medications. Most often, these medications require daily doses that must be taken at least once a day.\rSome individuals recover from their relapses without treatment. Primary progressive multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease which results in the body's own immune system attacking its own nervous system. The main symptoms of primary progressive MS include numbness or paralysis on one side of the body; difficulty walking, speaking, swallowing, and thinking; and problems with balance. Secondary progressive MS can also cause weakness, fatigue, and vision loss.\rQuestion: What are the signs and symptoms of Parkinson\'s disease?\rAnswer: The signs and symptoms of Parkinson\'s disease vary widely from person to person and may be mild (e.g., slowness of movement) to severe (e.g., tremors). Some people do not experience any symptoms at all. A person who has been diagnosed with Parkinson\'s disease usually experiences worsening symptoms over time that may worsen until they become disabling. In addition, Parkinson\'s disease affects different parts of the brain differently. Certain parts of the brain are affected by the condition while other parts remain unaffected. The result is a range of symptoms. The main symptom(s) of Parkinson\'s disease are tremor (also called rigidity), stiffness of muscles (usually the legs and shoulders), involuntary movements of the face, and slurred speech. Other symptoms may include depression, memory problems, trouble with speech, and inability to control motor activities. If you suspect that you have Parkinson\'s disease, please visit your family doctor for evaluation. \rQuestion: How does the diagnosis of diabetes affect my care team?\rAnswer: Diabetic patients often experience long waits at the emergency department or urgent care facility for treatment. Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease that damages the immune system in the central nervous system, causing damage throughout the body (brain, spinal cord, eyes, kidneys, etc.). Symptoms of MS include muscle weakness and stiffness, numbness or tingling sensations, problems with balance, difficulty walking, and fatigue. These symptoms can be caused by many factors including genetics and environmental exposure, but they typically occur within weeks of being diagnosed. The most common MS treatments involve steroids or immunosuppressive drugs like cyclophosphamide. Many patients also take medication for depression or anxiety as well as oral medications used to treat asthma or allergies. People who have MS may notice other problems related to their physical and mental abilities such as memory loss, trouble concentrating, lack of insight into personal thoughts and feelings, vision changes, trouble swallowing or breathing, and inability to perform daily tasks such as driving a car or operating machinery. Because there is no cure for MS, treatment usually involves reducing symptoms over time while improving overall quality of life.\nAdditional Information on Multiple Sclerosis

Questions About Sleep Quality: How Often Are My Dreams Relived?\nAnswer: If you're concerned about your sleep quality, check out our \u003c\/a\u003e Sleep Questions article. There you will find information about how long it takes to fall asleep at night, what happens during REM (rapid eye movement), when dreams occur, and more! It's not easy to determine whether your dream recall falls below average because you aren't always aware of what you are dreaming until you wake up from your nap. However, one thing you should do is keep a diary of all dreams you remember. This helps you to pinpoint specific times when certain things happen so you can figure out if your dreams seem to repeat themselves too often. By keeping a journal, you'll get a better idea of whether you're falling asleep quickly at night or taking longer than usual to fall asleep each night. You should make sure to avoid caffeine before bedtime because this increases your heart rate which triggers your body to start relaxing. Also, try to go to sleep earlier, since waking up early is just a waste of energy and could result in you feeling groggy when you finally wake up in the morning. Remember though that getting enough rest each day can help improve your performance and performance levels in everyday activities such as work and school. So make sure to maintain good sleep habits and you'll likely see improvements in your ability to stay focused and productive!\r

Answer: It's very important that you understand what happens after your period ends, when your body needs something extra to help fight off infection or protect against allergic reactions. There are many women who end up needing these medications even though they had taken them at no time prior to conception. These medicines tend to cause birth defects, such as spina bifida (a birth defect that makes a baby's spine crooked), in children whose mothers were taking them while they were pregnant. Therefore, if you're considering using these kinds of drugs, make sure you understand how long those chemicals stay in your bloodstream and whether taking them on top of your regular routine will put you at risk for problems later.

Q: Can I smoke while breastfeeding?\r

Answer: Some research shows that smoking while breastfeeding could pose risks for both mom and child. There isn't enough evidence yet to determine whether smoking actually causes harmful effects like lung cancer or heart disease. Smoking during pregnancy can increase the chance that your newborn will develop asthma, which can result in severe breathing difficulties for the infant. What is hypnosis?
Answer: Hypnosis was first described in 1798 by German physician August Wilhelm Stekel, who defined it as "a state of consciousness characterized by unconsciousness of thought and by voluntary suspension of all volition."
What is deep sleep?
Answer: Deep sleep is a period between two successive awakenings during which physiological functions are suspended and memory consolidation occurs. It is an essential stage of recovery following any kind of traumatic brain injury or seizure and can lead to better quality of life.
How does brain regeneration work? 
Answer: Brain regeneration is the process by which nerve cells regenerate after being injured or destroyed. In the case of trauma, the nervous system's natural repair mechanisms begin to function again. The process of regeneration takes several months, depending on the nature of the injuries, and results in new nerve cell growth and restoration of brain cells to their healthy resting state. A traumatic brain injury typically leads to permanent disability in which the affected parts of the brain continue to function poorly, resulting in some degree of functional impairment. A person may have problems with learning and remembering information; speech, reading, and writing skills may be impaired; social interactions and physical activity may be difficult; and daily activities such as eating, sleeping, and walking become more difficult due to decreased attention span, increased anxiety, reduced motor skills, and loss of balance.
Does the mind control the body?
Answer: Not entirely. However, many people believe there must be something going on between the mind and body if we feel so relaxed when we're asleep. This belief has led to the development of various alternative therapies aimed at bringing relaxation into everyday life. These therapies include meditation, self-hypnosis, biofeedback, yoga, massage, chiropractic care, osteopathy, acupuncture, electrical stimulation of nerves, therapeutic touch, sound and light therapy, biofeedback training, and even astrology. Many of these practices do not require medications, and no drugs are involved in most cases.
