"The goal of this study was to understand how people interpret various types of information that they receive from medical sources and how they make decisions when interpreting these information," said study co-author Dr. David M. Buss, associate professor of medicine at the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio. "We found that most consumers use multiple different methods when making choices about whether or not an intervention they want to implement will help them achieve their goals."

Buss' team studied 2,000 adults who filled out a survey on the web site Quora asking questions such as "How important is it for someone to have access to a well-educated healthcare provider?" and "How much does healthcare cost in our country?" They also asked participants about their own experiences with health care providers, including their doctors and nurses, along with questions like, "What is your impression of your doctor?"

Responses to the first question were measured using several variables designed by researchers to capture a variety of factors, including demographic characteristics (gender, age group, income) and medical history. Questions on healthcare costs were analyzed by measuring the likelihood that respondents would say, "I am currently paying more than I should because my insurance company hasn't been keeping up with its payments for medications and treatments," based on responses to another question regarding financial responsibility.

In addition to answering questions about personal experience with healthcare providers, study participants answered other questions related to the overall quality of health care provided by healthcare providers; how likely respondents were to recommend their doctor or hospital to others; and a final question about how much they thought each of their top five health care providers were charging per visit. These measures allowed the researchers to identify which factors contributed to the decisions individuals made about whether or not to pay attention to their healthcare providers.

text:
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is characterized by the progressive loss of motor and sensory functions as well as cognitive function in the brain. The typical signs and symptoms that MS patients experience include numbness or tingling sensations along with muscle weakness and spasticity. An estimated 1 out of 100 people will develop MS over their lifetime. However, as many as 70 percent of MS cases go undiagnosed until late stages. Many women who have had MS suffer from debilitating pain as they age and can also experience nerve damage. If you know someone who has MS, it is important for you to be available to provide assistance. A good starting point for learning more about MS is www.ms.org\u00a0www.emedicine.com/medguide/topic3279.htm. Although there is no cure for MS, treatment includes medications and nutritional supplements that may help alleviate some of the disease's symptoms. In fact, the most widely used drugs for treating MS are beta blockers such as diltiazem (Imodium), lamotrigine (Lamictal), and primidone (Primobolan). Dietary changes also play an important role in managing the disease. Some of these dietary changes include reducing alcohol intake, limiting coffee, avoiding processed meats, and consuming at least six servings of fruits and vegetables per day. Other lifestyle changes such as taking care of your heart, keeping blood pressure in check, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising regularly, and eating plenty of fresh fruit and vegetable foods and whole grains are also necessary to improve overall health. You should discuss any concerns with your doctor before beginning any new diet plans.\r

Chronic disease is one of the leading causes of death in industrialized societies today. It has a direct impact on personal well being and economic productivity. The three biggest categories of chronic conditions include: (1) cardiovascular disease; (2) type 2 diabetes mellitus; and (3) cancer. In addition, there are other ailments that affect people's lives such as infections, digestive problems, and mental illnesses. Each person responds differently to certain conditions because of genetic differences or environmental influences. For example, some people who are obese, have high blood pressure, are prone to chronic lung problems, or suffer from allergies may be able to take better care of themselves than others. The major risk factors for these diseases are excess weight, physical inactivity, poor diet, lack of exercise, tobacco use, alcohol consumption, and inadequate sleep. Health problems associated with obesity can also lead to metabolic syndrome which is a combination of high blood pressure, cholesterol, blood sugar, triglycerides, and low HDL levels. Cancer is caused by abnormal cells called tumors, and they grow uncontrolled when there is an imbalance between normal cell growth and apoptosis which occurs when cells stop dividing due to damage. This imbalance creates new tumor cells that eventually become malignant. Common cancers include prostate, breast, colon, rectum, ovarian, thyroid, kidney, pancreas, throat, skin, and head and neck. Many healthy individuals develop symptoms due to their own genetics but not everyone will experience any significant problems. Those with known predisposing factors such as smoking, high blood pressure, poor diet, and excessive alcohol intake are at highest risk. Some common lifestyle choices like eating foods rich in cholesterol, alcohol, trans fats, and processed meats increase your chances of developing chronic disease. Your best bet is to eat a balanced diet rich in fruits and vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts and seeds, fish, and healthy fats. To help you achieve this goal, consult a physician before making changes in your diet. If you would like more information on how to prevent chronic diseases and manage them properly, please visit www.healthtalkguide.com

Many of my colleagues have no idea that I am MS (motor neurone disease) or that I can be so slow to respond to questions. Most employers aren't aware either. The only way you can be prepared for an unexpected question is by having written information on hand. You might ask your boss or the HR manager in charge of human resources to set up a meeting with him/her for this purpose. In addition, it's important that if your employer does find out that you're MS, they know what you do and don't disclose regarding your disability. They may make allowances as needed because they assume you'll continue doing your job as usual. That said, if you need special accommodations in order to perform your job, get them in writing before you tell your employer or try to take time off. Finally, keep in mind that you may not always be able to give the same answer to all questions related to your disability. If someone asks about your symptoms, you must explain the nature of your impairment; however, when trying to figure out which type of therapy would be most effective for me, for example, I usually won't necessarily know the specific treatment I'd prefer. But I'll have a good understanding of what the doctor has prescribed based on my past experiences and research, and I'll know what I'm likely to experience during each episode. So even though you may not have the exact words to describe your condition, you should still provide information and answers in a clear manner.

If you're concerned about your ability to talk about your condition with co-workers, consider these additional tips. Keep in mind that the more people you speak with about the issue, the better. If you speak to one person per day about your illness, you should probably start by getting permission from your supervisor or HR representative. Also, be careful about how many times you share your diagnosis with coworkers—the more often you do this, the harder it becomes to get help and support if you do end up needing it. And remember, there's no shame in being honest about your condition! Don't feel like there's anything wrong with speaking up if you are afraid of making others uncomfortable. There are plenty of ways you can say it just right without crossing any boundaries.

Be sure to check back later today for a post where we discuss some other ways you can communicate your medical status in a positive and nonjudgmental manner.

text:
Ketosis is the body's natural reaction to starvation or inadequate food intake. It is caused by an excessive production of ketone bodies (beta hydroxybutyrate) in the liver due to elevated levels of fatty acids produced from protein breakdown (the process known as lipolysis). Most people will naturally lose some body fat during periods of starvation because fat cells have a limited capacity to produce energy. Fat loss is necessary for keeping your blood sugar level under control. This can be achieved through increased physical activity, or by reducing calorie consumption so that you consume fewer calories overall than you burn. The ketogenic diet is one way to achieve this. An excess of beta hydroxybutyrate in the bloodstream causes a number of physiological changes including, but not limited to, a lower than normal blood glucose concentration, which leads to ketoacidosis and the unpleasant symptoms associated with it such as headaches, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, weakness, confusion, abdominal cramps, and sometimes seizures or coma. A low blood glucose concentration also causes muscle and joint pain, fatigue, and depression, which may result in weight loss on a low carb, ketogenic diet. It should be noted that the ketogenic diet does not cause all of these symptoms; only those caused by a low carbohydrate diet. Because the body has many mechanisms that regulate glucose levels in the blood, a low carb diet has been shown to increase insulin sensitivity. In fact, many studies suggest that eating very few carbohydrates increases metabolism enough to allow the body to utilize dietary fat rather than glycogen for fuel. Many experts agree that most individuals who follow a ketogenic diet experience significant improvements in their quality of life.\r

"While there is no exact proof that consuming fat makes you healthier, the research suggests otherwise. While there is no specific scientific evidence proving that a low carb diet can prevent chronic disease, the general consensus among doctors is that eating more healthy fats and less saturated fat reduces risk factors related to heart disease, type 2 diabetes and obesity." \r

"Although researchers continue to find beneficial effects of certain types of fat in our diets, they do not yet fully understand how fats interact with proteins, carbohydrates, and vitamins and minerals in ways that make them good or bad for us. Scientists have also discovered that many people respond best to different types of fats. For instance, polyunsaturated fats have anti-inflammatory properties while saturated fats tend to contribute to cholesterol build up and increase the amount of triglycerides in the blood."

How do I know if my HDL ("good") cholesterol is too low?\r

Answer: If your triglycerides are elevated, then a healthy HDL "cholesterol" level should generally be at least 50 mg per deciliter (0.5 mmol/L).\r

\r

How do I know if my LDL ("bad") cholesterol is too high?\r

Answer: If your triglycerides are elevated, then a healthy LDL "cholesterol" level should usually be between 80 and 120 mg/dL (2.1 and 3.7 mmol/L), depending on age.\r

\r

What happens to my HDL and LDL when I lose weight?\r

Answer: Your HDL cholesterol will increase while your LDL will decrease. Losing weight reduces insulin resistance. As a result, your triglyceride levels will drop and HDL levels will rise. This process can take several weeks or months. During this time period, your doctor might recommend taking fibrates or statins to lower your LDL cholesterol and keep your HDL levels up.\r

\r

Is diet soda bad for me?\r

Answer: Diet soda contains artificial sweeteners, chemicals linked to obesity and diabetes.

At this stage of the disease, it's important that you don't stop having sexual relations until you've been diagnosed, treated, or found a cure. Even then, some men will still experience trouble during their sexuality. In addition, MS can cause chronic fatigue and general aches and pains. This can make your day-to-day life very difficult at times. 
Answer: Why do I need treatment if I'm in good health?

But even healthy individuals may develop some level of symptoms that can negatively effect their quality of life, so they should consult with their doctor before starting any new activity (or quitting one that isn't necessary or that doesn't involve risk). The main objective of treatment is to slow down, reduce, or eliminate the symptoms, which may include pain, numbness/tingling sensations, visual disturbances, tingling, loss of feeling, fatigue, dizziness, sleep disorders, and depression (which could lead to suicidal thoughts or behavior). Treatment also includes medications to treat blood clots (venous thromboembolism) and to lessen inflammation (arthritis), to improve vision, balance, memory, strength, and coordination. 
Answer: What else can happen with MS?

\u201cMultiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks the nerve fibers that carry signals from the brain and spinal cord to the rest of your body. It affects millions worldwide; some people with MS have no symptoms but others experience severe disability and even death.\r

\u201d Multiple sclerosis typically develops during childhood or adolescence. There are several factors that influence how likely it will develop, including environmental exposures such as infections (including pneumonia), genetics, age at first infection and exposure to other viruses, medications, diseases and conditions, and infections caused by bacteria. The condition may also worsen when you're older than 40 years old.\r

\u201cThe rate of relapse for multiple sclerosis is approximately 50%. This means that while you should be able to lead a full life without experiencing any new symptoms, there is still a chance of developing the disorder again after time passes.[/quote]

text:
Mental Health Problems \nCommon mental health conditions include depression, anxiety, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), substance abuse disorders, eating disorders, and personality disorders.\

Mental illnesses are complex, but they may be caused by physical or emotional factors such as depression, anemia, chronic pain, etc.. There is no specific cure for any of these illnesses. For example, depression is typically not cured with drugs, even if you take them. However, there are medications that can help decrease symptoms, like antidepressants. In addition, research suggests that medication alone does not work well in treating all cases, and it's possible that some people respond better to psychotherapy.\r


Other mental illness symptoms that might be present include hallucinations, delusions, severe headaches, obsessive thoughts, insomnia, poor concentration, and difficulty sleeping. These symptoms may seem minor at first, but over time, they become more debilitating and often cause significant problems. If left untreated, mental illness will eventually develop into a full-blown psychiatric condition called schizophrenia. Symptoms of depression, anxiety, PTSD, substance abuse disorders, and personality disorders can also lead to serious complications, including suicidal behavior, self-injury, drug use, eating disorders, sexual dysfunction, and criminal behavior.\r

What questions do patients ask online?

Many mental health users have questions that go beyond the basics of their health condition. Patients want information on everything from how to start treatment to whether they should pursue certain types of therapy. Patients want guidance on things like diet, exercise, and social situations. They also want to know when to seek support, and what kinds of resources are available for them. The internet has made it easier than ever before for consumers to find information about mental health, so patients are able to choose providers who offer assistance and advice based on their personal needs. Many patients are able to find support in groups focused around particular issues such as suicide prevention, healthy relationships, and coping skills for dealing with depression or anxiety.\r

How much time do patients spend searching for information online?

A recent study found that approximately 50 percent of Americans used the Internet to view medical images, videos, and other information related to their own health. Another study conducted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that nearly 35 percent of adults use the Internet to look up information about their current or past medical care.\r

Answer: There are no clear-cut treatment regimens for major depression, but there are some strategies that may be effective for most patients. These include therapy, medication (such as antidepressants, mood stabilizers, or electroconvulsive therapy), and lifestyle changes, among others. Many experts believe that the combination of these therapies helps people who struggle with the disease achieve better functioning while also reducing its severity and duration.  Questions: What should I eat before taking antidepressants?
Answer: According to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), it is generally safe to take antidepressants before a meal. Some doctors recommend waiting 10 minutes after eating, though others strongly caution against eating immediately before taking antidepressants. Even so, eating before taking an antidepressant is unlikely to cause side effects and may actually provide you with the nutrients needed during the day. Most studies show that eating within 30 minutes of taking a drug improves appetite and decreases withdrawal signs. However, you should check with your doctor first about whether you should consume food with the medication to ensure that this won't interfere with your treatment.

\nA medical condition in which the immune system destroys healthy cells throughout the body, causing them to multiply uncontrollably. The disease is caused by an abnormal response from white blood cells called lymphocytes that attack healthy brain tissue. A person with relapsing remitting MS often has problems swallowing, speaking, walking or even breathing. It can cause weakness of joints (arthritis) as well as severe muscle pain. A person may feel fatigued, have blurred vision, trouble concentrating and lose memory. These symptoms usually improve with medication. In most cases, people will recover completely if they get proper treatment at an early stage. Relapses do occur though, so it's important for caregivers not to give up on their loved one once symptoms start to worsen.\r Question: How much does spinal cord injury affect my body? Complete Answer: Spinal cord injury affects your entire body in some way. Your brain and spinal cord control many vital functions including movement, sensation, hearing, speech, swallowing, swallowing, breathing, and heart rate. There are numerous ways in which damage occurs to nerve cells in the spine. Each type of damage affects a different part of your body. An example would be a broken neck where there are injuries to nerves that help you move your head. Damage to other areas of your body may include:

Fractures (bone breaks) in your bones.

Tearing of soft tissues such as skin or cartilage.

Damage to your organs such as the heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, etc.

The following can also happen after a traumatic incident. They can range from minor cuts and bruises to more serious conditions like spinal cord damage:

Bleeding between two vertebrae.

Second, the symptoms of reading problems are often caused by other physical or mental conditions which should be considered before considering any treatment. Also, each person has different strengths and weaknesses when it comes to reading, so it is essential to discuss any concerns with your doctor or specialist and work through any problems together.
Third, there are over-the-counter and prescription medications available to treat some types of reading difficulties. Other medication treatments include the antihistamine diphenhydramine (Benadryl), which reduces eye itching; the anticholinergic drug propranolol, which helps relieve sleepiness during the daytime; and fluoxetine, which helps increase attention span and calmness in depressed patients. 
Fourth, if you have problems with reading comprehension, a test called the Raven Progressive Matrices provides a measure of reading ability. This type of test requires reading aloud a series of sentences in order, followed by responding appropriately.

\nFitness and the brain\nMS is characterized by weakness of the central nervous system. This can affect balance, coordination, mood and ability to concentrate.\r

In MS, there can be changes in the structure of neurons within the spinal cord. This may cause the patient's muscles or nerves to become weaker. A weakened central nervous system can increase susceptibility to fatigue from any source such as exercise, illness, toxins, trauma, sleep deprivation, infections, depression, medication side effects, etc.\r

Other factors that can weaken the CNS include age, gender, genetics (including hypothyroidism), environmental exposures (e.g., drugs, radiation exposure, tobacco smoke) and certain medications such as those used for epilepsy. \r


What is FIT?\r

FIT stands for Functional Imaging Training. FIT provides training materials on how to perform functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). The goal of these exercises is to help participants better understand what they see during fMRI scans and then use this information in their daily lives and clinical practice. In addition to improving participants' understanding of fMRI, FIT also focuses on improving their skills using techniques that improve accuracy and reproducibility in image processing. These techniques include multiple-regression analysis, segmentation, group comparisons, cluster enlargement, automated segmentation, thresholding, statistical tests, regression analysis and classification, image normalization and transformation, signal enhancement, visualization, data reduction and presentation, and more. By doing these types of training exercises, participants have the opportunity to gain valuable practical expertise and new techniques necessary to conduct research and develop improved diagnostic tools.

For a list of all current FIT courses offered by MSU, please visit www.imagingmedicine.org/training/.

How does fMRI work?

Functional MRI (fMRI) measures blood flow through an area of the brain while subjects view pictures that appear on a computer screen and move one of two cursor keys. As the participant moves the mouse over the images, the volume of each area of interest increases or decreases based on whether the region is active or not (active regions contain greater activity than non-active areas). Scientists use this information to determine if the area has changed due to physical damage or disease. At this time, fMRI cannot detect every kind of change in the body but it can identify the patterns of neural activation associated with specific conditions or diseases. An fMRI study often involves hundreds of participants and many thousands

This is a disease in which the immune system attacks the myelin sheath that surrounds nerve fibers.
Q2: Primary or secondary?
Answer: The two main types of MS are primary or secondary; they occur in roughly equal numbers among people diagnosed with MS.
Q3: What causes MS?
Answer: People who have MS may develop it from damage caused by an autoimmune attack on the nervous system triggered when proteins called autoantigens — substances that normally act as "weapons" against invading viruses — start attacking the body's own tissues. In some people, a single trigger can cause the development of both forms of MS.
Q4: How does MS progress?
Answer: As your body tries to repair itself after exposure to a first immune response (called an antibody reaction) that triggers autoimmunity, new antibodies become stronger and more numerous. Eventually, you begin to experience symptoms similar to those associated with MS. Symptoms include fatigue, muscle weakness, vision problems, balance disorders, sleep problems and trouble thinking clearly. Some people also have difficulty swallowing or breathing, but these conditions usually improve over time.
Q5: Why is treatment so important for treating MS?
Answer: Treatment begins with the diagnosis. It's not uncommon for some patients to be misdiagnosed because their symptoms don't seem like signs or symptoms of MS. Also, many people believe they will get better on their own if they just take medicine. But often these treatments do nothing and only make things worse. Therefore, doctors must diagnose you before beginning any type of treatment, such as drugs, surgery, corticosteroid injections or other therapies, such as acupuncture. They might even recommend surgical procedures, such as neurosurgery, if they think your condition cannot be improved by existing medication.
Q6: Does MS affect others?
Answer: Yes, according to one study involving 856 participants with MS. Those who were treated with either steroids or interferon beta did significantly better than those given neither treatment. However, it should be noted that this study focused on the effects of steroid therapy on the skin and did not examine its effect on nerves within the spinal cord. Although there haven't been enough studies done yet to show whether steroids work differently on the brain compared to nerves, researchers say that steroids could possibly help reduce the activity of certain neurotransmitters, thereby affecting the nervous system.
Q7: Is it possible to cure MS?
Answer: Not likely.

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease caused by antibodies attacking the myelin sheath that surrounds nerve cells throughout the body. People with MS experience loss of muscle control, weakness, numbness, difficulty walking, blurred vision and speech and problems hearing. Because this type of disability results from damage to brain tissue, symptoms may progress over time or not show up at all in some people. \nAnswer: If you have experienced a stroke, then your doctor would first want to know if it was triggered by an underlying neurological condition such as MS or another neurologic disorder. In most cases, however, the cause of strokes has been identified through research. This may include genetic mutations in certain genes responsible for causing stroke, stroke prevention drugs, a recent head injury or trauma, or some other factor. The doctor will also look for any changes in how you act after experiencing a stroke and make sure you receive regular followup care.

\nAnswer: The recommended dose is 1 mL (0.12 mL/kg) intramuscularly or 0.5 mL subcutaneously once every 6 months for 4 years.[7] This number can vary by individual based on the severity of their disease and how long they have been taking medications and supplements.[8] To date, no studies involving the safety of the Vaccinia virus strain have been published.[9][10] There have also been questions regarding whether patients who have received the vaccine may be more susceptible to influenza viruses than those that did not receive the vaccine.[11]. Therefore, it is best to discuss the benefits and risks associated with vaccinating against flu or other illnesses with your physician prior to receiving the vaccination.[12]

The Vaccinia virus strain contains human papillomavirus and some strains contain human herpesvirus type 14. Each of the vaccines available contains elements from both species, with HPV being the most prevalent form of HPV infection. In addition, many HPV types do not cause cancer, but rather genital warts. Some HPV types can also trigger cervical cancer, especially in women who were previously infected with an HPV type known as HPV16, which was included in the original HPV4 vaccine. However, there is growing concern over the increase of infections caused by the HPV18-related virus type 6, which causes precancerous lesions that resemble genital warts. These precancerous lesions typically occur several years before the symptoms of cervical cancer appear.[13] For more information please see: http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6533a2.htm.

Q1: What is a spondylolisthesis?\nAnswer: A spondylolisthesis is where one or both of your lower back bones ("sponds") become fused together after an injury occurs. An example would be if you had a fall, accident, trauma, surgery or another event that damages the lower back. The result could be fusion, dislocations, ligament tears and/or stress fractures. Spinal fusion in this case might lead to lower back pain, instability or even spinal cord compression. You might also experience pain in a joint called atlantoaxial joint or hip dislocation. Spinal fusion results in permanent changes to your spine and your body.\r

When providing medical information, please remember to avoid stating that you "think" something is true when you do not know what medical science says about it. For example, when evaluating whether or not to tell a patient they have cancer based solely on their family history, do not say "I think so." Instead, state that you believe that the disease is more likely than not caused by an inherited genetic mutation.\nExample:\t{\rm{My opinion on this topic is based on my clinical training and extensive research into hereditary causes of cancers. Q: Should I use my feet when doing squats?
Answer: You should not squat with your toes pointed straight ahead; instead, place your heels flat against a wall or mat. This will allow more flexibility in your ankle joints, which can then facilitate a better squat position.
The most effective technique is to bend forward at the waist while keeping your torso tight. The heel drop enables greater depth and stability in the squat, while the raised knee position prevents excessive sliding during the descent.

Q: What's the best way to do leg curls?
Answer: Leg curls should be performed standing up with your legs extended out parallel to each other, so that your thighs rest against a wall or mat. Keep your feet close together while lifting your knees off the floor.
Leg curls can be combined with leg extension exercises such as pushups or lunges to further enhance their effectiveness. Also make sure that you keep your arms overhead until you reach full range of motion.
Q: How many sets of crunches should I do before training?
Answer: Ideally, you should complete 3-5 repetitions per set, but individual results may vary depending on your height and build. A good rule of thumb is to aim to finish between 10 and 20 reps.
Keep in mind that some people may find it difficult to maintain strict form for very long periods of time, making them uncomfortable. If so, gradually add weight to your workout, ensuring that you're able to complete all 10-20 reps without any discomfort. For instance, if you normally take 8 minutes to complete the crunches above, try using 40% less weight.

It is important for patients with metastatic disease to get the best possible prognosis from their physicians. There are three types of outcomes that can occur in this stage of cancer: (1) remission; (2) recurrence or spread beyond initial site; and (3) death (or "mortality"). In general, patients with advanced disease who have failed to respond adequately to standard therapy will be diagnosed as having relapsed. As long as treatment remains available, however, most relapse cases can be managed effectively by improving the patient's quality of life through lifestyle changes such as exercise or dietary modifications.\

In many instances, relapses may not lead to treatment failure but rather into successful progression through multiple stages of management. The most common reason for a patient's relapse is an inability to follow the diet and physical activity recommendations made by his or her physician. If it becomes evident that you cannot live on your current diet and training regimen, then your doctor should begin to evaluate other options. The main consideration when deciding whether you need further evaluation is whether the relapse is the result of a biological response to the treatment plan rather than the treatment itself. To learn more about the biology of treatment response, visit the National Cancer Institute at www.cancer.gov. \r

Chronic diarrhea is the most commonly diagnosed form of food intolerance in North America. It affects more than 20 million people around the world. You may experience symptoms when you eat foods that contain an enzyme called lactase that helps digest milk products, especially cow's milk. These digestive problems cause bloating, diarrhea (often accompanied by vomiting), cramping, pain, constipation, abdominal discomfort, weight loss, fatigue, headache, or dizziness. The digestive symptoms often resolve on their own within one day after your first meal without further treatment. However, some individuals do not have normal gut bacteria and still suffer from this condition. If you suspect you may be suffering from chronic diarrhea, consult with your physician. If you don't have any symptoms or can't remember what happened before you became ill, you probably did not get sick because you ate an item containing lactose or another nutrient that was missing in the dairy product. The reason for these conditions is unknown, but it could be that your intestinal tract has been altered due to poor nutrition, such as malnutrition, antibiotic use, trauma, smoking, high stress levels, environmental contamination, and other causes. This could explain why you had diarrheal symptoms instead of nausea. \u003c\/span\u003e \u003cp class=\"p1\"\u003eThe exact mechanism behind this condition remains unclear, although several theories exist. Certain types of bacteria living in your intestines break down lactose into glucose, which is then absorbed into your bloodstream for energy. Others believe that certain enzymes in the mouth help break down lactose into smaller molecules so they're easier absorbed by your cells. In addition, there are many cases of individuals who report having chronic diarrhea but never actually consumed any fermented milk product, such as kefir or cheese. Because these individuals are lactose intolerant, their bodies may also produce lactic acid in response to an overabundance of sugar in the blood. However, no scientific evidence supports this theory at this time. Another explanation for the problem is that too much bacteria in the gut (and possibly other organs) means that the body becomes overwhelmed with lactose. It turns out that the stomach and small intestine handle large amounts of sugars very well. So if bacteria in the gut cannot process the lactose properly, it ends up in your stools where it binds together

A. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is an inherited connective tissue disorder that causes painful muscle spasms. It is characterized by the presence of thickened skin on the face, neck, arms and legs, as well as deep indentations in the muscles and bones in those areas. \r

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can also cause joint problems such as patellofemoral hypermobility, which affects the knee joints; fibromyalgia, a chronic fatigue state that includes multiple physical symptoms, including headaches, sleep disturbances, memory issues, and more; rheumatoid arthritis, a form of inflammation of the joints; and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). The symptoms of IBS can range from mild discomfort or bloating to severe abdominal cramping and diarrhea. There's no cure for either EDS or IBS but treatments with antihistamines and steroids may be effective. Both IBS and EDS need regular treatment. Read more about Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome.

Q: How does my body work?\nAnswer: Your body works because it is made up of trillions of cells called cells. Cellular processes include moving oxygen around your blood vessels, breaking down food into nutrients, making proteins and hormones, regulating your metabolism and providing energy to other parts of the body. While every cell in your body performs these functions exactly the same way, some cells have different ways of doing them than others. For example, white blood cells carry out specific tasks, like fighting infections or stopping viruses, while red blood cells help you fight against infections and keep your organs healthy. Learn more about what makes each type of cell do what they do, how cancer cells work, and why cancer is so deadly.


How does my body make insulin?\nAnswer: Insulin is one of three types of hormones produced in your pancreas, along with glucagon and somatostatin. These hormone are secreted into your bloodstream when certain foods stimulate your cells to produce glucose from carbohydrates (glucose being the main sugar found in food), or when glucose levels drop too low in the blood. Glucose levels rise after eating foods containing carbohydrates, and remain high until the next meal comes along. These hormones then tell your cells to use protein to create glycogen and release stored glucose into the bloodstream.

\nThe stage 4 triple positive (TPN) breast cancer treatment is the most invasive form of breast cancer. It generally takes longer than other types to spread throughout your body but can be cured with surgery after you have exhausted all treatments.\r

To find out more about this type of breast cancer, refer to: \r

What are the characteristics of triple negative breast cancer?\r

\r

Q. What are the characteristics of triple negative breast cancer?\r\nA. The characteristic that distinguishes triple negative from other kinds of breast cancers is its ability to hide tumors through the use of an abnormal protein called PD-1. This protein protects cells during normal cell growth processes. However, when PD-1 is inhibited by certain drugs or radiation, the tumors grow unchecked, which leads to them becoming resistant to chemotherapy.\r

The main purpose of PD-1 inhibitors is to stop tumor growth while allowing normal cells to continue dividing freely. However, as PD-1 inhibitors become less effective over time, some patients develop resistance. In such cases, other strategies must be used to suppress the tumors and prevent metastasis.


Accordingly, doctors often administer a drug called docetaxel (Vayarin®) before radiotherapy in order to block PD-1 activity on the surface of malignant cells so they cannot evade destruction. If docetaxel becomes ineffective or there are no suitable PD-1 inhibitors available, then chemotherapy may be administered instead. For these reasons, triple negative breast cancer is one of the most difficult kinds of breast cancer for physicians to diagnose accurately.\r

Other characteristics include a slow rate of tumor progression and poor prognosis. Therefore, triple negative breast cancer is not usually treated aggressively; it is typically treated with hormone therapy until the disease has progressed into stages 2 or 3. When stage 1 disease progresses, radiation treatment is given. Once stage 2 or 3 disease develops, surgery may be considered if certain criteria are met.


Because triple negative breast cancer tends to be particularly aggressive, it is best to receive regular follow up examinations by a specialist at least every 5 years.

Studies suggest that stressful events such as work, family obligations, and school can trigger a negative response from the body called "fight or flight". This reaction is similar to how we get tired during exercise. While your body prepares to fight the event, this can result in fatigue. One way to prevent or alleviate your problem is to learn how to relax, so your body doesn't react with stress responses while you rest. You could try to find some relaxation techniques on the web (like listening to music), read a book, take a yoga class, meditate, or seek out a good friend who does relaxation exercises to help you sleep better.

The ketogenic / keto diet is an effective treatment of type 2 diabetes in adults that improves the blood sugar control of patients by limiting glucose consumption and/or improving insulin sensitivity while allowing more calories from fat than carbohydrates to be consumed.[1]

What is the Ketosis Diet?

The ketosis diet (KD) is a dietary therapy used as a lifestyle modification program for Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetes (T2DM). It uses fat restriction and a higher carbohydrate intake, specifically as a result of high glycemic index foods such as wheat, potatoes, pasta, breads, rice, nuts, seeds, dairy products, sweeteners, etc., but does not include any other sources of protein, which would also increase the risk for T2DM. In contrast, the Atkins Diet has a lower carbohydrate intake (<40g daily), but includes some animal proteins, thus lowering the risk for T2DM. Both diets have been shown to reduce the glycaemic response to a meal in both diabetic and non-diabetic individuals. However, the KD differs from the Atkins Diet in that it encourages a reduction in the amount of carbohydrate-containing foods and therefore may lead to greater body weight loss during the first 2 weeks compared to the Atkins Diet. Additionally, the KD restricts the total amount of carbs, including sugars, that can be eaten on one day. This should encourage low carb eating habits throughout the week.

A person on the KD will typically consume a relatively large dose of fats, usually up to 80% of their calorie needs. On average, the individual on the KD will not eat a lot of protein (about 30% of calories), nor do they have much energy. However, if you follow these guidelines, you will notice dramatic improvements in your symptoms. Many of the benefits of the KD include:

Decreased appetite.

Increased energy.

Reduced inflammation, muscle weakness, loss of bone mass, increased stamina and strength, better sleep, less cramping and headaches and improved immune function.

Improved skin and hair texture.

Less chance of developing heart disease or stroke.

Improvement in cholesterol and triglyceride levels.

Easier digestion, overall reduced anxiety, depression, fatigue and irritability.

Better mood and well being.

Lowers cholesterol.

Decreases blood pressure and blood sugar.

Improves mental clarity.

Supports brain health and metabolism.

Improved sex drive.

Improved quality of

Multiple Sclerosis is an autoimmune disease that attacks the brain and spinal cord by destroying myelin sheaths, which form the insulation of nerve fibers in the central nervous system (CNS). It can lead to paralysis or blindness. Your symptoms usually develop gradually over many months. You'll probably be able to walk again after several months if you take medicine every day for at least two weeks; otherwise it may be difficult to regain your strength.\r

\r

Answer: \u201cMultiple Sclerosis (MS)\" says MS-UK on its website. \"This is not a disease where one day you have a sudden onset of illness, nor does it appear suddenly at any time. In fact it starts years before – often as soon as someone graduates from high school and becomes employed, or even when they attend university.\" \u201dThere are three types of MS - relapsing/remitting (MSR), primary progressive (PP) and secondary progressive (SP). Each type has different symptoms and treatment options. Relapses are generally defined as the return of MS symptoms within 6 months. The main symptom in PP MS is weakness or numbness in both arms or legs that occurs 2-5 times per month. The symptoms usually become worse over 3-4 days then disappear completely. SP MS typically begins with a few small spots called demyelinating lesions appearing in the brain and spine. These rapidly progress and cause more damage until lesions cover large areas of the body. Symptoms include severe headaches, muscle weakness, impaired vision, trouble swallowing, blurred vision, hearing problems, and involuntary movements. There is no cure for any type of MS but there are treatments available. Talk to your doctor about what is best for you.\r


Answer:\u201cWhat are the symptoms of multiple sclerosis?\u201dThe symptoms of MS vary greatly among individuals. Common symptoms include weakness (often in limbs); difficulty walking, sitting and lifting heavy objects; fatigue; sleep difficulties; memory loss; bladder dysfunction; and infections such as pneumonia, sinusitis and urinary tract infection. A person who is suffering from MS could experience a number of different neurological signs and symptoms. For example, you might notice changes in speech, balance, or gait; pain in your joints; chronic coughs; painful muscles or spasms; shortness of breath; dizziness; seizures; or vision disturbances including double vision. Question: What is an intrauterine device?
Complete Answer: An IUD is an implantable device that can prevent or reduce the chance of getting pregnant by preventing sperm from reaching the egg, either through an external coil or through hormones. The IUD has two pieces of flexible plastic called threads, which can be removed after intercourse. After removal of one piece of thread, the other remains inside the body, like a small Tic Tac ring. If you have had unprotected sex since your last use of contraception, you may need to change your method of protection for 1 month before using another type of birth control such as condoms, spermicides, or a diaphragm.
Question: How long does it take an IUD to work?
Complete Answer: It depends on many factors including: the brand and model of IUD; how frequently you have intercourse; what position and if any you're currently using; whether you've been sexually active recently with men who aren't married or living together; and whether your provider is familiar with and uses the right type of IUD. Because there's no way to predict how long an individual will get pregnant while using an IUD, all women should make sure they know their best course of action if anything unexpected happens during insertion, even if the process feels uncomfortable or painful.
Question: What do I do if my IUD won't stay in place?
Complete Answer: Contact your provider immediately and tell her you want to remove your IUD or have it removed. Even if your provider doesn't seem surprised by your request, she'll likely ask some questions first, especially if you're having difficulty pulling out the IUD or if the IUD isn't making it much easier. Once you've answered those questions satisfactorily, you might have your IUD removed without any issues occurring. Your provider may also perform a pelvic exam, ultrasound, or blood test. You don't usually feel any pain at the time of the procedure. When you come home from the hospital, check in with your provider to make sure everything went well. Most providers offer these services free of charge.

text:
LONGEVITY, DEATH AND HEALTH EFFECTS OF THE LONG TERM

Long term effects of the aging process include an increased risk for many chronic diseases, including cancer and cardiovascular disease. Certain cancers can also be caused by aging as well as other life-threatening conditions that often develop later in life like diabetes, osteoporosis or heart failure. The increase in risks is not limited to those of old age but applies to children too (see section entitled "Children" below). Long-term effects of aging include an increased rate of death from some causes and increasing rates of disability due to others. A person's overall survival depends on a number of factors, including their age at onset, length of time since diagnosis and underlying illness. For example, a 60 year old who developed cancer two years ago and had been healthy until then may now die within three months because he was diagnosed with early stage cancer in his late 50s. On the flip side, if a 40 year old patient shows no ill effect from his recent bout of prostate cancer then it seems likely that prostate cancer will have become inactive over the past five years which would mean his chances of dying during the next 5 years is zero. If the same man had been treated in childhood and developed cancer only 3 months after diagnosis, his chance of surviving 10 years would have risen to less than 1%. There is no simple answer to whether one should get treatment before or after the development of illness or whether any given person has sufficient time to overcome the negative consequences of aging before making such decisions. However, there are ways that people can take steps to improve their overall quality of life while avoiding or delaying the more serious adverse effects of aging. To learn how you can do this, visit www.ageingcure.com

MEDICAL REQUIREMENTS

Age-related conditions vary greatly throughout the world due to differences in genetics, environment and lifestyle. In general, older adults are generally healthier and live longer when compared to younger individuals. Health conditions associated with aging include:

Heart disease - People who are 70+ suffer twice as much heart disease as 20-29 year olds. Some studies show that the rate of heart disease doubles among the elderly. Heart disease also increases significantly in the last decade of life. The first signs of heart disease can appear as early as your 20's. It is a major cause of premature death, especially among the elderly, and a leading cause of blindness. Other symptoms of heart disease include chest pains, shortness of

MS is an autoimmune disease that can strike anyone at any age. The risk of developing MS increases with time after the onset of first symptoms. A person's chances of developing MS can be lowered by taking immunosuppressive medications such as steroids or corticosteroids before they develop severe symptoms. However, people who have not had previous attacks of MS may still develop it if they take certain medications that interfere with their immune system's ability to recognize foreign invaders. These include some types of antibiotics like ciprofloxacin (Cipro) which may cause permanent damage to your liver or kidneys; penicillin (Pen); macrolides like azithromycin (Zithromax); azole antifungal drugs like ketoconazole (Nizoral); fluconazole (Tampanel), minocycline (Minocin); sulfasalazine (Erythromycin). In addition, it is possible for you to get MS even though you've never been diagnosed with the condition.\r

\r

What causes MS?\r

MS is a chronic inflammatory disease caused by the body's own immune system attacking its own tissue. It can affect many parts of the body in different ways including the brain, spinal cord, optic nerve, joints, skin and eyes. The exact causes are unknown but research indicates that several factors could contribute to the development of this condition.\r

\r

Who gets MS?\r

The risk of getting MS varies among individuals based on environmental factors, genetics, sex, age, family history of the condition, the amount of inflammation present in the tissues, how much inflammation there is, exposure to toxins, and other biological factors. When you're young, the risk of developing MS may seem higher because of the relative ease of acquiring the disorder. As you grow older, your risk of developing MS declines because you build up more of your own natural defenses against invading bacteria and viruses. Research has also shown that genetic factors influence whether someone develops MS early or late in life. Certain genes predispose people to a higher incidence of MS while others increase their risk of developing it later in life. Some studies have suggested that the presence of these inherited genes explains why most people do not develop MS during childhood \r

\r

How does MS progress?\r

Research suggests that MS progresses differently in men and women and that it changes over time according to whether it's being caused by environmental

Eyeglasses may be considered high risk if they cause symptoms like redness or irritation when worn by people who have diabetes, heart disease, stroke, certain cancers, liver diseases, kidney disease, or other conditions that can affect vision. Some eyewear also may not protect against the sun's harmful ultraviolet rays. For example, many sunglasses prevent UV light from reaching the retina but do nothing to shield your eyes from UV radiation from sunlight. \nThe first stage is when the body is unable to produce enough of an enzyme called IL1 beta by itself. During this phase, there are symptoms such as weakness, numbness and tingling in arms and legs. This occurs because your immune system is not able to recognize the signal from your own body's cells that tell it to make antibodies against foreign proteins in your tissues. When you come down with multiple sclerosis, the disease becomes chronic. The second stage is inflammation, which means the immune system has begun to attack its own tissue. Symptoms include fatigue, loss of muscle strength, difficulty walking or sitting up. You may also experience vision problems as well as other types of brain damage including memory loss, confusion, difficulty concentrating, dizziness and fainting, depression, anxiety and sleeplessness. In the third stage, inflammation has spread to your bones. Your joints become inflamed so badly that they break easily. Your feet may swell and become painful and painful urination can be difficult. Eventually, your muscles will start to weaken. In the final stage, the body's ability to respond to a normal infection causes permanent damage to the lining of the bowel. Once multiple sclerosis hits your 50s, you're likely to live a long time, but you'll still have problems with getting around, walking and breathing.\r

Learn More About Multiple Sclerosis | Learn How To Reduce Your Risk Of Developing Multiple Sclerosis

This is an autoimmune disease that attacks the body's own cells, which damage or kill nerve fibers. When MS occurs in the brain (primary progressive), it affects mainly the central nervous system. It usually begins with numbness of some parts of the body and gradually spreads to other areas as the disease progresses. The symptoms can vary widely from person to person, and they can be similar for people who have been diagnosed later in life. There are many different types of MS, but they all generally cause progressive loss of muscle strength, speech problems, and difficulty swallowing and breathing. Other symptoms may include headaches, vision changes, or seizures.\pQ: What is my risk of developing MS?
A: Your chance of getting MS depends on several factors. You're more likely to develop it if you've had at least one episode of multiple sclerosis before age 30, if your mother was born with it when she was younger than 40 years old, or if you were exposed to certain chemicals or pollutants while growing up. Also, people who smoke or drink alcohol are less likely to get MS than others. In addition, your overall health has been shown to play a role in how often you develop MS. For example, those who are overweight or obese are much more likely to develop MS.\pQ: How does MS begin?
A: At first, MS symptoms are like those caused by other diseases, such as high blood pressure, diabetes, and heart disease. Eventually, however, people develop neurological signs or symptoms. These may include loss of balance, slurred speech, or trouble walking. Sometimes the most obvious signs occur right away — for example, your vision suddenly becomes blurry or you lose consciousness.\pQ: How does MS progress?
A: As MS continues, patients experience worsening effects over time. Some people will have no symptoms at all after one or two years. Others eventually show symptoms of full-blown MS. After 10 years, there is typically improvement, though not always. Sometimes, people who initially respond well to treatment go into remission and never develop MS again.\pQ: How can I help prevent MS?
A: If you've recently developed any of these conditions, talk to your doctor now about taking steps to protect yourself against MS.

What can I do if a doctor refuses to prescribe me an antibiotic for my sore throat?

A doctor might refuse to prescribe antibiotics to you because he or she doesn't know what the medication will do to your body's immune system, or to prevent bacterial infection in the nose. If you're not sure whether an antibiotic would help, ask the doctor how long it would take to see results, and if it could be dangerous if taken too soon. It's better to get an antibiotic now when the problem occurs so the infection can be treated effectively before the damage sets in.

Do I need to take medicine as prescribed by a doctor?

No. You don't need any medicines unless they aren't helping. Doctors sometimes prescribe certain over-the-counter medications such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen to relieve pain caused by colds, flus, flu, and minor injuries. But these medications usually won't cure a cold, nor will they reduce the severity or length of the symptoms. Even though they're available without prescription, you should never stop taking them until they've helped you, even if you think they haven't. The same holds true for most over-the-counter medications.

I've heard that many doctors say that you should just use warm compresses on your sore throat as a way to ease the discomfort. Can you explain that?

Nope! Cold compresses won't make it go away. They'll probably only make it worse, especially if you rub the area too hard. Just sit down, relax, and breathe deeply through your mouth. Your throat muscles won't contract in response to the compression, but your heart rate and breathing will slow. That means the sore throat will stay less painful until the next day, at least. Some people also experience chest pain or tightness while they're having an attack. Aspirin can help reduce the amount of mucus that gets into your lungs. It helps prevent infections in both the airways (known as alveolar inflammation) and the lungs. In addition, it may also relieve muscle aches, pain, weakness, or fatigue. You should always ask your doctor how much aspirin you need before taking them.\nQuestion: How do I know if I have cystic fibrosis?\rComplete Answer: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic condition in which there is a build up of thick, sticky deposits called mucus inside the lungs. This accumulation usually occurs because of an overproduction of mucus cells in the lung lining (lung tissue). These buildup has resulted in a type of pulmonary hypertension known as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Lungs with high levels of mucus contain excess fluid, increasing pressure inside the lungs, causing swelling and narrowing the airflow through the lungs. Although COPD is caused by many factors, genetics play an important role in determining whether you will get these symptoms. The main genes involved in getting CF are related to the production of mucus cells, including Muc2 and Fos (Fas and Cdc42), which are often mutated in patients with CF. When these mutations occur, the normal functions of the genes involved become compromised. As a result, more mucus accumulates, and it collects on the walls of the lungs, interfering with their ability to function properly.\rQuestions: What does it mean when someone is "tired" or feeling "crappy"?\rComplete Answer: A person who is tired or fatigued typically feels less energetic than usual; this may be due to lower energy level during the day and/or decreased physical activity. Neck stretches are a great way to loosen up your neck! To stretch the neck muscles, lie on your back with your arms at your sides. Keep your head up straight by keeping your chin down. Lift both elbows off of your knees (keep them as high or higher than your shoulders) and lean forward until your chest is parallel to the floor. Keeping your arms straight, slowly lower yourself down so that you can reach your hands out in front of your body. Repeat this exercise for 30 seconds and then repeat it again for 15 seconds; hold each position for 3 minutes. \r

Complete Answer: Shoulder stretches are a great way to loosen up the pectorals, especially when paired with your arm stretches. Hold your arms straight overhead while you extend your hips to relax your shoulders. Then place one hand behind your back, allowing your elbows to bend slightly at the elbow joint. Keep your upper back flat against the wall and lift your torso into an upright position. Continue to lower your upper back down until your chin touches the ground. Return to the starting position and repeat for 5 sets of 10 repetitions. Your shoulder muscles will be stretched and your posture relaxed during this exercise. \r

Complete Answer: Hip flexor stretches are a great way to strengthen those pesky hip flexors. Lie on your side with your legs crossed and feet pointing toward the ceiling. Bend at the waist and pull your tailbone towards your spine. Slowly bring your buttock back into line with your spine, then push your pelvis backwards so that your knee points directly beneath your thigh. Once your buttocks are aligned, return to the starting position and repeat for 5 sets of 10 repetitions. If your hamstrings feel tight, use a foam roller to massage these areas before performing this exercise. Also, don't forget to warm up after doing all of this stretching. The following are some other great hamstring stretches that you could try next time you visit the gym. \r

\nChronic diarrhea is the name given by doctors for a group of gastrointestinal (GI) complaints that may last from several days to several weeks or even months. These symptoms can range from mild cramps, gas, bloating, nausea, and diarrhea to more serious problems like dehydration, hemorrhage and perforation. The cause of most chronic diarrhea is unknown, but there are some general theories. Some people with severe cases suffer from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). IBS can be triggered by changes in diet or medications, or it can result after eating too much sugar. Many people experience GI symptoms while they're on certain medicines such as chemotherapy drugs or steroids. Others have had their digestive system damaged due to cancer treatments or surgery. Doctors often suspect a GI disorder when patients complain of unexplained fatigue or abdominal pain in addition to the usual constipation, flatulence and diarrhea. Chronic diarrhea is treated using medication, diet changes, exercise, and sometimes antibiotics. For more information visit the links below\u00a0 \u00a0 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14374934

Vitamin D Deficiency - This condition causes your skin color to change slightly yellowish or greenish brown. You will also notice that you sweat more than normal, especially during winter. There is no cure for this condition and it does not usually affect most children. Vitamin A deficiency - If you lack vitamin A in your diet, your skin color will turn dark green. This is because vitamin A decreases the amount of melanin in your skin cells, which makes them darker. Skin pigmentation is important for lightening hair. Niacin (B3) deficiency - People who are deficient in niacin will become pale or gray instead of their normally pink skin tone. A good source of niacin is eggs from hens fed a daily dose of niacin.

How does diabetes affect your life?\nAnswer: Diabetes is caused by an imbalance between sugar (sugar) and energy in the blood. It occurs when the amount of sugar in the bloodstream exceeds the body's ability to process sugars. When that happens, the brain turns off its own cells' ability to use sugar for fuel and begins storing fat instead. There are several types of diabetes. Type 1 diabetes is characterized by frequent urination, loss of appetite, fatigue, skin rashes, muscle aches, headaches, joint pain, memory problems, and dizziness or lightheadedness.\r

\r

Type 2 diabetes is characterized by high blood sugar levels and frequently occurring weight gain or obesity. High blood sugar levels can cause serious complications such as blindness, kidney failure, heart attack, stroke, amputation, and death. It is estimated that up to 3% of Americans have type 2 diabetes.\r

\r

In particular, I am interested in understanding the role of stress hormones and neuroendocrine systems in aging. Therefore, I am especially focused on developing new strategies and drugs that will slow down the rate at which individuals age and slow the progression of existing disorders.\r

That means any bacteria she ingests during pregnancy could pass on to her developing lungs and possibly trigger a severe reaction. Most of these bugs come from mom's skin, but some may be passed through breast milk. A healthy diet that includes plenty of fruits and vegetables will help keep your child safe from infection. If your newborn needs medication for his respiratory problems, ask your pediatrician if he can give it to him early. He'll usually advise giving your baby two to three days' worth at first, followed by increasing the dose gradually over several weeks until he reaches age 2 years. In case of emergency, contact your local hospital emergency room right away. See a doctor immediately if your infant starts coughing excessively with rapid, sharp chest movements. text: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks the central nervous system (CNS) causing loss of vision, paralysis, and a wide range of other symptoms. The first sign of MS is usually visual problems such as blurriness, blurred vision or double vision (sitting up straighter than usual). The second symptom is weakness on one side of your body called myoclonus (slower movement), sometimes caused by weakness of motor neurons (muscles that control arm movements); this may lead to difficulty with grasping objects, including your own hand. A third characteristic of MS is a sudden onset of pain, often in a single limb. In some cases, the weakness can be permanent.MS causes damage to the CNS and is not curable. There are currently no cures for MS. Treatment involves suppressing the immune system to prevent further damage. Symptoms will improve over time when the immune system is restored, but this is not always possible. Some people who have had MS for several years may develop relapses after several years of treatment. You should talk with a doctor about whether you need to continue taking medications, such as corticosteroids, if you experience sudden worsening of your symptoms.\nQuestions:\tWhat do I do if someone asks me what the best way to treat my MS is?\nAnswer: There is no right answer to this question. It all depends on how severe your MS is, how long you've been living with it, and your personal preferences. Your physician will decide what works best. For example, some doctors recommend a combination of different drugs, others prescribe an immunosuppressant medicine, while still others may choose to use only one drug at a time. Most physicians try to find a medication that is effective against both MS and its triggers. Although it's never too late to start taking medication for MS, it may take 2-3 months to see improvement. If you don't feel well or think your symptoms worsen, contact your physician before making any changes.If you're concerned about using certain types of MS medicines, discuss them with your physician. For instance, it isn't uncommon for patients to want to stop their treatments when they learn that another type of MS medicine has less side effects or doesn't require a prescription. Ask questions like how often the medicine is taken, what dosage you'll need, and how frequently your doctor will monitor your progress.In addition, make sure your doctor knows about other diseases or conditions that may affect your ability to tolerate medicines. Question: What causes MS?
Answer: MS develops as a result of two different types of degenerative diseases in the central nervous system (CNS). The first type is called autoimmune disease, where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues and organs. In this case, it attacks myelin sheaths, which protect nerve cells from injury and infections. This leads to inflammation that damages axons, or long strands of neurons that extend throughout the brain and spinal cord, ultimately leading to damage of these structures. These axon branches eventually become tangled and lose connections, resulting in impaired signal transmission through the nerves. The second type of MS is called demyelinating disease, which involves damage to the brainstem or parts of the cerebellum. In this condition, the brainstem becomes abnormally sensitive to electrical stimulation and experiences severe tingling or paralysis. Both types of MS cause disability and death, and each has some risk factors for progression to other forms of the disease such as optic neuritis or peripheral neuropathy. Because both types of MS are characterized by progressive loss of function, scientists use the terms "primary" and "secondary" MS to describe them. Primary MS results when the initial attack against the CNS begins, usually between ages 40 and 50 years old. Secondary MS, meanwhile, occurs later in adulthood, around age 60 years. It can be treated with medications, including antifungal drugs and steroids, and is commonly managed through rehabilitation programs and home healthcare.

The key words here are "and" and "or."\r Answer: Some people think that medications are better than diet in treating certain illnesses, but this isn't true. It takes more than just one medication to cure a condition. Sometimes lifestyle changes, exercise, and healthy eating habits help prevent or manage a number of chronic diseases. Some diseases, like obesity, can only be treated by weight loss and/or dietary modification.\r Answer: You'll also want to look for the latest research on any new treatments or cures and make sure that your doctors understand the current medical understanding regarding them. In other words, if you're having trouble finding information on new treatments or cures, ask about research being done right now to develop them. Also remember that drugs and medicines often aren't available until the end of their patent term (the period of time after which the drug company has exclusive rights to sell it). When considering a possible new treatment, consider whether there is enough evidence to support its effectiveness within a reasonable amount of time. Ask about FDA approval processes. These allow drugs to be approved for sale once they pass safety trials and are proven safe. You should check with your pharmacist to find out how long it typically takes before a drug can be marketed.\r Question: Many people believe that eating red meat increases the risk of developing cancer, especially colorectal cancer. Step 1 - Conduct a thorough examination using a hand mirror\r

Step 2 - Remove all of the fleas from the affected area with a small vacuum cleaner bag filled with rubbing alcohol\r

Step 3 - Take a picture of the fleas with your smartphone, which will help you determine where the fleas originated from\r

Step 4 - Contact your veterinarian or pest control service to ensure removal of the fleas\r

Step 5 - Rinse the pets with water for 30 minutes\r

Step 6 - Repeat Steps 1 through 7, but now use a cotton swab instead of rubbing alcohol to remove the dead fleas\r

Repeat Steps 1 through 5 until you have removed all of the fleas from the affected area\r

Keep in mind, some fleas can remain dormant for several months before becoming active again. When your pet returns home after a long trip away, they may have a few lingering fleas on their body. If they still appear to have fleas when they return home, you may need to reexamine them more carefully.

Q: What are the three best things that can help prevent my child from developing Alzheimer's Disease?\r Complete Answer: Early detection and intervention are key in preventing Alzheimer's disease. Your healthcare provider should tell you which tests he/she recommends. For example, your healthcare provider could ask about medications you take, including herbal supplements. These medications could decrease the risk of developing Alzheimer's Disease. If you develop dementia after starting any medication, talk to your healthcare professional immediately so changes can be made. Some medications used to treat MS can affect certain brain cells known as amyloid beta. Amyloid beta levels increase in the brains of people who already have Alzheimer's Disease. Therefore, taking medications that lower amyloid beta levels can slow progression of Alzheimer's Disease. Also, physical activity increases amyloid beta levels naturally in the brain. Physical activity helps clear out amyloid beta, thus reducing its harmful impact.\r

\r

--------------------------> Eczema is a chronic skin condition caused by bacteria that can grow on the skin or in the mucous membranes of the upper respiratory tract (nasal cavity). It can cause redness, swelling, itchiness, and other symptoms. The most common type of eczema is atopic dermatitis. Atopy refers to an allergic reaction to allergens found on the surface of the body rather than to foods such as food dyes. The cause of allergy is unknown but may be related to certain environmental exposures. Symptoms vary with the severity of exposure. Most people have very mild reactions to some types of allergen. People who suffer from allergies often develop severe reactions after an event involving a particular allergen. Some people are more likely to experience serious reactions than others. Allergies occur in every culture around the world. If you have any questions about these diseases, please call your doctor for advice before visiting your local pharmacy.

Multiple Sclerosis affects more than one million people each year in the United States. In most cases, MS can be successfully treated with medication. However, some patients have an autoimmune reaction that causes symptoms similar to MS. People who have this type of reaction usually respond well to medications and may even recover completely from their disease. The main treatment for relapsing forms of MS is called immune stimulation therapy or immunomodulatory therapy (IMT). IMT involves taking immunoglobulin drugs – medicines that stimulate the body's own immune system against specific diseases such as MS. This type of treatment typically takes 5-6 months to begin working. If it doesn't work within 3-4 weeks, doctors sometimes recommend adding other treatments like corticosteroids or steroids to try to get the antibodies to attack the disease cells again. This approach has been shown to help improve outcomes in many patients. In the future, immunotherapy could also be used to treat other types of cancer. An estimated 1 in 15 people will develop MS over their lifetime. It often strikes young adults and is most prevalent among blacks. It affects men and women equally. The average age at onset is 50 years old.

What is Myelin?\nQuestion: What exactly is myelin?\nAnswer: Myelin is the fatty sheath surrounding nerve fibers inside our nervous systems and protects them from damage. It contains special proteins called oligomers and consists of thousands of tiny fibers. These are highly conductive and allow electrical impulses and chemical signals between nerve cells to move through the brain and spinal cord, nerves of the eyes and ears and muscles. Each nerve cell has a different myelin layer. During development, myelin production depends on the number of cells in your brain and the length of time they stay in a particular area. A few cells from a nerve cell will start producing myelination as it grows. The older the cell becomes, the longer it stays in the same place. Eventually the cells stop growing and die off. A group of neurons containing axons in your brain known as dendrites develops a thicker and thicker myelin covering each day, making the connections between its individual neurons stronger. At the same time, new neuron bodies grow in the outer layers, so the surface area of these new neurons increases as well. Thus, the total surface area of the myelin coating of the entire developing brain increases from one to two square centimeters per week.
