text: \u201cLong term effects likelihood multiple sclerosis,\u201d a disease characterized by the progressive loss of myelin sheaths around nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord, is caused primarily by an abnormal immune response. The cause of this abnormal immune response remains unknown. It has been speculated that there may be some connection between various autoimmune diseases and this syndrome.\u2026 Although many patients experience improvement over time with appropriate treatment, no controlled clinical trials have shown that any specific cure exists for MS. More research on this condition will help us better understand its causes. In addition, it is estimated that up to 75% of people who start treatment with a vaccine for MS develop relapses of their original disease within two years of starting the course of therapy.\u201cMultiple Sclerosis (MS) is a debilitating, degenerative disorder. Although there are currently no known cures or treatments, there are effective interventions available for managing symptoms as well as delaying progression of the illness. Multiple sclerosis affects about 1.2 million Americans, and about 10 percent die from the disease each year. A vaccine for MS was approved in 2000 for use in children ages 6 through 15. The vaccine prevents the development of antibodies that would normally trigger a severe inflammatory response to infection. This leads to a gradual slowing down of disease activity. Current guidelines recommend the vaccination of all individuals at least four times during childhood.The CDC estimates that as many as 25,000 new cases of MS occur in the United States every year. About 2,500 of these newly diagnosed cases are women, and the vast majority of them suffer from multiple sclerosis with onset before age 30. Approximately 95 percent of all individuals with MS live with no disability beyond the limitations imposed by the disease itself, however, and are expected to live into their 60s or 70s.According to the National Institutes of Health, the average life expectancy for individuals with MS is 5.6 years less than those without MS. However, as much as half of all deaths due to MS can be prevented if early detection and treatment begins earlier. For example, MS sufferers tend to develop the disease at older ages. If they receive timely diagnosis and treatment, most of these individuals will avoid experiencing serious complications such as stroke or respiratory problems.In addition to the standard physical examination, you should also perform a thorough history and physical exam. While your physician might ask you questions regarding past illnesses, he or she does not need to know about current medical conditions, recent surgeries, allergies, genetic predispositions, allergies or other

Multiple sclerosis is the most common inherited neurological disease in the United States. The term "disease" is used loosely here because MS affects different parts of the body at various times, resulting in varying degrees of disability. Most commonly affected areas are the brain, spinal cord, optic nerves (the nerve that allows us to see), peripheral nervous system (including your muscles, joints, skin, blood vessels, and digestive tract), and heart. \r

The three major forms of MS are:\r

1) Primary progressive;\r

2) Secondary progressive; and\r

3) Non-progressive.\r

Primary Progressive \r

MS is characterized by a series of recurring attacks or periods when symptoms first appear. These attacks may be mild, moderate, or severe, but often last from several months to several years and may occur every few weeks or so.\r

These attacks can cause significant impairment to everyday life. For example, they interfere with daily activities such as walking, typing on the keyboard, reading, writing, caring for oneself, using the bathroom, dressing, and more.\r

Symptoms typically begin slowly, then quickly get worse. Symptoms may fluctuate over time; some patients experience none while others have a number of them throughout their lives. Many patients also report that they do not remember the onset or severity of their symptoms until much later in life. Some people who develop this form of MS will never regain full use of all of their senses, although they may continue to function well enough to perform routine tasks such as eating, drinking, driving, playing sports, and working.\r

Some people who develop this type of MS do eventually experience partial recovery from their disabilities, however these individuals usually remain severely impaired for the rest of their lives. Although it's difficult to predict whether someone will develop this form of MS after a particular point, if you're thinking about getting tested for it, please discuss any future testing decisions with your doctor.\r

Secondary Progressives \r

This form of MS generally develops between ages 20-40. While other types of MS are caused by damage to the same part of the central nervous system (cranium), secondary progressive MS occurs due to damage to another part of the nervous system called the spinal cord. This type of MS causes an attack of inflammation of the lining of the spinal canal within the skull known as cerebrospinal fluid leaks. In addition to causing disability, these

Mental disorders, including anxiety, depression, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and psychosis, affect nearly every American of any age (and in many cases, at some point during their lives). A variety of diseases also are associated with mental illness: diabetes, arthritis, cancer, and Alzheimer's disease. In addition, there is a wide range of conditions that cause physical symptoms or behavior changes, such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), obesity, and alcohol dependence. Many people have psychological issues they don't know they have because their brain chemistry isn't working right. For example, you may be experiencing stress or grief from an abusive childhood; your mind is wired differently than it should be for coping with stressors; or your body responds too slowly when stressed out. These types of problems aren't typically recognized until after a person has experienced them; therefore, the sooner someone realizes they are having difficulty with something, the better able he/she will be to deal with it. If you have these kinds of difficulties, your doctor may refer you to a specialist who specializes in treating this kind of problem. 
How do I tell if I'm depressed or anxious?
Answer: Depression is the major mood disorder affecting Americans today. It affects approximately 15% of adults aged 18 to 64 years, while anxiety affects another 10%. Both disorders are characterized by low self-esteem, feelings of hopelessness, excessive worry, sadness, guilt, helplessness, fatigue, loss of interest in activities once enjoyed, decreased energy, insomnia, and/or weight gain. When untreated, both emotional and behavioral symptoms can lead to serious long-term consequences. The key treatment for both disorders involves addressing underlying causes, such as biological (such as an imbalance in neurotransmitters) and environmental factors (like life stresses or life events). As part of these treatments, medications may be prescribed to help treat the physical symptoms. Medications used to treat depression include selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), lithium, and tricyclic antidepressants. Other medications used for anxiety or mood disorders include benzodiazepines, antihistamines, and antidepressants such as imipramine, paroxetine, trazadone, venlafaxin, sertraline, and others. An article on this website includes information about other types of medications used to address these two types of conditions.

The first step in treating MS is to identify the cause of your symptoms. Symptoms may be due to another condition such as an autoimmune disease or mental illness. If you have been diagnosed with MS, take a physical exam and receive a thorough neurology evaluation by a physician who specializes in MS. The physician will also recommend specific treatments for you based on your history and current symptoms. After treatment, if it was successful, you should continue to follow up with your doctor once per year to monitor any side effects that are noticeable. In addition to a physical examination, a physician will usually order brain scans, spinal taps, MRIs and echocardiograms (stress tests). Although these exams can't show what's going on inside the brain, they provide important information about how the body is functioning. Sometimes MRIs can reveal abnormalities that point towards possible problems in your nervous system. For example, there are several types of lesions called white matter lesions that are associated with MS. These areas contain some of the most severe damage to the CNS, causing a person's neurological function to decline over time. It can help determine if any lesions exist in an MRI scan, but it can still look like other conditions. For this reason, some doctors prescribe medications that target particular white matter lesions while others focus on improving overall functional abilities. You will likely need both laboratory tests and imaging tests. Laboratory tests can tell doctors if you're having abnormal changes in certain biochemical processes in your blood that may lead to MS. Imaging tests help detect the presence of nerve cells (neurons) and their connections throughout the central nervous system in a more detailed way than lab testing. When using imaging tests, your doctor may request additional testing if he or she thinks the results could indicate a new disease process. Other potential causes of MS symptoms include toxins, infections, pregnancy and hormonal issues. Many times women with MS report experiencing symptoms during menopause or after childbirth. Hypothyroidism is a condition that leads to the body's production of too much thyroid hormone, which can interfere with your body's ability to function properly. It also causes other metabolic problems such as fatigue, weight gain, depression, and increased cholesterol levels.
Question: how long does it take to get better?
Answer: 
Once you have been diagnosed by an endocrinologist or doctor, treatment takes place in a hospital setting. Treatment options include medicines (such as levothyroxine and clomiphene) taken by mouth, injections (such as thyroxine patches), or surgery (which can involve removal of the entire thyroid gland).
Question: what happens when you go off medication? How many times?
Answer: As mentioned previously, once a person has had enough hypothyroidism medications (i.e., they are 'on the shelf'), there will be no need for them again until their levels drop back down below normal. There are several different ways to reduce the amount of hormones you produce: diet, exercise, thyroid supplements (for adults only), and/or taking thyroid hormone replacement therapy (also called T4 or synthetic thyroid hormone).
Question: is hypothyroidism dangerous?
Answer: Hypothyroidism may cause serious complications including heart disease, high blood pressure, stroke, nerve damage, vision loss, seizures, infertility, and even death. While most people experience some degree of hypothyroidism throughout life, some do not. When this happens, hypothyroidism is generally treated by lifestyle changes that bring your hormone levels into optimal range and limit any negative effects on your health.

If you feel unwell while using Adderall, talk to your doctor about switching to another form of treatment such as stimulants (medicines that help improve concentration, motivation and energy) or anti-depressants.\r


How do I store Adderall?

Keep Adderall out of the sight and reach of children. Keep away from heat and direct light.

Store at room temperature away from moisture and heat.

Do not open without a prescription.

Ask a doctor or pharmacist if you have questions about the best way to store Adderall.

I am a chronic pain patient suffering from fibromyalgia (pain without any known cause) and I would like to know more about the treatment options available for my condition. Complete Answer: Fibromyalgia is a disease characterized by widespread pain throughout the body caused by damage to nerve cells located at the base of the neck. Although the exact cause of fibromyalgia has been unknown, scientists now believe that a combination of genetic and environmental factors contribute to its development. These factors include genetic predisposition toward inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease, lupus erythematosus, ulcerative colitis, and certain autoimmune disorders. It also involves disruptions to the immune system, which results in an imbalance between normal white blood cell production and inflammation. The resulting inflammation leads to swelling in parts of the body including the legs and feet, joints, heart, lungs, intestines, skin, brain, kidneys, testes, adrenals, pancreas, and adrenal glands. Symptoms of fibromyalgia range from mild to severe and are similar to those of many other illnesses including asthma, diabetes, headaches, joint pain, back pain, insomnia, irritable bowel syndrome, anxiety disorder, depression, and even HIV infection. Most people who suffer from fibromyalgia do not seek professional medical attention because they feel too embarrassed to talk about their discomfort to family members or friends. However, when treated appropriately, there is good evidence that treating fibromyalgia is beneficial for most patients. Treatments include pharmacological treatments and non-pharmacological treatments. Pharmacological treatments include anti-inflammatory drugs such as acetaminophen and ibuprofen; antihypertensives such as naproxen sodium; and beta blockers such as propranolol. Non-pharmaceutical treatments include acupuncture,

The main symptom of multiple sclerosis is loss of the ability to move and speak. This results from damage to the part of your brain responsible for these functions. There are two types of MS - relapsing-remitting and primary progressive. Relapsing-remitting MS occurs when there are frequent relapses. If this type of MS does not improve, it may be classified as secondary progressive MS. Primary progressive MS also has frequent relapses but is less severe than relapsing remitting MS.\ nWhat causes multiple sclerosis?\

Answer: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disorder caused by the body's immune system attacking healthy cells in your central nervous system (CNS). This can affect any part of your CNS, including the spinal cord and the optic nerve. Most people with MS have a "leaky" blood vessel near their brain called an optic neuropathy. In some cases, the problem is so severe that there is no blood supply to much of the brain at all. These patients often go blind and cannot see anything clearly. Sometimes these patients have problems with balance or coordination, movement or balance problems, hearing, vision or speech difficulties, memory or language problems, headaches and vision changes. Some patients with MS develop sensory symptoms, like tingling, numbness or pain in the hands, feet or face. Some people who develop MS later in life develop chronic fatigue syndrome, which involves fatigue, muscle weakness, unexplained weight gain, poor sleep, difficulty concentrating and more.\ nHow is multiple sclerosis diagnosed?\

Answer: You will need to visit your doctor for a physical examination and ask questions about your family history and any family members with MS. Your doctors will probably order tests and procedures, such as: CT scan, which uses x rays or other radiation to look inside the head; MRI, which uses magnetic fields to image large areas around the body; PET scans, which use radioactive substances to look at how chemicals are produced and stored in the body; Lumbar puncture, which looks at the back of the neck for signs of infection or fluid leaking into the spinal canal; and spinal tap, which checks the nerves to make sure they are functioning properly. It might take several weeks before your doctor diagnoses you with MS and gives you specific treatment instructions based on your symptoms.\ nIs my child at risk for developing multiple sclerosis?\

Answer: Children are most likely to get MS if one parent has the disease, especially if both parents are affected. Children tend to outgrow their initial symptoms

The term secondary progressive MS (SPMS) refers to the early stage of multiple sclerosis that may be associated with significant neurological dysfunction prior to clinical symptoms. The typical onset is between 12 and 18 months after diagnosis but can occur as early as 6 months postdiagnosis. In most cases, SPMS does not appear until symptoms become more severe than in the presence of other forms of MS; however, it can occasionally present at any point along the course. It often progresses from relapsing–remitting to progressive, characterized by worsening of disability over time. Symptoms may include numbness or tingling sensations on the affected limb, weakness on one side of the body, difficulty walking, problems with balance or coordination, visual disturbances such as double vision or loss of vision, and/or speech changes such as slurring or stammering. Primary progressive MS (PPMS), which also may begin during this first phase, involves widespread loss of neuromuscular function including muscle strength and range of motion, and irreversible nerve damage. There is no known cure for either form of MS. Most patients achieve partial improvement during periods when they are receiving treatment while others do not improve or continue to deteriorate.\nSecondary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis \nAnswer:

Primary progressive MS (PPMS): This form of MS is the most common type. PPs typically develop between the ages of 35 and 70 years old; 40% of all people diagnosed with primary progressive MS will have been younger than 45. People suffering from PPS have progressively worsened neurologic impairment since their initial diagnosis of PPS. These individuals usually exhibit signs and symptoms of deterioration beginning 3 weeks before onset of the classic disease course or progression of the disease. Many symptoms experienced by PPs are similar to those seen with other forms of MS, although there are some differences in appearance. For example, PPs typically experience a wide variety of neurocognitive deficits, including confusion, memory issues, difficulty concentrating, poor attention span and decreased concentration, memory lapses, impaired judgment and decision making, trouble learning new information, poor judgement regarding social interactions, depression, irritability, anxiety, and obsessive-compulsive behavior. The majority of patients who have had SPMS demonstrate progressive neurologic sequelae with increasing severity and disability from the earliest stages of the disease. Because of the long latency period associated with PPS, an individual's risk for developing PPMS is lower than that of having SPMS. Although there is no clear correlation between the two diseases, there has been a

Multiple Sclerosis is not related to sleep problems or forgetting. However, some cases of MS are more severe than others. In general the number of symptoms increases with age and MS often progresses with age. Some cases may be milder than other cases and it can take years for MS to progress to full disability. It's important that your doctor knows what you think MS symptoms mean for you and how long they have been occurring. They will decide if further testing should be done.\nQuestion: What causes chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS)?\nAnswer: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) is a chronic illness characterized by persistent physical, psychological, social, emotional, and/or mental symptoms. Symptoms usually begin during middle age or later. The most common types of CFS include Acute Fatigue Syndrome (AFS), Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS), Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), and Social Phobia. A person must suffer from at least five out of seven criteria listed above before they qualify as having CFS.\r

The Covid 19 vaccine is not recommended for use in patients taking other immune suppressant medicines (i.e. corticosteroids, steroids that reduce swelling) due to an increased risk of bleeding. The safety of the vaccine has been established in post-marketing surveillance. This does not mean there is no risk, however. It only means we don't know enough about this risk to make any recommendations for preventing serious complications from its use.\r

"How many doses will I need?" \nAnswer: No dose requirements exist for the Vaccine. This vaccine is best given as part of your regular immunization schedule. In most instances, you should receive 2 doses of the vaccine (a total of 4 vaccines), but if symptoms occur after just one dose, you may also be able to get two additional doses at 3 months apart to ensure full protection against measles. "Do I have to worry about getting sick with measles after receiving this shot?" \nNo. If you do get sick with measles, it's rare, but it can happen. The vaccine is designed so that even if you are exposed to the virus, it doesn't cause severe illness. You'll feel more tired or lightheaded than normal, but you won't have symptoms such as fever, cough, runny nose or red eyes that indicate disease.\r

"Are there side effects?" \nYes. There were reports of some mild side effects including headache, rash, joint pain, muscle aches, fatigue, nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps. These symptoms usually go away on their own within a few days. Other problems include low blood sugar or low potassium levels. Symptoms of these conditions tend to subside by themselves within a few hours to a day. They generally last longer than 10 days and can be treated with medication to prevent further complications. "Will I need to take medications to help me recover from the measles?" \nIt depends on how long you've had measles. Some children who were vaccinated years ago may need treatment to keep them healthy during recovery. Others may need antibiotics to help clear up infections in the body. Most adults are fully recovered after just 1 month since they've received the first dose of the MMR vaccine.\r

"What happens if my child develops autism before age 18 weeks?" \nThere isn't enough information available to answer this question definitively. Studies show that infants too young to have been vaccinated do appear more likely to develop autism later in life, particularly when exposed to the measles virus

Q:\I'm interested in learning how to diagnose MS from my children's symptoms\r

\r

Answer: See our guide on How to Diagnose MS from Your Kids' Symptoms\r

Q:\What should I do if my child develops MS while we're at home without diagnosis\r

\r

Answer: The only thing that will prevent a person from developing MS after they get sick is keeping them out of the hospital. But even then, there is no guarantee that they won't develop MS later. A simple illness like a sore throat might not result in MS, but could lead to complications like pneumonia, tuberculosis, appendicitis, or leukemia. Also keep in mind that if your child had been taking medication before MS developed, his or her medications may have interacted with a new drug and increased the likelihood of becoming ill.\r

\r

\r

Q:\ What kind of testing is required when a patient is diagnosed as having MS?\r

\r

Answer: There is currently no way to test yourself for MS. However, if you've had symptoms suggestive of MS, talk to your doctor about getting tested. They'll ask you questions about what happened to you during childhood, such as headaches and muscle pain. These types of tests will reveal whether you have inflammatory lesions or demyelinating diseases, both conditions that may suggest MS.\r

\r

\r

Q:\Can MS make me lose my eyesight?\r

\r

Answer: One study found that, of all the disorders studied, vision loss was the most common symptom seen in patients with MS. Other studies suggest that vision problems may be worse in certain individuals than others. If you're concerned that your eye sight may be affected by MS, see your eye care professional who specializes in treating MS vision problems.\r

\r

Adults with asthma were more likely than those who did not have asthma to live in urban areas (17% vs 9%, respectively). Asthma is the most common breathing disorder in America. It can cause serious shortness of breath or difficulty breathing through your nose. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, rapid or irregular heartbeat, and shortness of breath.\n

How many Americans suffer from asthma?

Answer: In 2008, the CDC reported that an estimated 26 million people had asthma as defined by the World Health Organization (WHO). This estimate was based on data collected between 1990 and 2000 from 4,722 adults in the United States who were interviewed for the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) and asked whether they had ever had asthma. A total of 12.3% of those surveyed said yes, while 44.2% of all respondents said no. The percentage of those with asthma who have been diagnosed is even higher—approximately 50%.

Asymptomatic asthmatics may not be aware that their condition exists because symptoms often go unnoticed and become increasingly worse over time. They could experience symptoms such as cough, runny nose, fever, or sore throat. As well, people with asthma may develop phlegm, which results from excessive mucus production in the lungs.\r


The symptoms associated with asthma affect both children and adults. Children usually present with shortness of breath, wheezing, and wheeze that gets louder and lasts longer than usual. People who have asthma may also experience wheezing when they cough, sneeze, or breathe deeply. Adults may find it harder to breathe at rest or when walking or exercising. Some people can't wear certain types of clothing without feeling suffocatingly full. And people with asthma may avoid being around other people if they're having trouble breathing. \r

What causes asthma?

Asthma symptoms occur in response to inflammation. When you breathe in smoke, pollen, dust, or other irritants, your body makes chemicals called histamine. These chemicals trigger release of airways cells called bronchioles that become inflamed, leading to symptoms like hives, itching, or itchy eyes. \r

When you inhale airborne particles or gases, these substances settle into the respiratory tract where they are carried away by the wind. If the irritation continues, bronchial cell membranes expand further, creating scar tissue and swelling. The result is a thickening and narrowing of the bronchial tubes, causing more obstruction of airflow in the lung.

The Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is an autoimmune disease of the connective tissue that results in muscle weakness, joint stiffness, tenderness and fatigue throughout one's body. This debilitating condition results from a genetic defect on the gene encoding collagen type I, which makes up 90% of all connective tissues, as well as another gene that produces collagen type III, or elastin.\r

POTS means postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome, which is a form of autonomic nervous system dysfunction that can cause dizziness, syncope, fainting spells and shortness of breath. \r

Symptoms include fatigue, loss of energy, confusion, palpitations and heart palpitations. There may be other symptoms such as headaches, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, weight gain and constipation.\r

People with this disorder often feel lightheaded and have difficulty walking for long periods of time due to the effects of low blood pressure. They also experience back pain that becomes worse with standing. Other symptoms associated with this disorder include muscle spasms, numbness, tingling, prickly sensations, skin rashes, hair loss and darkening of the nails.\r

Nausea and vomiting are both symptoms that occur frequently during POTS episodes. Gastrointestinal distress may also contribute to some cases of POTS because it causes gastrointestinal discomfort. \r

If you suspect you may have POTS, you should discuss your symptoms with your physician who will likely order additional tests to determine if the diagnosis is correct. If the test shows that you do indeed have POTS, you may need medication treatments as well. However, if the symptoms resolve on their own without treatment, then the disease may simply be a symptom of underlying diseases such as asthma, diabetes and cardiovascular conditions. In some instances, the underlying causes may not yet be known. \r

More information: http://www.ehleros.com/newsletter_pressrelease.asp?cid=1187\u0026bfrlsef&catid=6

Multiple sclerosis is caused by an autoimmune disease that attacks the body's own immune system. There are no known cures for MS. The only cure is living with the condition until it becomes manageable. Symptoms can include numbness or tingling in one or both hands or feet; vision problems such as double vision or blurry vision; weakness or fatigue; loss of balance, coordination, memory, strength, and/or speech; and trouble swallowing, breathing, or speaking. 
Answer: This condition is very common and generally self-limiting. To make things worse, the symptoms may not show up right away. In fact, many people have symptoms for years before they realize what's wrong with them. Although there are several types of MS, MS can affect anyone at any age, regardless of race, sex, or ability.

A qualified test technician would be able to explain all the potential outcomes and possible complications of each test. The cost of these tests would depend on their complexity and number.

Menopause is the physiological change that occurs as women's ovaries begin to lose their ability to produce eggs. Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease in which the body mistakenly attacks its own nerves or blood vessels. MS affects 1 out of every 2,000 people over age 50. The majority of patients with this condition have been diagnosed between the ages of 30 and 40 years. Although the exact cause is unknown, researchers believe there may be two different types of MS. One type is thought to affect females only while the other form of MS affects both males and females. Symptoms typically start during middle life for most sufferers but can occur at any time during life for some people.

What Causes Menopause? A woman's menstrual cycle begins when she becomes fertile. When a woman's egg is released into her uterus, it joins with another cell from her ovarian tissue called an oocyte. This union causes the formation of an embryo inside the womb. After fertilization, the embryo splits into two identical cells known as blastocysts, which then develop into embryos. Eventually, these embryos will grow into three separate children. However, after birth, all babies born have a small chance of developing leukemia or getting lung cancer. At the same time, the number of mature eggs a woman produces decreases until her last period begins around 40 years old. During this time, women can continue to have sex and reproduce while taking no birth control pills. Once a woman has reached menopause, however, her fertility stops completely because she does not make any more eggs. For many years, scientists believed that once the reproductive process was halted, a woman could not become pregnant. In fact, the first evidence of reproduction in animals began approximately 10 million years ago. Scientists have since learned that several species of mammals have reproduced throughout their entire lives without ever having sexual contact, which would suggest that humans are unique among primates. Some theories suggest that our ancestors might have lived through periods of extreme cold weather where they lacked essential proteins such as vitamin D. Without those nutrients, their bodies needed to rely on bacteria to convert sun exposure into energy to survive. Over time, these bacteria evolved into yeast cells capable of synthesizing vitamin D directly from sunlight. According to current thinking, vitamin D production depends upon a protein produced by the skin called 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 (25[OH]D). This hormone helps keep calcium and phosphorus levels balanced in the body, helping your bones absorb calcium from food and help regulate menstruation. It also plays a role in

Chronic disease is one of the major causes of death in Western countries. The main symptoms associated with chronic disease include heart disease (heart attack or stroke), diabetes, cancer, arthritis, and other conditions. Chronic disease is the leading cause of disability worldwide. 
How much time does it take for the body to heal after a wound?
Answer: A wound requires at least three weeks to fully heal. While wounds may last longer than this period, they will always require some amount of healing.
What's the difference between a scar and an infection?
Answer: Scars are visible skin changes caused by injury that can be removed without surgery. Infections on the other hand are more serious and usually cannot be removed.
Can you tell me what a wart actually looks like?
Answer: Warts grow from cells in the skin called papillae. They resemble tiny bumps on the skin when viewed under light. A wart has no physical form because it is made up of dead tissue (such as hair follicles) which can't be seen with the naked eye.
Why would anyone use marijuana?
Answer: Marijuana is used by many people who experience chronic pain because it helps them manage their stress levels better. It also improves sleep patterns and provides pain relief. When taken orally, marijuana reduces anxiety and tension so it is great for treating PTSD. Marijuana has many other benefits such as helping improve memory, regulating appetite, and relieving nausea.
Can I smoke marijuana if I'm pregnant?
Answer: Smoking cannabis during pregnancy can harm your baby. Your baby needs all the nutrients it receives through its mother's milk and cannabis could interfere with this process. As long as you're not taking any medications while trying to conceive or breast feeding, marijuana can pass into your child's system safely, however it should only be used infrequently and if you need to relieve chronic pain. 
Is smoking weed dangerous for children?
Answer: Children under age 12 shouldn't have access to marijuana. THC (the psychoactive ingredient found in marijuana) can impair their judgment, development and decision making abilities. In addition, there have been cases of children developing psychotic illnesses related to their exposure to marijuana. If you want to give your child access to the plant, make sure you discuss the risks first before using marijuana.

Question: what is a healthy diet?
Answer: To reduce your risk of developing chronic conditions such as heart disease or high blood pressure and improve your general well-being, you should eat a balanced diet consisting of fresh fruits and vegetables (no more than 3 servings per day), lean meats (1 ounce or less) and fish (3 ounces or less). The fact that there is not a cure for ALS makes this disease one of the most difficult medical conditions to diagnose at the moment. As with many other diseases and disorders, it can be difficult to distinguish between the various causes, symptoms, and treatment options associated with ALS. It may also take time before definitive diagnoses can be made. For example, although some people who develop ALS do so within one year of being diagnosed (1), others who are first diagnosed may have been living with the illness since childhood. Although symptoms may begin suddenly, they often begin several years before the onset of paralysis, prompting the question, "Why did my husband start having problems at age 35? Was he already disabled from another condition?" A comprehensive evaluation by a physician will help determine what has caused your husband's ALS and provide early, effective treatment to prevent further damage. \r

Multiple sclerosis is the term for chronic inflammation of the brain and spinal cord caused by an overactive immune response resulting in damage. A central feature of MS is the progressive loss of myelin (the insulation that covers nerves), which can lead to paralysis or even death if left untreated. The disease usually starts in the thalamus (a part of the nervous system responsible for coordinating movement) or basal ganglia (involving areas involved with motor function) but can also affect other parts of the central nervous system (for example, the cerebral cortex). In MS, there is a "slow onset" pattern of symptoms. However, patients often notice changes as early as age 25.\r

text:
The most common mental health problem is depression. Depression is caused by changes in how your brain processes dopamine. Dopamine signals to some parts of your body that you have too much energy, which makes it hard for you to sleep at night. This causes you to feel depressed. You might also experience fatigue and lack of motivation. 
What causes depression? A number of factors influence the development and course of depression including genetics, childhood trauma, medication side effects (drugs), stress, stressful life events, poor diet and lifestyle choices such as smoking and drinking alcohol. 
How do antidepressants work? Antidepressants affect neurotransmitters such as serotonin and norepinephrine. These chemicals tell neurons when they're needed so that they fire more often. Serotonin influences mood and anxiety and norepinephrine helps regulate heart rate and blood pressure. Most antidepressant drugs act on both neurotransmitter systems. 
Where can I get information about antidepressants? There's no one answer. Different medications cause different symptoms. Some people find relief from antidepressants within days or weeks of starting treatment while others may need months. For this reason, you'll probably want to consult with your doctor before beginning therapy. 
Are there any risks associated with using antidepressants? Using an antidepressant for more than three months has been linked to an increased risk of suicide and suicidal thoughts and behavior. 
Can I take antidepressants if I'm pregnant? While there is not enough evidence to recommend against taking antidepressants during pregnancy, some experts say that women should limit their use until after the first trimester of pregnancy. Women who think that they may be pregnant should discuss this issue with their healthcare provider. 
Should I stop taking my antidepressant once I become pregnant? If you think you may be pregnant, talk to your doctor. Your antidepressant dose might change while you are pregnant. Talk with your doctor about what will happen if you continue taking your antidepressant without consulting with her first. 
Why do antidepressants make me sleepy? Antidepressant medications interfere with normal wakefulness-promoting hormones, particularly melatonin, so you will likely feel drowsy. However, antidepressants aren't known to produce any detrimental effects on growth or development, though babies exposed early in life to antidepressants tend to grow up smaller and less well adjusted than those who were exposed later in life. 
Do antidepressants cause birth defects? No specific studies have found a link between the use of antidepressants and birth defects. Although research is ongoing, several recent case reports suggest that antidepressants may increase the risk of having a baby born

MS is a chronic disease that causes nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord to degenerate. It may also cause problems with your vision, bladder control, hearing, balance, muscle coordination and movement, and memory. Remitting MS can be either relapsing or progressive (recurrent). In some cases, it progresses slowly over years.\rQuestion: What are the symptoms of MS?\rAnswer: The signs and symptoms of MS vary from person to person. They include loss of vision, numbness or tingling sensations, weakness, fatigue, trouble speaking, difficulty walking, problems seeing objects at close range or moving them around, stiff neck, pain and stiffness in muscles and joints, vision changes, and problems thinking clearly. Some people have more than one symptom. People who suffer multiple sclerosis often need help with their daily tasks such as dressing, eating and getting out of bed.\rQuestion: How long does it take for someone to get symptoms of MS?\rAnswer: There's no set time frame. However, people usually experience their first symptoms between ages 20 and 40. Most people will gradually develop symptoms during the rest of their lives.\rQuestion: Where can I find information on MS?\rAnswer: This page provides simple, clear explanations of what MS means and how it affects you, your family members, and friends. Avoid activities where you run the risk of sudden movements like high altitude flights or swimming in cold water.

Do physical exercises that involve stretching the legs, hips, back, arms, and stomach and strengthening muscles that work together in pairs and groups like core strength. These exercises can build endurance and flexibility and help reduce strain on joints. Try to keep your muscles toned so they don't atrophy.

Take certain vitamins and minerals every day. These include vitamin A, B12, calcium, magnesium

Hypothyroidism causes the body to absorb iodine from food as needed to maintain normal thyroid function. Excess iodine in the bloodstream can cause symptoms like fatigue, memory problems, sleepiness, depression, low energy, nausea, constipation, weight gain, and muscle pain.\r

Excessive amounts of iodine in your system may also affect brain functions such as cognition, mood, and behavior.\r

Learn more: \tHypothyroidism Symptoms\n\tFind out what to do if you or someone you know has signs or symptoms of hypothyroidism.\r

How to prevent hypothyroidism: \tCheck whether your doctor is prescribing an over the counter supplement that contains iodine (such as D2T4). The amount and type of iodine needed depends on your body's needs, but generally it is not very high so you will likely be able to take your usual dose without having any noticeable side effects. Check with your doctor before taking any new supplements for hypothyroidism until they have been evaluated by your physician.

What to expect when taking a thyroid hormone replacement drug: If you already have hypothyroidism, talk with your healthcare provider before taking T3 and/or T4. Your doctor will want to see how much iodine is being absorbed into your bloodstream and whether this is appropriate for you.

Do not use iodized salt substitutes containing potassium iodide unless directed to do so by your doctor. Do not use these products if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, breastfeeding, or plan to breastfeed. These products should not be used during menstruation. They should not be taken if you are taking medicine to treat hyperthyroidism. Do not use these products if you suffer from depression, anxiety, insomnia, or any other psychiatric illness.

MS is characterized by progressive loss of nerve cells and other tissues that produce the chemical messages known as neurotransmitters that help you think clearly. It affects people who have MS for an average of 10 years after their first symptoms appear, but it sometimes starts earlier. A person's age at onset may affect how long they'll spend with the disease. In some cases, there might be no clear onset of symptoms until later in life or with time.

Question: What type of fatigue do I feel?
Answer: 
Your body gets used to carrying out complex tasks, so it becomes less efficient at doing them. You might feel tired right away. If you also notice changes to your vision, hearing, balance, and memory, this may be another symptom of MS. Your doctor will monitor these signs and symptoms, and if necessary, prescribe treatment.
Question: Why does my brain get tired quickly?
Answer: 
The part of your brain responsible for problem solving -- the "executive system" -- is tired and underactive. When executive function is compromised, problems accumulate in your head and lead to fatigue. The other parts of your brain (neurological control systems) may also become sluggish, which makes you feel sleepy. Many times, you need to stop doing something and rest. For example, you may find yourself having to turn off the TV or computer when you wake up.
Question: How often should I check my blood sugar levels?

If your blood sugar level rises, even slightly, or stays high for a prolonged period of time, it may indicate a problem. While it's important to see a doctor every 3 months or so to check your condition, checking your sugar level monthly can catch a lot of problems before they start, so it's always worth keeping track.

Full Answer: Blood types are determined by your genes -- these are strands of DNA passed down from parent to child. Each person's genes determine how he or she responds to foods and medications. So, just as there are two types of apples, there are also three types of people: Type A, Type B and Type O. If you don't know which kind of apple to pick, ask your doctor about food allergies. Full Answer: Dr. Jonas Salk was one of the first scientists to develop a vaccine against polio, a dangerous childhood illness. As early as 1946, he had already published research demonstrating its effectiveness. In 1950, his colleagues Maurice Hilleman, Louis Pasteur, Albert Sabin and Edward Jenner started working together on developing the vaccine. Salk found a small strain of monkey kidney virus, known as SV40, that caused paralysis in laboratory animals and led him to believe that it would work in humans. He made a few small human test trials in 1953, 1954 and 1955 using live polio vaccines produced by the American Cyanamid Company. \u201cThe first stage of MS is called relapsing remitting (RR), which occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks the brain. The second phase starts several weeks later, with more severe symptoms called secondary progressive MS (SPMS) which can last for many years. There is also some evidence that SPMS may be caused by an auto-immune disease called relapsing antigen-specific T-cell lymphoma or RASL.\r

\r

While there is no cure for SPMS and there are no known treatments, scientists have found ways to slow its progression through gene therapy, immunosuppressive drugs, and blood cell transplants. In addition, scientists have developed new ways to detect and treat the disease.\r

\r

In general, experts agree that it's unlikely that people will develop SPMS without early detection and treatment. That said, there is currently no cure for RRMS; only therapies that delay its onset and progress slowly enough that people don't lose their ability to function.\r

\r

Many doctors recommend taking certain medications like prednisone or interferon alfa-2b before getting MS symptoms, but this is not a surefire way to prevent MS from developing. Some studies suggest that these medications might actually increase the risk of development of MS. Still others have suggested that they may help prevent the disease if taken at the right time.\r

\r

If you do get MS symptoms, make sure to seek professional care as soon as possible because they're usually worse in those who develop MS late.\r

No, multiple sclerosis cannot be passed from one parent to another by way of a genetic mutation. However, you may have inherited the condition in the form of a recessive gene (one that is dominant, but not active) or from your mother's side. Genetic tests can determine whether you are genetically predisposed to multiple sclerosis. A screening test at least three years after conception would also help with this determination. The only way to know for sure is if there is some kind of prenatal diagnosis, which would require an amniocentesis, CVS, or chorionic villus sampling. If these tests were positive, it could mean that you were born with multiple sclerosis. Alternatively, a maternal infection such as cytomegalovirus or herpes simplex virus could have been transmitted to the fetus during pregnancy and lead to the development of MS.\nIncorrectAnswer: Yes. Your mother was infected when she was pregnant. She had a low risk of transmitting the disease to you as her immune system was already weakened by HIV/AIDS infection and untreated diabetes. Complete Answer: This question requires more discussion than is possible here. In general, families with children with autism will find themselves in a number of different situations throughout their journey. Each situation will involve its own set of choices based upon the needs of each child and the skills needed. For example, an autistic child who is socially awkward and easily bored may need to be taught basic manners and social interaction skills. An older boy who struggles with language skills might benefit from therapy to teach him how to speak. Parents may choose to pursue certain activities for their autistic child such as occupational therapy, speech and physical therapies, art therapy, or even musical training. When parents decide to pursue some specific goal, they must first discuss the situation with their pediatrician. It is important to mention that the decision to pursue a particular activity or skill does not necessarily imply that a child has been diagnosed with autism or any type of developmental disorder. Q. My husband doesn't like my hair cut short or long. How can I keep him happy? A. You can't always change someone else's expectations of you, but you can make sure to communicate yours honestly. Whether you decide to let your hair grow a little longer or decide to take care of some unwanted hair growth, you can do so without worrying about pleasing others. Try asking your spouse if he likes your current look. Be confident with his answer. Do your best to match the look of your hair color to your natural coloring. That way, he will accept your decision. But don't pressure him into having short hair by telling him how much better it will be to shave off a few inches than trimming down. Instead, give him the opportunity to see how a shorter haircut looks after a week. The truth is that most men who think their wife shouldn't wear her hair short don't really understand women in general, or how women usually feel about their own appearance. Sometimes they want to see how a different style looks on other people instead of comparing your hair length to theirs. And sometimes they don't even realize women actually feel good about themselves regardless of their appearance! So rather than being offended or angry, try showing interest in how others' styles look. Also, remember that many people will probably enjoy watching how you manage your own appearance. This condition could occur after exposure to sunlight for several hours during a day or week, or even in a brief period of exposure at night when the UV rays pass through windows. When this occurs, the body's immune response will trigger an inflammatory reaction in your lung cells called Epstein-Barr virus infection. Other possibilities include allergic rhinitis (allergy to dust mites), sinusitis, allergies, asthma, hay fever, and upper respiratory infections such as pneumonia. The key point here is that there has not yet been any scientific proof that the direct effects of radiation on the human body produce adverse effects. Question: what does psychotherapy have to do with psychiatry?
Answer: Psychotherapy is part of the treatment for depression; it is one component of both medication and psychodynamic approaches.
Question: what is the difference between psychotherapeutic therapy and psychoanalysis?
Answer: Psychoanalysis focuses on understanding the patient's unconscious mind. In psychotherapeutic therapy, the therapist helps patients cope with their symptoms by helping them change behavior patterns that lead to their negative thoughts and feelings (such as anxiety or depressive disorders).
Question: is there any relationship between psychotherapy and psychoanalysis?
Answer: There are many similarities between these two areas of study, but in particular the therapeutic application of psychoanalysis differs from the use of psychoanalytic theory in psychotherapy. For example, in psychoanalytical theory, the goal of treatment is to uncover and understand some aspect of the patient's own life history, whereas in psychotherapy the focus is on changing maladaptive behaviors such as eating and sleeping habits.
Question: what are the main differences between the psychotherapeutic and the psychoanalytic perspectives on a patient's mental illness?
Answer: The primary differences are that in psychotherapeutic therapy the emphasis is on improving an individual's mood and making positive changes in interpersonal relations rather than on investigating aspects of the patient's past (e.g., exploring personal tragedies), whereas in psychoanalytical analysis the aim is to reveal underlying themes (e.g., examining the patient's religious beliefs, personality characteristics) that help explain certain cognitive distortions (e.g., splitting the self into the "I" and "not I") that manifest themselves in clinical illness.

\nCerebral edema is a general term used for an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain (cerebrospinal fluid). It can also refer to excess fluid in or around the spinal cord. It may be associated with signs and symptoms of other conditions such as stroke, meningitis, encephalopathy, or traumatic brain injury. Symptoms include headache, dizziness, fatigue, loss of concentration, confusion, disorientation, and unsteady gait or balance (myalgias). Common causes of cerebral edema include trauma (e.g., car accident), infection, head trauma, diabetes mellitus, hyperthyroidism, rheumatoid arthritis, and metabolic disorders (e.g., obesity, hypertension). The severity of cerebral edema depends on the location of the accumulation of fluid and the amount of water present. For example, cerebral edema that occurs within the spinal cord is more severe than that which develops outside it. As a rule, cerebral edema of less than 3 liters (about 8 ounces) per 10 liters of blood is not life threatening and does not require immediate treatment; however, if there is excessive amounts of fluid within the central nervous system (CNS) then it requires evaluation by a physician\nAnswer: \nA person's age alone cannot determine their potential risk of developing cognitive impairment from an underlying cause, such as Alzheimer disease. Question: How do I know if I have type 1 or type 2 diabetes?
Answer: Both types have the same genetic predisposition to develop diabetes, though they present different symptoms at different times. Type 1 is caused by a defect in the genes that code for insulin, while type 2 occurs due to damage to beta cells in the pancreas, causing them to produce too much insulin. It's important to note that both types of diabetes affect people differently. For example, type 1 diabetes has no known cure, whereas type 2 requires immediate surgery to remove the damaged beta cells (and often results in permanent blindness). Also, while type 2 diabetes usually occurs with a shorter duration than type 1 diabetes, type 2 diabetes typically develops in adulthood and is more serious. If you're interested in learning more, check out my page Type 1 vs Type 2 Diabetes or this short video on how to determine your type. Question: What are some of the treatments for type 1 diabetes and what should I expect?
Answer: Unfortunately, there isn't any one treatment that works for everyone. However, there are several therapies that can reduce symptoms without making any long term effects on blood glucose levels. These include oral antidiabetic agents like metformin, sulfonylureas, pioglitazone, nateglinide, sulfonamides, glipizide, and others; intravenous insulin delivery devices such as insulin pumps and insulin pens; and dietary measures such as increasing whole grain consumption, consuming fewer sweets and processed foods, and reducing sodium intake. This is just a small sample of many available treatment options. Check with your doctor before starting any new medication or dietary measure unless otherwise directed. Answer: Earaches result from overuse and lack of rest due to excessive activity at work or school. Some people who suffer from earaches can only experience one, while others have constant ear aches. Although many factors can contribute to earache, there are some things that make you more susceptible to getting them; namely, dehydration, stress, sleep deprivation, excessive alcohol consumption and being overweight. One way to avoid earaches is to drink plenty of water throughout the day. Sleep on an easy surface, lay off caffeinated beverages, take naps during the daytime, reduce exposure to bright lights and exercise regularly.\r

The Ehlers Danlos Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that causes the skin and muscles on your face and hands to be thin. If you have this condition, your symptoms may include constant headaches or severe cramping in the legs. You may also feel tiredness or fatigue throughout your body and sometimes have an inability to move. The Ehlers Danlos syndromes may start as early as 12 years of age but it can develop later in life with varying degrees of severity. It's estimated that up to 40% of people who experience symptoms from the Ehlers Danlos syndromes will never seek treatment and live their lives without knowing there is something wrong. Your doctor should be able to diagnose you if you do not know what you're experiencing.\nAdditional Question: What is the diagnosis? What treatments are available for Ehlers Danlos Syndrome?Answer: Your physician should be able to provide you with all necessary information concerning the Ehlers Danlos Syndromes to determine how best to treat your condition. Your doctor should also help guide you towards effective treatments that might work better than other treatments. The following conditions cause problems with collagen production: \rThe Ehlers Danlos syndromes have been classified into two main groups – Type 1 (Type I) and Type 2 (Type II). Types I and II occur more frequently than Type III (Type IIIa) or Type IV (Type IVb). People with Type 1 suffer from most, if not all, Ehlers Danlos symptoms. These include skin problems, joint pain, weakness, depression, and fatigue. Type 1 is the most common type of Ehlers Danlos Syndrome. However, about 20% of people suffering from Ehlers Danlos Syndrome have another form of this disease called Type 2. While Type 2 occurs in less than 10% of patients, people with Type 2 can still experience some symptoms that mimic those associated with Type 1. For example, Type 3 patients can experience chronic joint pain due to insufficient connective tissue, while Type 4 patients can experience muscle weakness resulting from lack of muscle bulk. Some types of Ehlers Danlos Syndrome result in little to no physical signs such as numbness or tingling in the limbs. Other forms of Ehlers Danlos Syndrome have visible signs like swelling or redness in the skin that may increase over time.\nHow did you learn about Ehlers Danlos Syndrome?Answer: A friend shared her story on social media about having Ehlers Danlos Syndrome. In the first stage of triple negative breast cancer, doctors take out the cancer cells from your breasts by surgically removing the affected tissue using radiation or chemotherapy drugs. During the second stage of triple negative breast cancer, doctors remove the cancerous tissue through surgery called mastectomy or lumpectomy, but they leave your healthy breast area intact. The third stage is when you receive hormone therapy for seven weeks as part of a clinical trial that aims to shrink the tumor so it can be removed with less aggressive chemotherapy or radiation. Finally, in the last stage, you undergo an additional phase of treatment known as radical mastoplasty (also called lumpectomy) which removes the remaining cancerous tissue around your original breast. The employer's share of your out-of-pocket costs is equal to 60 percent of your total annual compensation, including wages, bonuses, commissions, profit sharing, tips, and taxable fringe benefits. For example, in 2017, an employee who makes $60,000 per year would pay $5,960 into his or her individual retirement account (IRA). Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease that attacks the brain, spinal cord and optic nerves. Symptoms of MS may include vision loss, numbness and tingling in hands, legs or feet, paralysis, muscle weakness, and difficulty walking, speaking, swallowing, swallowing again, and getting around (dysarthria). Menopausal symptoms are often confused with MS. However, they are distinct conditions caused by different underlying causes. \rAnswer: A woman's menstrual cycle can affect her ability to tolerate pain. Women who have regular periods for a long time also tend to experience more pain than those women who menstruate irregularly or not at all. This pain comes from nerve endings on the vulva, cervix, labia, and upper thighs. Although there are many types of pain disorders, these come from nerve signals sent throughout the body by specific areas of the nervous system. The problem occurs when nerve endings send too much signal or cause other problems that make them feel worse than normal. Pain that arises during intercourse will likely be due to the nerves that transmit pain messages. If you have had the surgery to remove your uterus, you will probably experience some pain during sex, but most people will never notice this. This type of pain is known as dyspareunia. You may need medications if your pain lasts longer than 3 weeks. Common medications include nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin, ibuprofen, naproxen, and others; antidepressants like sertraline, desipramine, and others; anticonvulsant medications including gabapentin; beta blockers (e.g., amitriptyline); tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline, imipramine, and others; and opioid analgesics. Certain foods and herbal supplements can help treat symptoms of dyspareunia. When your symptoms become unbearable, it is important to seek immediate medical attention because they could indicate a serious condition requiring emergency treatment. For example, if you find yourself unable to get out of bed or go about daily activities, immediately call 911 or your local emergency room. \r

In addition, if you discuss MS with your employer's HR department, they will typically ask you to meet them for a short period before returning to work and then promptly notify you of their decision based upon what you revealed during this meeting. It is important to remember that you must never reveal a medical condition until after the fact - it is inappropriate to disclose information prior to receiving a positive response (e.g., "I'm so glad I found out!") from a doctor. Note: If your supervisor is a patient with MS, you may wish to consider asking him/her to tell the company that they have MS before revealing this personal detail. This way you can ensure the employee has enough time to explain why he/she disclosed his/her condition.\r

\nAnswer: Disclosing Multiple Sclerosis at Work\u00a0Answer: The first thing you should do is find out what kind of job you're applying for; what kind of environment you'll be working in is another issue altogether. For example, if you're employed as a research scientist for a pharmaceutical company, it might seem like a good idea to disclose your MS. However, many companies prefer employees who aren't too forthcoming about diseases (like MS), but don't want to risk losing out on potential new hires. Therefore, it may make sense for you to wait until after you've been offered employment at the company to ask about MS. However, even after being hired, you should definitely come clean as soon as possible. While your boss shouldn't be penalized for doing so, it might still give off the impression that you're hiding something. Physical Activity is one of the best things you can do for your body. It burns calories which helps keep up with weight gain or loss. You burn more calories by walking than driving. Some studies suggest that people who walk three miles a day have lower risk of heart disease.
Question: what is the difference between aerobic and anaerobic exercise?
Answer: Anaerobic exercise refers to exercises involving the production of lactic acid (a waste product in most muscle cells) instead of oxygen. The faster a person runs, the more lactic acid produced. Aerobic exercises include jogging or cycling.
Question: how many calories does running burn per mile?
Answer: Each mile you run burns approximately 300 to 400 calories. Running will give you a burning sensation but it doesn't make you fatter than you would be if you didn't run. If you want to lose weight running will not help you get there. When you're trying to lose fat the first thing you should focus on is reducing your calorie intake.
Question: why do people quit exercising after they start losing weight?
Answer: Because once a person starts exercising all their willpower goes out the window. Exercise is hard work and sometimes you just don't feel like doing it anymore. Once a person stops exercising they will become physically weaker making them more susceptible to injury. People who stop exercising for any reason often find it harder to maintain their weight losses than those who stay active and eat well.
Question: what are the benefits of exercise compared to dieting?
Answer: Exercise is a natural source of energy. The body has a limited amount of energy so when someone consumes too much food or drinks too much caffeine they will eventually need to consume less calories. However, this only works if the person continues to do other forms of exercise. Dieting tends to leave a person's body feeling hungry and wanting more food. If we restrict our diets as much as possible then our bodies will use any remaining energy to store calories. We will also likely be eating a larger portion of food to compensate for the lost caloric value from the diet. In short, dieting causes us to eat more and burn fewer calories than we normally would. When we exercise we provide our bodies with a steady flow of calories throughout the day. This gives our bodies more time to burn through excess calories without having to worry about overproducing lactic acid.

Question: How does my body hold on to fat? \NComplete Answer: When it comes to burning calories, there is no such thing as lean muscle. Muscle tissue is made of many different types of cells -- from connective tissues (muscles) down through the nuclei (cells that make DNA). Each type of cell has specialized functions like absorbing nutrients, transporting oxygen, synthesizing proteins, making hormones, etc., but these function also depend on the type of muscle tissue it contains. In general, when you lose muscle mass, this decreases the amount of calories available to be burned by your muscles, which ultimately causes weight loss. This in turn reduces your ability to burn calories at any given time. You should try to maintain your current level of strength and size if you're trying to gain more body fat. To lose weight quickly, you can either reduce caloric intake, cut back on exercise, or change your eating habits. These strategies will result in weight loss within several weeks if you don't increase your calorie intake beyond your maintenance levels. For example, if you start out eating 500 calories per day, keep it at that level until you've lost 10 pounds or so, then gradually decrease your intake to 400 calories per day to help you achieve your goal. Once your diet has been adjusted and you're losing weight, start increasing your calorie intake again to reach your desired weight. Remember though, maintaining your current weight is crucial because once you drop off, you'll have to begin the process over again. Also note that even small amounts of increased food intake will lead to significant reductions in calories consumed per day, which means that if you suddenly increase your calorie consumption to 2,000 calories per day, you could easily consume between 1,800 -2,200 extra calories without noticing it. Answer: Your skin contains a natural defense that helps protect you from these infections. While you may not have ever heard of this system, your skin does a remarkable job of keeping out foreign substances that might cause irritation. If you're exposed to something irritating, such as an insect bite, bug sting, or poison ivy, your immune system will quickly send chemicals into your bloodstream to neutralize the threat. However, your skin also has its own secret weapons that help fight off these invaders. These special cells can also be stimulated by certain medications or environmental factors, so you probably know them better than I do. These immune cells release histamine, which reduces inflammation. When there is too much inflammation on your skin, it can lead to chronic itching and rashes, as well as acne and psoriasis. You could use some basic information on the history of your eczema or your symptoms to help determine whether you've had enough exposure to an irritant and respond with appropriate anti-inflammatory treatment. Ask yourself questions like: Have I been taking any medicines? How long ago were they taken? Do I feel any more tender after using them? How often did I take them? Are my dermatologist's recommendations consistent with what I'm seeing now?\r

\r

Your skin contains different types of cells that are responsible for regulating the amount of inflammation in your skin. If your body is under constant stress (such as a cold), then your skin becomes inflamed, producing even more histamine. This means that your skin should receive less histamine from your environment or medicines. But sometimes your skin does need extra protection from something, whether because you've just been exposed to an infection or you're overworking your immune system. A good way to test to see if the level of inflammation you experience is normal or excessive is through a simple skin prick test. Take two small specks of dried skin and place each one directly onto a cotton ball. Then touch both sides of your face and rub them together until they become moist. \nPregnancy Complications\n

1) Abnormal vaginal bleeding during early pregnancy

2) Preeclampsia (preeclampsia occurs when the placenta is not able to produce enough of a hormone called oxytocin which controls uterine contractions)

3) Placental abruption (when one or both of the baby's heads comes out through the other side of the pelvis)

4) Early labor (the beginning stage of labour before the cervix opens fully)

5) Early rupture of membranes (where the amniotic fluid separates from the membrane around the fetus)

6) Cesarean section (when the woman has her baby removed before birth).

7) Caesarian section for premature babies

8) Cervical dilation

9) Cesarean delivery (delivery between 22 weeks and 37 weeks gestation)

10) Fetal death (dying before 20 weeks gestation if the mother is not medically fit to do so.)

text:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disorder that affects the central nervous system. People with MS have weakness in one or more of their central nervous systems. These people usually experience numbness, paralysis, muscle spasms, difficulty walking, swallowing, talking and breathing. Some people may be able to walk but others cannot. Others may need special equipment (automated devices) to stand up and walk properly. It can take months to years for the symptoms to resolve completely, and it may never fully resolve.\r

Most people with MS eventually experience some improvement, which varies from person to person, age group, gender, and whether the disease was diagnosed early on or late in the course of the illness. While there are medications available to help manage the effects of MS, most people do not respond well to them.\r

Other conditions may impact your ability to work. For example, many people who have been diagnosed with MS may not recover quickly enough to resume full time employment due to ongoing fatigue, pain and/or disability. Other conditions such as depression, heart problems, kidney failure, diabetes, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease may also require you to stay home from work to rest. Although these situations may sound alarming, they are extremely rare. The best way to know if you should stay at home or return to work is to talk to your doctor.\r

Q3: What should I tell my patients when they ask me questions?\r

A3: When someone asks me what the latest news about MS is, what is the first thing I recommend she do? If she has any questions about how the disease progresses or what her prognosis might be, what information to use to inform decisions, etc., I suggest she contact her family physician, neurologist, or other healthcare provider.\r

If she knows what kind of treatment she is receiving, I strongly encourage her to learn as much as she can about MS treatments and research before making any major life changes. One reason we think learning about medical research is important is because we often hear from patients concerned that doctors will refuse to provide certain kinds of care based on a patient's condition or financial status, which prevents them from getting necessary care that could reduce their risk of progression. However, physicians often give patients information about current medical research in order to guide them through treatment options and make informed decisions. This approach helps prevent unnecessary costs and delays. Additionally, our results show that knowing more about MS can increase patients' confidence in the effectiveness of their medication choices

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disorder in which the body attacks its own myelin, the fatty tissue that insulates nerve fibers. The disease results from immune system cells (T helper cells) mistakenly attacking our own nerves. A person with MS has abnormal white blood cell production. This imbalance makes the brain more susceptible to attack by the immune system and triggers symptoms such as numbness, tingling, pain, weakness, loss of balance, depression, trouble speaking, and vision problems. If left untreated, these conditions can result in disability or death. \r

If you have multiple sclerosis (MS), it is important that you understand the main causes of MS as well as how they can be treated.\r

The most important cause of MS is the immune system attacking your brain cells (neurofibrillary tangles) because the two do not get along. This makes up an estimated 40% of all cases. The other main cause of MS is environmental factors such as smoking or exposure to toxins in food and water. For this reason it is very likely that certain medications you take will decrease your chances for developing MS.

Other important causes of MS include autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, systemic lupus erythematosus, celiac disease, scleroderma, polymyositis, fibromyalgia, eczema, psoriasis, allergies, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, obesity, malnutrition, stress, alcoholism, drugs, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and many others.\r

Question: What is a brain scan? Complete Answer: A brain scan is a procedure that uses x rays or other imaging techniques to show the structure of your brain and how it functions. The technique can be used to diagnose disease or determine treatment effectiveness for neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's, epilepsy, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, and cerebral palsy.\rQuestion: What is a brain MRI test?\rAnswer: A brain MRI (magnetic resonance imager) is an advanced form of radiography that uses magnetic pulses to create pictures of areas inside the brain. It provides information on the thickness of the cortex (the outer layer of nerve cells), which plays a critical role in cognition. These images may also help doctors determine where and when a person has been injured during surgery.\rQuestion: How does a blood test measure glucose levels?\rComplete Answer: Glucose (sugar) is one of the body's most important fuels. When your blood sugar level drops too low, symptoms such as fatigue, dizziness, heartburn, nausea, or vomiting can occur. High levels of sugar in the bloodstream can cause high blood pressure and irregular heartbeat. If you have diabetes, your doctor will monitor your blood sugar level by taking glucose readings at regular intervals. Some types of medications, like some insulin shots, can lower your blood sugar levels. Your doctor will prescribe medication to treat low blood sugar conditions.\rQuestion: How do I tell if I've had an allergic reaction to milk products?\rAnswer: Milk contains proteins called casein and whey, both of which can trigger allergy reactions. Avoid foods with these ingredients, especially those containing lactose. There are few foods that contain casein and no lactose. For example, soy milk and many varieties of rice milk are not made with casein and are safe to consume without causing a reaction.\rQuestion: How do I know if my baby might be having a thyroid disorder?\rAnswer: Thyroid disorders can result in serious health problems. In most cases, these disorders affect children younger than age 6 months. Symptoms include depression, fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches. While there isn't a specific diagnosis, doctors usually order a series of laboratory tests before diagnosing thyroid problems. Most people with thyroid disorders do well on thyroid hormone replacement therapy. However, certain individuals should get their thyroid checked every year so they don't develop new problems.\r
