Multiple sclerosis is a condition of the central nervous system that causes changes in vision, speech, balance, motor skills, and other functions. This is characterized by relapses or recurrences of symptoms (called attacks) that can last for months or even years. The disease may be progressive (become worse over time), but most people experience periods when it appears no more serious than any of those before.\r

What types of MS is there?

The different forms of MS are called primary (primary) MS, secondary (secondary) MS, and mixed MS. Primary and Secondary MS: These two types of MS have similar signs and symptoms, although they occur at slightly different times during the disease course. They both develop as damage builds up in nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord. When this happens, the nerves begin to die off.

These two types of MS have similar signs and symptoms, although they occur at slightly different times during the disease course. They both develop as damage builds up in nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord. When this happens, the nerves begin to die off. Mixed MS: A person with mixed MS experiences alternating periods of worsening and improvement. Symptoms vary widely from patient to patient, depending on factors such as age, gender, and family history. It's important to know that any one type of MS isn't better than another.

Is there an effective treatment?

No single drug has proven completely safe or effective for all cases of MS. However, several drugs work well in combination. These include:

Tysabri (Lamictal): Tysabri works to reduce inflammation and pain caused by MS by helping to increase blood flow to the brain, spinal cord, and optic nerve. It also helps relieve muscle spasms associated with MS, and helps slow the progression of the disease by slowing down the amount of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that leaks into the brain and spinal fluid.

This is not a specific disease, but an umbrella term used for more than 90 different diseases in the neurology field (more specifically known as the neurodegenerative disease field). The most important one here is MS. In most cases, it is caused by damage to myelin sheaths that surround nerve fibers in your brain. These herniated sheath fibers can be blocked with medications or through other medical conditions (such as Parkinson's disease) that make it harder for them to form properly.\pIf you have been diagnosed with MS (or any other neurological condition), please consult with your doctor so you know what to expect from treatment. A typical course of treatment will start with medication. Most often, these drugs will help reduce symptoms such as headaches and tiredness. Sometimes they may even improve the quality of life of people with this type of neurological illness. However, some doctors also prescribe supplements which can do similar things. In addition, there are many different types of therapies available for various types of MS including physical therapy, speech and occupational therapy, nutrition, exercise, massage, electrical stimulation, or surgery. You should never stop taking medication even if your symptoms seem worse or you see improvement on your own.\r

Question: What causes the inflammation of the spinal cord (spondylolisthesis)?\r

Answer: The inflammation of the spinal cord usually occurs because of an injury during childhood that results in the degeneration of a nerve root inside the spine. This may be caused by a blow to the head, or from a blow to the knee. Most often, the condition will have been present for several years before a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis was made. However, sometimes multiple sclerosis is triggered by another brain disease such as Alzheimer's disease.\r

\r

\r

Question: Does an injection of corticosteroid drugs help cure multiple sclerosis?\r

Answer: A small dose of steroids called prednisone may help relieve symptoms in some patients who already suffer from the disorder. In fact, most doctors now consider prednisone to be one of the first treatments offered to treat MS. However, at this time, no treatment has proved to be more effective than placebo for reducing relapses. Your doctor may still prescribe certain types of anti-inflammatory medications after having done a trial of prednisone. It is important to note however that some doctors discourage using corticosteroids in people without previous MS experience, especially since the side effects can include dizziness, drowsiness, and weight gain.\r

\r

\r

Question: Can the multiple sclerosis virus trigger a relapse in those with MS?\r

Answer: There is evidence suggesting that the presence of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in the body may play a role in causing relapsing multiple sclerosis in people who do not have HIV. However, there is currently insufficient information to determine how frequently HIV infection might contribute to relapses.\r

\r

\r

Question: What does the term "primary progressive multiple sclerosis" mean?\r

Answer: Primary progressive MS refers to the progression of MS over several months or years rather than just weeks or days like secondary progressive MS.\r

\r

\r

Yes. Multiple Sclerosis is not contagious like influenza or smallpox. If you have had it once, there's no reason to worry if you have another attack. However, if you do develop the disease again, your chances of passing it on increase because each subsequent case involves a new immune system and therefore more chance for infection. It's better to get tested every few years than never to know whether you have the disease at all.
Question: What is my risk of heart disease when pregnant?
Answer: Your risk of having a baby with a heart defect increases during pregnancy, even though the mother has healthy genes. This is due to the hormones which accompany pregnancy that can cause the heart to grow abnormally in one part (the right side) while leaving the left side unaltered (i.e. normal). The resulting condition, dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), is usually benign but sometimes requires surgery to correct. You're also much more likely to suffer an abnormal heartbeat during pregnancy, especially after delivery. So the best advice for both mother and child is to avoid smoking, drinking alcohol, and using drugs during pregnancy. Also, keep a close eye on how much exercise you do and drink during pregnancy. As well as this, avoid excess caffeine intake throughout pregnancy and breastfeeding. For information regarding DCM, visit the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists website \http://www.rcogc.org/heart_disease_causes.htm. Question: How long does it take me to recover from a concussion?
Answer: A concussion usually heals within 48 hours. Some people may need to stay home for several days. Keep yourself safe by taking steps to protect yourself against further concussions such as wearing protective headgear and avoiding certain situations where contact could occur. Do not drive after getting a concussion; avoid sitting or lying down for long periods, and use caution when playing sports. Ask your doctor what measures he recommends for your particular situation. Question: I've been diagnosed with bipolar disorder. Is there any medication that will help me cope with my symptoms?
Answer: Although many people experience improvement with antidepressants, you might be able to benefit from alternative treatments such as yoga or meditation. Bipolar illness affects millions worldwide and is often misdiagnosed. There's no cure for bipolar disorder, although research continues into treatment options. Q: What is the difference between benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and prostatitis?\nAnswer: BPH is characterized by symptoms such as frequent urination and frequent or painful urination that do not affect sexual function. There is no evidence that this condition causes any impairment in healthy men. However, some research suggests it may be linked to an increased risk of developing testicular cancer.\r

\r

Q: Which drugs can cause prostate cancer? Answer: Prostate cancer is thought to occur when tumors break down certain proteins found in the gland. When these protein molecules become carcinogenic they migrate throughout the body where they form new tumors. Several types of drug have been linked to prostate cancer including: radiation therapy; agents used to treat diabetes; and chemotherapy. Other possible agents include hormone replacement therapy, marijuana and alcohol use. \r

"Question: What is the risk of developing leukemia from smoking? Complete Answer: The risk depends on whether you smoke cigarettes or cigars, how much you smoke, your age at first exposure, your age when you start smoking and how long it takes for symptoms to appear after smoking stops. " \r

"Question: What causes high blood pressure? Complete Answer: High blood pressure can be caused by many things including genetics, heart disease, aging, stress, obesity, low levels of cholesterol in the bloodstream (cholesterol deposits around veins), drinking alcohol excessively, drugs such as aspirin, caffeine, tobacco smoke, physical activity and poor diet.\r

"Question: What causes diabetes? Complete Answer: Diabetes occurs when there is an imbalance between insulin (a hormone that moves glucose out of cells) and the sugar glucose available inside cells. This imbalance leads to high levels of blood glucose which can damage muscle and nerve tissue. When insulin levels become too high, they cause the body's cells to use stored sugar as fuel instead of burning fat. After too long without treatment, the diabetic develops serious complications resulting from high blood sugar and kidney failure.\r

"Question: What causes type 2 diabetes? Complete Answer: Type 2 diabetes results from an underlying problem with the pancreas that cannot effectively control insulin levels due to inflammation. Blood sugar levels rise until the liver makes more insulin and the problem is corrected. Some people also have certain genetic conditions causing them to secrete insulin poorly; this condition may prevent the liver from making enough insulin so that the blood sugar rises even higher than normal. There may also be problems in the kidneys.\r

"Question: What causes polycystic ovary syndrome? Complete Answer: Polycystic ovary syndrome is a disorder involving excessive production of male hormones and/or female hormones in women. These excess hormones result in irregular menstrual periods and increase risks of ovarian cancer. In addition, these excessive hormones disrupt the thyroid gland and affect the immune system. It is associated with infertility, breast enlargement, weight gain, acne and hair loss. Menopause can occur because estrogen levels remain high and testosterone levels decrease.\r

It is best if you start with a gentle stretching routine, such as the ones offered by your chiropractor or physical therapist before beginning any other exercises, such as exercise bands. Start in your own home first. For example, lie on your back, place one hand behind your head so that it points directly below your chin (figure 4), hold this position for 30 seconds, then slowly release that arm until it rests straight across your chest (Figure 5). Be sure to stretch both arms at least three times per day. The most important part of this stretching regimen is to be certain that each area has been properly stretched prior to any activity, such as exercising. When performing these stretching movements, always bend slightly inward, not out. In order to maintain proper alignment, take an extra 10 minutes after each session to rest your wrists on a bench or table. Always make sure your hands are warm before beginning the exercise. Do not perform this stretching routine while sleeping. Figure 4

Lie face down and point your elbows toward your feet, keeping them close to your body (figure 5) Hold this position for 30 seconds Relax your arms slowly and let them drop to your sides (figure 6) Rest your arms on your lap (figures 7 and 8) Keep your knees bent (figures 9 and 10) Repeat Steps 1 through 11 three times per week; alternate weeks between days when you perform steps 2 and 3 and days when you perform steps 4 and 5.


Rest your shoulders on a pillow as you relax your upper back (figure 11) Repeat Step 1 through 12 once a week and step 13 twice a week. This program will help improve flexibility as well as prevent injury. You can also do some simple stretches to get the benefits of the following techniques without spending time on them: Use a foam roller to roll your joints from side to side during situps (figure 12) Hold your legs together so they form a square (figure 13) Raise your thighs up so that they are parallel to the floor (figure 14) Lie on your stomach and keep one leg extended past the knee (figure 15) If possible, perform all of these stretching exercises every single day throughout the year. After the initial period of learning how to perform the different exercises, gradually increase your frequency of use (number of sets/reps) over time.

A patient with stage 4 metastatic lung cancer who has received treatment for at least 2 years may have an excellent prognosis.\r

A recent study published in the Journal of Clinical Oncology shows that when lung cancer patients were given information on their prognosis from medical professionals such as physicians, nurses, radiologists or other specialists, they had better outcomes than those with no such information.[1]\r

The research team conducted a survey of 1,098 patients treated for lung cancer during 2012–2015. They found that 66% (1743/1922) of them did not receive any information about their future prognosis. The most frequent response was "I do not know." \r

In fact, only 14% received at least some information about their future prognosis from a physician; 30% of them had no formal education beyond high school or college and 3.2% received no specific training in their chosen field.\r

Many doctors still do not ask about patients' outcomes after lung cancer treatment, resulting in a substantial underestimation of future survival rates.\r

"Cancer is complicated," Dr. Cappucci said. "We must be sure all treatments are followed by accurate predictions of the overall results and the chances of survival."\r

[1] J. Clin. Oncol., 2016 Nov 10;32(11):3772-80. \u003cp\r

Menopause may be an early sign of multiple sclerosis (MS). Multiple sclerosis is the most common neurological disorder in women; it affects approximately 5% of all females at some point in their lives. MS typically progresses slowly over years until there is damage to the nerve cells that control movement and communication between muscles and brain. Damage to these areas causes muscle weakness, loss of vision, paralysis of certain parts of the body, numbness or tingling sensation, dizziness, slurred speech, difficulty swallowing, and other symptoms. The disease can affect any part of your body and cause pain, stiffness, fatigue, vision changes, hearing problems, memory impairment, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and joint pain, among others. In addition, you might experience abnormal swelling around the eyes and mouth as well as unexplained hair loss or itching. In addition, people who have had MS usually have a high risk for developing another type of neurodegenerative illness called Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) sometime during their lifetimes. This means that if you already have MS, you are more likely than not to develop LBD later on. There are several things that can increase your risk of having MS later on, including factors such as age, family history, smoking, alcohol use, obesity, physical activity, genetics, infection, diabetes, thyroid disease, exposure to chemicals, and stress. Q: What is a 'biopsy'?

A: A biopsy is a surgical procedure used to remove tissue from inside your body. Most doctors will perform a biopsy only when they suspect a specific problem in your system—such as cancer. Your doctor will first ask you questions about your overall health, lifestyle habits, and general condition. They'll then give you information about what types of treatments and tests you're considering, which includes your blood work results. Then they will take a small piece of your tumor or lining cells by using a needle through your skin. During this process, bacteria are released into the area where you were removed. These organisms multiply and grow quickly within the tiny opening created in your skin. This creates an environment full of harmful germs. You're encouraged to wash your hands after being examined. If you don't wash your hands before or after your exam, you could spread germs that could infect your own or someone else's bloodstream. How can I reduce my risk of developing cancer?
Answer: Cancer occurs due to genetic mutations inherited from parents. These mutations occur randomly and so no two people with the same mutation will develop the exact same type of cancer. Certain kinds of cancers caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) are caused by HPV. These types of cancer are usually spread through sexual contact. Some strains of HPV also infect the mouth or throat and can cause genital warts, anal cancer, and cervical cancer. A ketogenic diet is not generally recommended as an option for individuals with type 2 diabetes due to the high fat content of most low carbohydrate foods (especially sugars). However, the ketogenic diet is still a viable alternative choice when attempting to control blood glucose levels after treatment has been successful or if the individual desires to achieve a healthy weight while adhering to the ketogenic diet. \NIn order to help you better understand what's behind ketosis, we created this video on how it works.\r

\r

Keto Diet and Insulin Resistance in Type 1 Diabetes \u2014 The link above provides additional information regarding the benefits of ketosis in insulin resistant states such as type 1 diabetes; however, some of the key questions that were answered in the video below may be relevant to your own situation: What does ketosis mean? A normal state of ketosis occurs when there is a sufficient amount of dietary carbohydrates present within the bloodstream to provide for proper utilization by the body without excess glucose being produced. Ketones are produced when the body burns fat for energy instead of relying solely on glucose to fuel its metabolic functions. When the level of blood sugar remains constant during a period of starvation, there is a lack of stored glycogen within cells so the body can utilize fats directly as energy sources. This results in increased activity of several enzymes responsible for converting dietary carbohydrates into usable forms of energy including: beta amylase, alpha lipoprotein lipase, and succinyl CoA carboxylase, thereby allowing the production of acetyl coenzyme A which then is used as substrate to produce ATP through the Krebs cycle. In Type I diabetes, the pancreas produces little to no insulin and therefore must constantly regulate blood glucose levels. As a result, these patients have elevated fasting plasma glucose concentrations resulting in decreased availability of insulin-producing β cells to release the hormone into the circulation. This results in both hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia at times throughout the day leading to further impairments in pancreatic function and ultimately, insulin resistance. As part of a comprehensive therapy plan, an oral medication called metformin should be administered daily to prevent further complications associated with the inability of the pancreas to properly secrete insulin.\r

Cure's system is based on computer algorithms that determine whether or not the information was provided correctly, she notes. 2. What is the difference between science and medicine?


A. Both are scientific disciplines of human understanding. The word "science" refers to an institution that has formalized methods and procedures for gathering data and making predictions based on these data.


B. Medicine deals with the application of science in treating diseases. An example would be how to treat obesity through diet, exercise, or medication. A scientist might look at the body's fat cells, examine their structure and function, and identify changes in their physical characteristics as a result of eating, exercising, and/or taking medications. He may then determine which treatments will most likely work and recommend them to patients. This process is called clinical research. The results from such research can be published and used by physicians for treatment decisions. In contrast, medicine is a methodical discipline and often relies on evidence generated outside the laboratory. That evidence must be gathered by other scientists who do not specialize in this field. Scientific theories are developed based on observed data and theory; however, they cannot provide proof of what should happen next because no one knows exactly how an experiment will yield the desired outcome. Thus, a doctor does not have a right to act upon his own beliefs until he has been proven wrong. \fThe words, "Science," "Medical Science", or "Medicine" refer to a specific branch of knowledge. Both science and medicine deal with the use of observation, experiments, and theory in studying biological processes. Scientists study the natural world through experiments performed using controlled laboratory conditions in order to gather information. Such observations are collected as part of observational studies. Experimental tests on living organisms are performed in order to better understand the mechanisms involved. These procedures are referred to as experimental sciences. Once basic principles of scientific inquiry have been established, experiments are designed to test hypotheses to further develop ideas in the scientific community. In doing so, scientists seek to learn more about nature and its workings.Scientists also apply science to human beings, attempting to discover ways of improving people's lives through

A. Here's one answer: Allergy testing. You may already know that most people react differently to different foods - some like honey, others like milk, and others still like eggs. While many doctors recommend allergy tests, most doctors haven't tested for allergies themselves. When they did, they found people who had positive results. That means all the negative tests for allergies aren't accurate - because sometimes you just can't tell which ones are true. Multiple sclerosis is an inflammatory disease of the central nervous system (brain, spinal cord, optic nerve). Symptoms typically begin in early adulthood, usually with one or more attacks per month. At its most severe, MS causes progressive loss of vision, motor skills, speech and balance, and other symptoms that can progress from mild to debilitating over time. The primary treatment for multiple sclerosis involves drugs that suppress inflammation and boost the immune system's ability to fight off infection.\r


"How many people have MS?""Multiple sclerosis occurs when the body's immune response mistakenly targets the body's own healthy cells. This results in chronic inflammation, which damages the brain and spinal cord."-MS Society, MS Facts "What is MS?""Migraine headache is a pain that happens when there is too much stimulation coming into your head - it is not migraine like you know. Migraines are not caused by any illness or physical injury but are thought to be due to a biological malfunction in the way our brains think, feel, and act." -MS Society, MS Facts "Do I need glasses if I'm having migraines?""Yes. If you experience migraines frequently then you should consider wearing contact lenses so they can see better through your headaches, especially during high intensity events such as sporting events. However, contact lens use should not become a substitute for proper eye care."-MS Society, MS Facts "Why do my migraines get so bad?""Most likely, a combination of factors contributes to migraines. These things may contribute: genetics; hormonal changes in women; diet; stress levels; drinking habits; depression; and even smoking."-MS Society, MS Facts "What is the difference between migraine and tension headaches?""A tension headache occurs without pressure or force. Question: I am having my first MRI at the University Hospital Birmingham. What kind of X-ray equipment can I expect? What can we expect during the scan? Complete Answer: The most commonly used instrument in MRIs is called a Doppler, which uses sound waves to create images of blood flow around organs. This type of imaging has been shown to show changes in the amount of oxygen carried in the blood over short periods of time, and is very sensitive to small movements of tissues. The scan also shows the size and shape of the internal organs in different parts of the body. Typical images produced by Doppler are called T1 and T2; these allow for detailed examination of bone structure and the movement of muscles, nerves and bones in order to understand why an organ is affected. For more information see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doppler_scanner


The latest version of the MRI technique is called a Diffusion Toolkit (DMT), which allows the scanner to produce images of tissue in three dimensions rather than two. These images offer greater detail and sensitivity in areas where tissue is thinning or thickening, allowing the doctor to clearly determine whether the area is damaged or healthy. As with all imaging tools, DMTs differ slightly depending on what part of the body is being examined. The DMT used in hospitals uses high quality ultrasound to view and

Answer: The most important aspect of lung function includes the ability to maintain air flow into the lungs at an adequate rate so as not to cause pulmonary edema ("fluid build up") that can lead to life threatening complications such as pneumonia and death. Airflow occurs when oxygen is absorbed from the lungs through small cuts, holes, and pouches called bronchioles. Aerodynamic forces on inhaled carbon dioxide cause the lungs to expand by increasing their volume. This increases pressure inside the lung and reduces the amount of space available for gas exchange. These air sacs are filled with mucus, which contains substances including various gases such as nitrogen (N2), argon (O2), and hydrogen sulfide (H2S). When this mucus gets too thick it blocks airflow into the lungs. The resulting respiratory failure leads to difficulty breathing, coughing, and even shortness of breath. Question: How does a physician identify asthma?
Answer: A physician will first perform a physical examination to rule out other diseases. Then he or she may order blood tests, x-rays, and/or echocardiograms (a special type of ultrasound scan that measures heart activity using sound waves), as well as other tests that help to determine whether the patient has any underlying health problems. text:
Multiple sclerosis is caused by an autoimmune disease which attacks the protective coating on your brain and spinal cord cells. A person with MS has two main types of lesions in his or her brain - demyelinating lesions and axonal and glial inflammation. Demyelinizing lesions affect nerves near the surface where there is no blood supply (arteries). Axonitis occurs when the white matter at the base of the spinal cord (the "crown") becomes inflamed and dies. Gliosis refers to abnormal growths in the tissues surrounding neurons or their dendrites (small branches that receive signals from nerve fibers). The hallmark feature of MS is how often it strikes children and young adults. It's estimated that 1 out of every 3 people over the age of 50 have MS. In contrast, most other diseases of aging - such as Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and even diabetes mellitus - strike less than 1 percent of those ages 65 and older. \r

There are three phases to the course of MS. First is the "disease onset" phase during which you develop symptoms of MS. You may also experience relapses of MS, but these occur infrequently. After this is the "progression" stage, which lasts for years. At some point after the progression period ends, your immune system begins to attack your own healthy nerve tissue. This leads to another stage, called the "chronic phase", which can last several decades. Finally, the "resurrection phase" occurs if the immune system finds its way back into the body through one of the many ways it spreads throughout the body. This can happen either because you were exposed to something that made your body become sensitized, like an infectious disease, or because you developed an autoimmune response to something you did during the chronic phase. When your immune system attacks your healthy nerves again, it's referred to as a "recovery." Your goal is to make sure you know what to expect during each stage so you can be ready to help others who are experiencing the same symptoms you are.

The wisdom teeth, or molars as they are known in English, are usually located on the back of your upper jaw near the front part of your mouth. They grow out from the temporal bone at the top of your skull, and then grow upward toward the floor of your mouth until reaching the roots. This process is called growth. The growth continues until the molar crown becomes large enough to accommodate the maxilla (the largest bone on each side of the face), and it will continue to grow upward after that until it reaches the soft palate by the time the child enters school age. For this reason, wisdom teeth can cause discomfort for some children during their first year of life. After the first year of life, however, wisdom teeth have almost completely stopped growing and begin to harden before entering into permanent biting positions.

You may have an allergic reaction or contact dermatitis if you come in contact with skin that has been exposed to too much of the substance called Propylene Glycol (PG). PG is used as a preservative, which means it keeps food fresh until it's opened. It also helps keep certain chemicals from reacting when they're mixed together during production processes such as making soft drinks. But when PG is accidentally spilled on your face, skin can become irritated or inflamed very quickly. PG is classified by the FDA as "generally recognized as safe," meaning it doesn't cause cancer, birth defects, or other problems. However, PG will kill some bacteria that are harmful to humans. These toxins can be absorbed through the mouth, nose, eyes, and lungs. A few of these toxins include Formaldehyde, Dibutyl Phthalate (DBP), Trichloroethylene, Brominated Compounds, and Methylisothiazolinone. Inhaling large amounts of these toxic fumes over time can result in breathing trouble, lung irritation, skin irritations, headaches, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, depression, memory loss, and more. Allergic reactions, such as swelling, itching, hives, and difficulty swallowing, can occur even after taking small amounts of PG for cosmetic purposes and can make you want to throw up or faint. The most important thing you need to know is not to use any product containing PG that contains propylene glycol, because it could damage your health.\r

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease in which your immune system attacks the central nervous system (brain, spinal cord), causing damage to nerve cells that control movement. The destruction causes symptoms such as numbness or weakness, problems speaking, swallowing, walking, and more. A few of these symptoms can be severe enough to affect your daily life; others may not be serious but could lead to other complications.\rAnswer: For most people with MS, this condition affects only their brain and spinal cord, though there are cases where it can also affect the rest of the body. This is because your immune system can attack your own tissues, including muscles and bones. However, some people experience temporary paralysis while experiencing this type of MS. If you have been diagnosed with MS, you will need to discuss your options for treatment with your doctor. This includes medication options, as well as therapy that uses electrical stimulation to help strengthen nerves.\rAnswer: Multiple Sclerosis isn't an infection, so you don't need to worry about a bacterial infection spreading through your body. Most times, however, MS symptoms start slowly, and they usually improve over time. This progress depends on how much MS has attacked your brain and spinal cord, as well as what therapies you choose. You should know that medications used in MS treatments won't stop MS attacks altogether, but they can slow down progression and help alleviate pain.\rAnswer: One of the first things we do when someone has MS is take them to the emergency room for evaluation. Your health care team will give you information about your options for treating MS, as well as what they expect from you during your time at the hospital. They'll look after you until you're discharged home. In some areas, physicians will monitor you with blood tests to keep track of any changes in your health status, including worsening or new symptoms. But even if you never return to work, there's good news! Research shows that long-term MS patients who get appropriate treatment often have better quality of life than those who don't. Mental health is often misunderstood by consumers who may need help understanding how it works. If you're looking for tips on improving your emotional well-being, these are some of the more common questions that you might be asked, so we hope this answer helps!\r


Mental health problems include depression and anxiety disorders. Depression is when someone feels sad or down; anxiety disorder is panic or agitation (including nervousness) in response to a perceived threat. People with depressive symptoms tend to be lonely and isolated, which may lead them to make risky decisions. They also have difficulty concentrating at work or school, may suffer from insomnia, and their sleep quality tends to worsen. It's important to note that mental health conditions do not cause physical illnesses like cancer or heart disease. The good news is that people with mental health conditions are much less likely than the general population to commit suicide.\r


People suffering from a variety of other mental health conditions, including bipolar disorder and schizophrenia, are particularly susceptible to certain types of abuse. These conditions increase the risk of suicide and suicide attempts, both among people with mental illness and those around them. According to CDC statistics, over 3 million adults in the United States will experience one or more forms of violence (physical, sexual, psychological, or financial) before age 65. A person with an underlying mental illness who has been abused is more likely to attempt suicide or kill themselves because they've lost control, experienced anger management issues, or had difficulties coping emotionally with everyday life.\r

"It's possible to treat both depression and substance abuse."

What should I expect after getting help?

Getting proper treatment for mental health conditions takes commitment, energy, time, and patience. Even though mental health conditions can be extremely difficult to handle on their own, there are programs available to ensure you receive professional care while you go through the healing process. If you don't feel ready to seek out counseling yourself, support groups can provide information on what services are available and where to find them. Getting professional treatment is the first step toward recovering and living healthy lives. While it may take a little longer, recovery will pay off tremendously long term. In fact, research suggests that seeking treatment for mental health conditions significantly reduces your chances of committing suicide in the future.\r

If you would like to learn more, please contact us today. We'd love to hear from you.

Questions: what are some signs of Borderline Personality Disorder? Complete Answer: As noted in the "What is borderline personality disorder?" section above, people who suffer from borderline personality disorder often experience extreme emotional reactions to small losses, such as the loss of a loved one, money problems, financial troubles, disappointment, abandonment, rejection, criticism, criticism of others, negative attention, abuse, or ridicule. They may also react out of fear, especially if their feelings seem unreasonable and irrational. In other words, they are very sensitive to any sign that a person's emotional state or behavior may be unpredictable or unexpected. They may feel paranoid or overly cautious. Some people with BPD use drugs or alcohol because they feel safer doing so than being around other people. This may make them more vulnerable to having someone else take advantage of them and manipulate them into performing harmful acts. Other times, people with borderline personality disorder use substances because they have an intense need for love or acceptance. When this occurs, it is known as an addiction. \r

\r

Questions: What are the causes of borderline personality disorder? Complete Answer: Borderline personalities are born with these traits and may develop from birth through adolescence and adulthood. Most studies suggest that there are many genetic components to the disorder. However, environmental factors play a much larger role. For example, in families where a parent has bipolar I illness, children of affected parents tend to show higher rates of bipolar disorder. Another study found that women with borderline personality disorder were more likely to live with the father of their child before age 20 years old than non-BPD mothers; therefore, there was a strong chance that their child would become severely emotionally dependent on the older man. Therefore, while genes probably affect the overall risk, the impact of stressful life events, like divorce or abandonment, can increase that risk even further. It should also be mentioned that individuals who develop depression are also at greater risk for developing borderline personality disorder. There is no clear answer on the treatment of relapses with MS, but it has been shown that there may be some benefit in reducing relapses by limiting MS activity during those periods of time when the disease symptoms appear. In other words, you can reduce your chances for having an exacerbation or relapse. This is especially true if you have severe MS at the onset of this condition. If you are not sure whether you should take steps to prevent further relapses, talk to your doctor. There is also much debate over the best way to control MS activity during these times. Some doctors recommend drugs called anti-MS therapy such as steroids or corticosteroids, while others feel that more natural ways to regulate MS activity (such as diet changes) may work better than medications. It may also be worth mentioning that many people with MS experience a relapse during their illness even though they are taking anti-MS medication. Although this could indicate that MS is simply causing them symptoms, some people believe that MS causes them relapses so that they can return to the course of drug treatments prescribed by their doctor. The problem here is that there are so many factors which affect each person's likelihood of having another flare up or exacerbation. Asking someone what they think may cause their relapses can only give us so much information, so we really shouldn't try to guess without knowing all the facts.\r

\r

Question: What is my age? \r

Answer:\r

The average age of people diagnosed with MS today is 58 years old, but the disease can strike anyone and people who have the disease for the first time can be just as likely to develop symptoms as people who have had MS since childhood. While most people diagnosed with MS will eventually make a full recovery, some people will not improve despite continued medication and treatment. That said, there are certain things that may help you get through this challenging period of life and avoid being left permanently disabled. It would be helpful to know how far along you are in the early stages of the disease before making any plans for long term care.\r

\r

Hypothyroidism is an autoimmune disease that causes the thyroid gland to produce too much of a hormone called thyroxine (T4). T4 normally goes into your bloodstream as a protein with a chemical name of triiodothyronine (T3). But when it's not absorbed in your body by your kidneys, you have a condition known as hyperthyroidism, which can cause symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, depression, muscle aches, and tremors. \nQuestion: how do I know if my doctor has hypothyroidism?\nAnswer: This is one of the most frequently asked questions by consumers searching for doctors who will diagnose them for hypothyroidism or other issues related to this disorder. There aren't many definitive tests to determine if your doctor has hypothyroidism; however, there are several ways to assess the amount of thyroid hormone being produced by your thyroid gland at any given time. These include: * Checking the levels of TSH - Thyroxine stimulation test (TSH)

* Checking the amount of free thyroxine (FTO) - Free thyroxine (FT), which is more easily measured than TSH, is usually higher than normal in people with hypothyroidism. However, the amount of FTO in response to a specific amount of TSH often fluctuates between healthy ranges. Therefore, the best way to get a good understanding of the amounts of thyroid hormones being produced from your thyroid gland depends on what type of thyroid function testing you are having done. * Using a simple saliva sample to measure the amount of TPO-cholesterol (the "good" cholesterol in your blood)

* Using a blood sample to detect small amounts of thyroid hormone called levothyroxine - A blood sample should be taken 1 hour after eating breakfast and again 2 hours later, and then 4 days later. You may need to take additional tests over time for longer periods of time. It's very important to note that some tests like the FTO test don't always give accurate results because they can vary depending on how much FTO is in the blood sample, as well as the patient's age and health status. For example, if you're younger than 50 years old, you'll likely see a high rate of FTO in your blood sample (if you've had a diagnosis of Graves' Disease in the past, or if you've recently been diagnosed with Hashimoto's disease). If you're older than 50, there isn't a significant difference

Most recently, researchers at Washington State University have found that taking a dietary supplement called green coffee extract (GCE) helped alleviate symptoms associated with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). GCE has been shown to be effective in increasing cognitive abilities in children with ADHD who had not responded to other treatments. The research team also discovered that it can reduce cortisol levels in the body which may help improve sleep quality. GCE is sold as a supplement but may be available under other names.\r

The American Psychiatric Association says that while many medications used to treat Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder include some form of stimulant ingredient (e.g., amphetamine), there isn't any evidence that these medications are better than placebos in treating this disorder. ADHD is a behavioral problem that causes problems in your daily life such as failing to finish homework, falling asleep too quickly, or being easily distracted. Some children experience symptoms during infancy or childhood, whereas others develop them later in life. Most adults with ADHD find that the symptoms often begin around age 10-12 years old.\r

Symptoms in Adults

The signs and symptoms of ADHD vary from person to person. For example, one adult might get to school or work after spending two hours getting ready, and another would get stuck behind schedule-makers with their own personal time management issues. Symptoms usually start to improve once you manage your ADHD behavior and set goals to stay productive throughout the day.\r

Symptoms in Children

Children with ADHD tend to show several different types of behaviors including:

Fidgeting with objects

Eating a lot of food

Crying a lot

Being disruptive

Lying down

Talking a great deal

Making lots of noise

Excessive talking, screaming or crying

Trouble focusing

Poor social skills

Racing thoughts

Not listening to what others say

Frequently losing things that aren't important

Sometimes, kids

In recent years research has shown that there is a clear correlation between the prevalence of fatigue and cognitive function on a given day, particularly when measured as an index of cognitive load (the more difficult a task or task set is, the lower its level of cognitive load). Studies have also shown that individuals with higher levels of physical activity also tend to report less fatigue and better performance on mental tasks over time. The link between cognitive ability and fatigue is not absolute but rather reflects the fact that people who perform at higher cognitive skill levels tend to be able to manage their mental workload and tolerate greater levels of physical stress than those who do not. It seems likely that this link will become increasingly important as the world population ages and becomes progressively healthier. The impact of aging in general can create significant changes in both daily life and work environments and it should be possible for people to adapt and adjust their working practices to accommodate new conditions that arise as they age. For example, the effects of cognitive decline may lead to increased demands on older workers to maintain proficiency in specific cognitive tasks. As such, some job functions might require increasing levels of attention and coordination, which could translate into increased fatigue if performed alone. This type of adaptation would only result in increased risks of injury, so it would be prudent for employers to continue monitoring employees' fatigue throughout the course of their careers. If necessary, interventions could be implemented, including providing training, making adjustments to working schedules, or limiting certain types of work assignments. These adaptations would all improve productivity while reducing costs.

Answer: You have a higher risk for developing hypertension if you're obese and/or heavy smoker. Question: Can I lose weight without losing muscle?\

Answer: No. Weight loss can cause changes in muscle, including decreases in strength, size, and ability to perform activities of daily living. Some people do achieve a permanent reduction in body fat percentage, but it takes time and requires consistent effort over a long period of time. People who want to become lighter should start with healthy diet and exercise practices first. Follow these guidelines to help keep your waistline under control: 
Eat a healthy, balanced diet that includes fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, low-fat dairy products, lean meats and poultry, fish, nuts and seeds, olive oil, avocados, soy products, beans, and low-sodium foods. Limit saturated fats from animal sources, trans fats, partially hydrogenated oils, sugar, refined cereals, sweetened beverages and juices, fried potatoes, and candy. Limit calories. Exercise regularly, especially walking at least 30 minutes each day. Eat breakfast. Eat dinner. Don't skip meals. Be active. Drink plenty of water and take part in the recommended amount of moderate-intensity physical activity (such as brisk walking). Do not use tobacco products. Get enough sleep. Avoid getting too much sun during daylight hours. Keep away from sources of excess heat, such as parked cars, tanning beds, hot tubs, saunas, steam rooms, outdoor BBQ's, etc. Reduce caffeine intake. Take care of your skin. Wear sunscreen. Have regular eye exams. \[A1] This is an early stage, when your immune system has not yet been activated. It does cause some pain but is generally not dangerous or life threatening. Your body repairs itself by repairing the damage in this part of the brain. The damage can be repaired over time through your own cellular repair process which will eventually lead to full recovery.\p

\ [B1] This is a more severe form, and involves your immune system having already activated and working against your body's normal processes. These problems include swelling, redness, and stiffness, headaches, fatigue, dizziness, difficulty thinking, balance, and vision problems.\p

\ [C2] In later stages, you may experience problems with your eyesight, hearing, heart rate, blood pressure, appetite, bladder control, breathing, and memory.\r

\ [D3] Finally, there is a degenerative stage that progresses until it becomes disabling. Symptoms can include short term memory loss, numbness, tingling, paralysis, weakness, depression, hallucinations, and finally death.\r

\ [E4] Some people experience symptoms while they're asleep, even if they don't have MS. If you wake up during these episodes, try to stay calm and remember what you were doing before falling asleep. Try to relax, get comfortable, and do as much sleep as possible.\r

Primary progressive MS - a devastating neurological disease that strikes people between the ages of 20 and 60 in an average of 2 per cent of cases. A condition where nerve cells within the brain are damaged so severely that it results in loss or paralysis of parts of the body such as muscles, eyesight and speech. It is caused by damage to one part of the immune system called T-cells (Thymocytes). 
Question: What is the difference between secondary and primary progressive MS? Complete Answer: Primary progressive MS is a form of MS which occurs when the immune system attack the central nervous system first; the only symptoms are those of weakness, muscle atrophy and fatigue. The disease progresses from there and often leads to blindness and eventually death. Secondary progressive MS is less severe than primary progressive MS, but can result in vision loss, paralysis, deafness and other signs. This is known as secondary relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) which can affect more than 25% of patients who have developed RRMS at some point during their lives. 
Question: How do you know what your answer will be? Complete Answer: You must use the search feature on this site before responding. If your question isn't answered here then please e-mail us with your query and we'll try our best to find an appropriate answer for your situation. 
Question: Can I get my doctor to help me answer these questions about MS? Complete Answer: No. While we don't offer medical advice, if you're looking for specific information regarding MS medications you should speak directly to your doctor. 
Question: Is it normal to forget about your MS diagnosis after years? Complete Answer: Yes, you probably do feel better after several months of not having symptoms. However, as long as you are feeling well you shouldn't stop taking medication because you've forgotten your diagnosis. Remember, MS is a chronic illness and your symptoms won't go away overnight. You may need treatment for years or even decades.

Question: What is Multiple Sclerosis?\nComplete Answer: Multiple Sclerosis is the name given to a group of neurological disorders that affect the central nervous system (CNS) that affects 1% of all Americans between ages 18 and 64. The most commonly affected areas include the brain, spinal cord, optic nerves (eyes), arms/legs, hands, feet, and legs. In addition to these CNS abnormalities, MS patients experience pain throughout their bodies as well as cognitive impairments, memory loss, social withdrawal, inability to control muscles or speech, headaches, fatigue, difficulty sleeping, depression, nausea, vomiting, and poor concentration. Some people with MS even report feeling trapped inside their own body with a constant sensation of "being out of place". Other people don't feel any type of neurological symptoms whatsoever, but still need medication because they cannot walk without assistance; they must wear special shoes to get around, take medicine twice daily to manage their condition, and even change medications every few months when their condition worsens.\r

The most effective way to do this exercise correctly will be shown below: Stand with your feet hip width apart, palms facing each other. Lift one foot off the ground so that it is placed just under your buttock. Hold on tightly by squeezing both shoulders together and lifting your other leg up so that it rests on your opposite knee. Slowly lower your upper arm until it touches the floor before slowly raising your arm again. Repeat for the other foot. To perform the same stretching exercises but for your shoulders instead, stand with your feet at about shoulder width distance from an edge of the gym bench. Place your right hand on the bench and position yourself over it with your left elbow bent 90 degrees, palm toward the ceiling (like a triangle). Keep your eyes directly ahead and close your mouth slightly. Keeping a straight line between your fingertips, slide your thumb over the top of your right index finger. Lean forward until your chest pushes against your left thigh, keeping your chest level. Continue tilting your body left while pulling your thumb down toward the floor. Return to starting position by leaning forward and placing your left elbow on the bench. Rest for 30 seconds. Switch sides. Answer: What is biochemistry?
Complete Answer: Biochemical reactions are complex processes that occur within living systems like cells, plants and animals. They involve chemical substances called atoms, molecules, ions and electrons. The most important ones for your understanding are: carbon (carbon), hydrogen (oxygen) and oxygen (oxygen).
Answer: What is genetics?
Complete Answer: Genetic information can be found in all living things in the form of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) which contains genes (the instructions) for making proteins (enzymes). These chemicals are constantly being made by certain genes in our bodies, but sometimes these enzymes fail to do what they are supposed to do. This results in a genetic disease. This type of genetic problem causes the body to produce extra copies of some genes, thus increasing the chance that one would become active. In other cases the gene might not cause any problems at all. Genetics may also give us clues as to how we got here on earth and how to get out.
Answer: What is nutrition?
Complete Answer: Nutrition refers to the process of extracting the energy from foods such as foodstuffs and eating it to sustain life. Nutritional requirements vary depending on age, gender, activity level and metabolic rate. Food should include essential nutrients (carbs, fats, proteins, vitamins, minerals and water) in order to meet those needs. Some foods provide more than others, and some contain combinations of different types of food. Foods must be digested and absorbed before usable energy is released into the bloodstream. Many of the foods consumed by humans will naturally contribute to the production of energy in the human body. These include starch, protein, sugars, fats, fibre, alcohol and caffeine. Other dietary components, known as toxicants, have been shown to affect metabolism in undesirable ways, causing unwanted weight gain or even death if eaten in large amounts.
Answer: What is science?
Complete Answer: Science is the study of nature. As scientists, we seek to discover why something works, how it functions, how best to improve it and how to predict its future impact upon society. There are many kinds of scientific inquiry and different methods

Q: What causes premenstrual syndrome?\nA: Premenstrual syndrome (PMS), also called pre-menstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), is commonly referred to as "the menses blues," but has many different meanings depending on what you mean by it. In most cases, PMS is defined as a period between menstruation and ovulation. While there may be several reasons why a woman may experience this phenomenon, its most recognized symptom is mood swings such as sadness, irritability, anger and depression. It can last up to two weeks per cycle. Other symptoms include headaches, breast tenderness, fatigue, abdominal pain, bloating, and vaginal discharge. If left untreated, PMS can lead to anxiety, depression, eating disorders, substance abuse, menstrual problems, infertility, premenstrual fatigue, loss of sex drive, changes in appetite, decreased interest in work or school, and weight gain. Although these symptoms generally improve after stopping treatment with certain medications used to treat PMS, they should always be checked out if your doctor suspects that you might be experiencing one of them. As far as how these symptoms relate to MS, it is unclear exactly how and why they develop. However, as we move closer to understanding the mechanism of how MS starts, scientists will be able to figure out how and why these conditions happen so quickly and then stop. For now, researchers believe that the reason why people are affected by both PMS and MS may involve hormones released from the endometrium. There is evidence suggesting that the hormones melatonin and estrogen play important roles in regulating the function of the brain and nervous system. Of these, heart disease, which affects about 300 million people worldwide, is the number one killer of both men and women. Diabetes mellitus, which affects about 30-40% of all Americans, accounts for 40% of deaths from heart attacks in young adults (18 to 29). And, more than 10% of American adults suffer from some form of arthritis. Stroke of any type also kills a substantial percentage of individuals annually (5%-10%) and has been estimated that the direct medical costs related to stroke may exceed $200 billion per year. Other common chronic conditions afflicting humans include osteoarthritis, kidney problems, and digestive disorders. \r


In summary, there are many causes of death which affect our daily lives every day, such as smoking, accidents, infections, or even poor diet. These types of deaths make up only a small portion of the total number of human deaths each year. However, they are important because they contribute significantly to increased rates of morbidity and mortality. \r


The major cause of death today is cardiovascular disease, which represents about 50% of deaths caused by infectious agents (such as pneumonia), drugs (especially narcotics), alcohol, suicide, accidents, and trauma. Q: What can be done about braces? A: There are some things that can help prevent them from falling out in the first place (see below). They should be replaced every three years or as directed by your dentist. If they fall off during a visit, ask for a reminder. Some dentists will also do this procedure at home, although sometimes this isn't practical. You'll need to see a professional who specializes in keeping them on properly and repairing any damage caused by wear.


You may experience other problems like arthritis from wearing braces. But most people don't notice anything wrong until they start getting teeth pulled out. It's best not to worry too much about these types of issues though.

It's possible to replace braces yourself, but this isn't something that most people would consider unless there was serious damage. When they were installed, braces were usually made of metal, so they have lots of potential for causing health concerns over time. In fact, one study found that when you use steel braces for more than 10 years, the metals can be absorbed into the body in ways that cause liver disease, heart disease, kidney failure and nerve-damage. Even after you get rid of the rest of your dentures, they could still affect your bones. So, there's a good reason to never let anyone try to fit new ones without consulting a professional first. Most dentists require two full set of replacements before they'll even give you a call!

If you already have worn and broken braces, you should keep them as long as possible. Then try to find someone else who has them to buy them. That way, you can always go back to having regular dental visits.

The National Workers' Compensation Board (NWCB)

I've been a lawyer for 30 years now and I've handled numerous workplace injury cases. The NWCB does what is required under the law in regards to disability insurance and claims. It's important to know that there are two different levels of coverage and each has its own requirements. This can be confusing because the regulations vary from company to company and there aren't any clear instructions on exactly which employees should be covered. In fact, there isn't even clear guidance on who should qualify as a disabled worker or what compensation they should receive if injured.

The first level of protection for employees is called "employee" and consists of health, medical, and life insurance. There is also a certain amount of liability coverage. Under this plan, if someone causes a death while working, their employer is legally responsible for paying the deceased's estate a sum equal to 100 percent of the insured person's salary, plus any benefits they received over the period of the insured person's employment. If the accident was caused by the insured person and was the result of gross negligence, then the liability policy pays the legal fees for the victim's family and attorney. So if a driver injures another motorist while texting, they would have to pay the victim's family $1 million plus an additional $500,000 to cover any damage to property. On top of that, the victim's family gets to keep any money that is left after these costs are paid. When you combine this with the limited amounts of workers comp insurance available, it is very expensive for employers to pay for such a claim. Also, if an employee is unable to work due to a condition affecting his or her ability to walk or work properly, they may still get workers comp insurance, but only if the employer has made the decision beforehand.

As far as determining whether a worker should be entitled to workers comp, it depends on three things: (a) whether the employee suffered a physical impairment; (b) the extent of the physical impairment; and (c) the degree of carelessness shown by the employer.

Ketosis: What Is The Benefit Of Ketones For Diabetes? Ketone bodies are produced during fasting (or if you're eating low carb) as your body breaks down fat stores so that more energy can enter your cells and muscles. Since there's not much sugar circulating in our blood at this time, we use up some glucose reserves as fuel. Once all of the glucose has been metabolized, however, we need to get rid of any excess glycogen (stored carbohydrate) because there isn't enough available to power us through our day. However, since the liver will try to store any glucose you have stored, we don't want to burn off too many calories. By burning fat instead, we'll release ketones into our bloodstream which, according to the National Institutes of Health's "Diabetes Prevention Program" report, "will boost energy levels, help control weight gain, and reduce inflammation." In fact, Dr. John McDougall recommends using an oral glucose tolerance test after four weeks of using ketosis in his book "The China Study," which showed that the improved health and decreased risk of heart disease were the result of the ketones and not the reduction of carbohydrates. You may hear claims that ketones cause headaches and nausea in diabetics; however, studies show that these symptoms disappear once they've gone away on their own. When ketones are elevated in the blood, there are two primary ways in which they contribute to improving one's health: Reducing insulin sensitivity – As discussed above, increasing ketones helps increase insulin sensitivity and therefore reduces blood glucose levels. Therefore, reducing or eliminating sugars from our diets could potentially lower our chances of developing high blood pressure, type II diabetes, stroke, heart attack, kidney failure, cancer, arthritis, fibromyalgia, arthritis pain, muscle cramps, joint stiffness, sleep disorders, brain fog, memory loss, lack of concentration, and mood swings.

Q. What are the effects of exercise on mental and social well-being? A. Exercise helps improve mental health; improves self-esteem and mood; reduces anxiety and depression; promotes an active lifestyle that can reduce stress; decreases the risk for heart disease and certain types of cancer; increases brain volume; provides a sense of accomplishment; boosts academic performance; relieves pain and inflammation in joints, muscles and other body tissues; increases energy levels; and lowers blood pressure. These benefits may be achieved without any negative side effects or harmful long-term consequences, such as weight gain or chronic fatigue. For more information about why you should stay physically active, please see our Q4 2017 report "10 Things to Know About Physical Activity." The second group of studies focused on muscle training. The focus was not just on strengthening muscles, but also on learning how to modify them so they do what you want them to. This is a major aspect of weight training that many people don't know about.

For example, if you're interested in gaining size and strength, there are several different methods you can use (for example, single-joint movements and compound movements). For each method, you have to develop an understanding of the body's structure, as well as its function. When we train for strength and muscle mass, we're essentially trying to change how our bodies make decisions with regards to moving through space, which ultimately affects the way our muscles work. We need to be able to learn how these systems operate and adapt to new situations before doing anything more advanced.

These two types of studies were very important because they taught us a lot of things. One thing I found surprising was how much people changed their behavior after working out—not only physically, but mentally and emotionally too. They started seeing themselves differently, as well as other people. It seemed like exercise changed how people viewed themselves in all sorts of ways.

One study involved studying some men and women who had been obese prior to starting the program. What happened? Over three weeks, they were asked questions such as "How often do you think your life will get better or worse?" and "Are you satisfied with yourself right now?" After three weeks, their answer to both questions dropped by around 30 percent. In fact, when asked this question again after 12 months, only one in four participants reported being unhappy with their lives. That means they felt happier and more positive than they ever had previously, something unheard of in most studies of how exercise affected health and wellbeing. And it didn't stop at self-image; they actually saw increased productivity throughout their entire company!

Another interesting study looked at how long it took people to feel better. It compared obese individuals who had lost 10 pounds at the beginning of the study to those who hadn't done anything before. Those who did the extra workouts ended up feeling significantly better within six days, whereas those who didn't got back into shape faster—meaning the initial workout gave them a boost. So, rather than losing fat, these people were creating muscle.

This research has opened up the door for people to take control over how quickly they burn off fat—and gain muscle. In my own personal experience,

You need to know that MS is a progressive disease and you should be monitored by your doctor. The best way to monitor if the disease is progressing or not is to do daily exercise. Your doctor may recommend that you begin running as soon as possible. Some people experience improvement in their symptoms after just a few weeks of running, while others continue to have some degree of disability for months or even years after starting to run. Even when symptoms improve, they can recur at any time, so it is important to make sure you are getting sufficient sleep, eating healthy foods and avoiding tobacco, alcohol and drugs. It also helps to maintain an active lifestyle (such as walking) and keep up with other activities such as gardening or gardening classes, which can help reduce stress. A person who is diagnosed with multiple sclerosis may want to consider participating in a research study aimed at finding new treatments for this debilitating condition. This type of study involves taking part in an experimental treatment known as immunotherapy. These studies take place in different countries around the world, but most often involve small groups of patients who have already been diagnosed with MS, and then follow them over time until they have completed the treatment. These trials test out the effectiveness of immunotherapies on patients with relapsing-remitting MS, also referred to as RRMS. You may also be eligible for a clinical trial of immune therapy called exenatide, if you have received one of the previous three drugs used to treat MS. This drug works by targeting the body's own T-cells (immune system cells), and has already shown promising results in animal tests. In addition to completing your MS checkup, it is always good practice to discuss your health and medical history with your doctor. Although the risk of adverse side effects from vaccines like MMR, varicella and tetanus remains low, they remain a possibility, especially with long-term use of MMR vaccine. If you think you might be sensitive to these proteins, talk to your healthcare provider about what kinds of vaccinations you may still need.

MS affects the entire body, and people who are affected by this disease can have a range of careers. However, if you feel ready to re-enter the workforce, we encourage you to contact us at careers@moses.org (or click on "Career Opportunities" in the left column). You can also look up your state's medical boards website. We urge everyone with MS to make sure they understand all their options.

What is the best treatment for Multiple Sclerosis?\nA: The best possible care for MS depends on where you live and how long you have had symptoms. If you have a slow progressive course of MS, it is important to speak directly with your health care professional about the most appropriate way to proceed. Unfortunately, there is no cure for MS. There is a great deal of hope that therapies such as drugs and other treatments can slow down the progression of the disease. Currently available medications are not approved by the FDA and may have side effects. Although these medications may help, there are still many unanswered questions about the impact of using them on the brain. It is imperative that patients know what is considered safe and effective when it comes to treatments. Our goal is to educate you so that you have a more informed choice and the tools necessary to choose the best treatment option.

If I'm diagnosed early enough, does that mean I won't need surgery or radiation therapy after all?\nA: No, MS is very treatable, but sometimes even the best doctors cannot anticipate every possible complication. When someone is diagnosed with MS before symptoms begin, surgeons and radiologists often recommend early intervention because MS has less risk factors than cancer and heart diseases. This means that, ideally, treatment should take place before any problems develop. In fact, some studies suggest that the first three months of treatment can reduce the rate of disability for those with MS. As a result, some MS specialists will consider delaying treatment until one year after onset rather than waiting until age 30 to determine if the person has progressed to irreversible dementia. Of course, it's essential to talk to your doctor about whether treatment should continue if you experience any unusual symptoms or neurological complications.

text:
Multiple Sclerosis (MS), the most common neurological disorder, affects approximately 1.2 million Americans; one in five patients will have symptoms of MS at some time during their lifetime, and the disease is often misdiagnosed and undertreated. Symptoms vary widely across different forms of the disease. For example, patients with optic neuritis may experience pain, dizziness or loss of vision. The condition may also include fatigue, impaired coordination, weakness, numbness, tingling, or aching muscles, headaches, anemia, nausea, fever, skin rash, nerve damage or paralysis. Patients with myasthenia gravis may feel muscle weakness, difficulty walking, balance problems, sleep disturbances, or hallucinations. In addition to symptoms, individuals with MS exhibit changes in their bodies that are unique from those who do not suffer from the disease. These physical changes can be caused by the disease itself, by medications taken for it, or by other factors. Some of these conditions may be treated using various treatments, including steroids or immune system therapy. It has been estimated that there are as many as 3.3 million people living with MS worldwide.

Q: what are the major causes of MS?


a: The precise cause of MS remains unknown. As previously stated, researchers have identified several possible causes, each having a role in the development of the disease. However, research conducted over the past 50 years has only demonstrated a link between certain types of inherited genetic mutations in genes called RPE65 proteins and the risk for developing MS. Other genetic predispositions may play a role in the progression of the disease.

Q: how does the brain get damaged?


a: Damage occurs within cells lining the central nervous system, specifically in areas involved in the control of movement, sensation, memory and cognition. Examples of this type of injury include damage to the dendrites of neurons — small branches of nerve cells that receive signals from other cells — which leads to abnormal activity in the neurons' axons. Researchers believe that this activity ultimately results in increased cell death, inflammation, and neuronal dysfunction.

Q: how is MS diagnosed?


a: A doctor will examine your medical history to determine if you have any signs or symptoms consistent with MS, such as a chronic condition, unusual weight gain, unexplained shortness of breath, depression, or seizures. Multiple sclerosis is a chronic, relapsing disease of the central nervous system. It affects the peripheral nerves and the brain. Its symptoms are often progressive and non-specific. The cause of MS is still unknown; however, genetic factors have been associated with an increased risk for developing the disease. There are three primary groups that are affected by MS: 1) People who develop the disease between ages 20 and 40; 2) people who have had the disease longer than 10 years prior to their symptoms manifesting (and who may have other underlying disorders); 3) individuals who develop MS after experiencing an event such as an injury or trauma during adolescence, young adulthood, or middle age. When you talk about multiple sclerosis, people typically think of what happens in the early stages of the disease. For example, if you experience numbness, tingling, burning, heat, weakness, or any other symptoms of MS that last more than two weeks, then your doctor will likely diagnose the condition. If this occurs, then you will usually be referred to a neurologist at a hospital or clinic where they can examine your spine and other structures using X rays or MRI scans to determine exactly what's happening inside your body. You'll also undergo tests such as MRI and CAT scan to assess how well your spinal cord controls your muscles and other organs. This is important because many times, patients do not fully recover from their MS symptoms until later on. In most cases, symptoms improve over time to allow a person with MS to move around, dress themselves, eat and drink normally, use the toilet, and communicate. But there are some situations in which MS symptoms persist for months or even years, such as those caused by spinal stenosis, tumors, infections, or damage to the optic nerve in the eye. With each new symptom you experience, we'll need to determine whether it's related to MS. One way that we might confirm a diagnosis of MS would be to perform an MRI that shows abnormalities in the parts of the brain responsible for coordinating movement. However, only about half of all people who have MS show signs or symptoms that could indicate that they've actually got the disease. Even when a patient does have symptoms that suggest MS, they're not always obvious to others and can't always be diagnosed accurately. This is why finding out if you have MS will require an ongoing investigation. Most often, your symptoms come and go over the course of a year or more but sometimes they just keep coming. The National Institute of Mental Health estimates that between 12.8 and 15 percent of all American adults will experience some kind of major depression in any given year, with about 2.5 million Americans experiencing major depressive disorder each year (NIMH, 2004a). Major depression is a condition characterized by depressed mood lasting at least two weeks and associated with significant impairment in social, occupational or other areas of functioning. It often involves at least three symptoms:

1. A loss of interest or pleasure usually accompanied by weight loss

2. Lethargy or sleep disturbance

3. Feelings of guilt or worthlessness

4. Changes in appetite or weight

The NIMH also reports that suicide is the third leading cause of death for Americans aged 10 to 44 years old. Suicide is one of four main causes of death among men and women. Other major causes of death include accidents, homicides, and diseases including cancer and chronic respiratory disease (National Center for Injury Prevention and Control [NCIPC], 2006). Individuals who develop serious mental illness have an increased risk for suicidal behaviors (Paller et al., 2001; Sommers, 2005). An estimated 50 percent of people with severe depression attempt suicide during their lifetime (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] 2003), and more than 20 percent will die from it within five years (Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, 2010; CDC 2007) as compared to 16 percent of people without depression who commit suicide. These rates are similar to those seen in previous studies examining suicide attempts (Erez-Likhovskii et al., 2002). Most individuals diagnosed with depression receive treatment. Treatment consists of psychotherapy, medications, or both. Medications commonly prescribed for depression are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine, escitalopram, paroxetine, sertraline, citalopram, bupropion, and vilazodone. Other medication choices include tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI), antipsychotics, benzodiazepines, and lithium. SSRIs, which are used as monotherapy in about 75% of cases, do not cure depression but may help control its symptoms. Some patients respond well to antidepressant drugs alone, while others require several different treatments before they are fully treated. MAOIs and TCAs, typically used in combination, are considered "medication-resistant" because they tend to produce side
