on both sides of the head. The other was that it was more than just a symptom, and not the only one – but it was among them. I had been diagnosed with an "autoimmune disorder" which means my body attacked itself.

I have chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS), also known as Myalgic Encephalomyelitis or ME, often described in medical literature by a few different terms such as acute-onset, progressive, post-exertional malaise, chronic fatigue, flare up, etc.

The term chronic is what sets me apart from many people who are diagnosed with the illness but do not actually suffer from symptoms; they might be fatigued for several days at a time or even weeks at a time, but never become so tired that their ability to function is compromised. This does not mean I'm healthy though.

A recent study conducted by the British Medical Journal (BMJ) has confirmed what many ME sufferers already knew – ME is a disease of the immune system. A disease caused by long periods of inflammation, particularly in a part of our bodies called the nervous system.

The researchers found evidence that ME is characterized by a faulty or damaged brain-derived neurotrophic factor, or BDNF, which serves as a key player in regulating the balance of nerve cells throughout our body. It's like a muscle that becomes overworked and weak after years of being used regularly without maintenance. That's exactly how my body responded to the flu vaccine.

It took seven months until I felt well enough to go back to work, six months before I could return home, and finally another four months before I started feeling better again. When your body doesn't get its normal amount of rest and recovery, eventually it starts to shut down, the result of which can be debilitating or fatal for some people.

Unfortunately, there is no cure for ME/CFS, and I've spent nearly 25 years researching this problem. At first I thought the condition was just one of those things like seasonal allergies or asthma, something that you have to deal with through daily life but then don't realize all too well until it comes out into full force during sickness and the flu season.

Then, about two years ago I learned that I had an autoimmune disease. As most people know, when we're born we inherit a certain set of genes from each parent, and these genes determine whether we'll develop diseases later in life. In my case, I inherited

It includes some recipes that are easy and quick for everyone to make at home, along with more complex dishes that can be made in larger quantities but require more attention to detail (like making sure your ingredients are cooked through). The recipes are easy-to-follow, requiring only 3 ingredients and 6 minutes of preparation time. This is an important question and the answer can vary widely from person to person. However, in general terms it is a process of talking with someone who has experienced problems or issues that are related to their mind. It can also involve exploring ideas through various techniques including: hypnosis, talk therapy, biofeedback, cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT), dream interpretation and more. This approach is generally referred to as Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT).

Who might benefit from psychotherapy?

Psychotherapy can help many people experiencing a range of mental health issues, such as anxiety, depression, stress, low self-esteem, relationship problems, eating disorders, phobias, addiction and much more. People may have different ways they like to use treatment but all patients need psychological support to feel safe enough to take part in therapy. The majority of clients seeking counselling find that they get better without using psychoactive medication or therapy alone.

What do therapists usually do when working with people?

In a traditional therapeutic setting you will see the therapist every day for a set number of sessions. Depending on your needs this could be 15 minutes, 3 hours, 7 days a week. You then choose the time and place of each session, usually at a suitable location where you can relax, eat, sleep, watch television and work in peace.

How is psychotherapy done?

We will discuss a few typical stages of CBT practice. These include the following:

• Getting started: A brief introduction to you and your experience with emotions, thoughts and behaviours.

• Recognising triggers: What causes feelings of anxiety, anger, frustration and sadness?

• Understanding the nature of problems: How is thinking about yourself affecting your mood and behaviour?

• Developing coping skills: Learning how to cope with situations based around how these emotions affect you. For example: learning how to manage anger by focusing on something positive, understanding why feelings of fear lead to bad behaviour.

• Change planning: The plan for changing one's life and/or behaviour should include things to expect and avoid. Some examples may include:

• Avoidance: When negative thoughts arise, finding ways to change your environment to stop them from happening.

• Self-talk: Talking openly about difficult experiences to understand how to deal with them.

• Stress management: Practicing strategies to reduce stress before and after therapy so that negative feelings don't dominate your life.

These steps can be used

Allergies and Asthma The following are symptoms of allergic reactions: hives; swelling in the face, lips, tongue, throat, hands, arms, legs, feet, or eyes; trouble breathing; wheezing; tightness in the chest, nausea, vomiting, fever, chills; shortness of breath; tightness in the chest, rapid heart rate, or irregular heartbeat.

Anaphylaxis Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening condition that causes severe inflammation of your airway (anaphylactoid reaction). It can occur after eating peanuts, tree nuts or tree-nut products. You may have an episode as early as 30 minutes before you eat the food, but it usually begins between one hour and four hours after you eat the food. Symptoms include sudden onset of breathing problems such as difficulty breathing, coughing up thick phlegm, or experiencing difficulty swallowing; sudden shortness of breath; confusion; vomiting; increased blood pressure; wheezing; and shock. Treatment with epinephrine (adrenaline) may be needed immediately if you experience any of these symptoms. Seek immediate medical help for anyone who experiences any of these symptoms. Allergic reactions like this should be reported to your health care provider so they can treat them appropriately.

The answer to this question is a resounding yes. The key to treating type 1 diabetes (T1D) with diet and exercise is to do it in order of increasing likelihood, not as a series of fixes or treatments that you would use for every ailment (even cancer).

Most type 2 diabetics are able to control their condition by taking insulin; however, the vast majority of T2D patients do not have access to such medication, making it impossible to cure the disease without surgery.

What Causes Type 2 Diabetes?

Type 2 diabetes develops due to increased fat consumption, which leads to a buildup of glucose inside cells. Insulin then responds by cutting off the flow of sugar into the bloodstream, causing a vicious cycle that eventually results in the pancreas producing too much insulin and becoming resistant to its effects.

In the case of T2D, excessive blood sugar levels can be caused by:

Fasting – people who regularly eat little or no carbohydrates during the day often develop an unhealthy relationship with food. Many times when people fast they end up skipping breakfast, lunch and dinner altogether. As long as you consume plenty of healthy fats and protein throughout the course of your day, fasting will not be harmful.

We are all made up of a mixture of bacteria and fungi, including our own skin cells. The more we are exposed to these microbes in our lives, the more likely they are to cause problems for us. This is why using antiperspirant depletes your body of good bacteria and promotes bad ones like Staphylococcus aureus (strep throat). As Staph infections increase, you could develop an increased risk of developing other health issues such as:

Osteomyelitis,

Stomach ulcers,

Bacterial endocarditis,

Skin infection,

Meningeal inflammation,

Gastrointestinal inflammation,

Blood or fluid leaks from the stomach,

Vaginal discharge,

Erectile dysfunction,

Pancreatic cancer,

Colon cancer,

Liver disease,

Constipation,

Weight gain,

Urogenital tract disorders,

Fertility problems,

Depression,

Headaches,

Diarrhea,

High blood pressure,

Heart disease and stroke,

Breastfeeding problems,

Ulcerative colitis,

Cancer,

Inflammatory bowel disease,

Tuberculosis,

Other types of cancers, and even many rarer conditions, like chronic fatigue syndrome, autism spectrum disorder, dementia and Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, multiple sclerosis and more! These conditions can be caused by the effects of the microbial imbalance present in our bodies when exposed to antiperspirants.

To read about how antiperspirants could contribute to some of these illnesses go here.

So what do I use?

The best thing to use to prevent any type of bacterial growth within your home is simple…use a clean washcloth with plenty of water on it! If you have dryer sheets lying around you may want to try putting them away because most cleaning products contain chemicals that will create a similar effect to drying out fabrics without really working. Instead of trying to remove them through your laundry detergent you should simply add a bit of water to the dryer sheet and rub it across the cloth to dry it completely. You don't need anything fancy, just a towel or two and enough water so that there isn't much left after washing. The moisture from the fabric will

and ovarian function. In addition, the use of hormonal contraception was associated with a small decrease in the incidence of breast cancer but not an increase or decrease in risk for ovarian cancer.

However, this study is limited by several potential limitations. First, the analysis included only women who were using oral contraceptives at the time of diagnosis. Because many users may discontinue their prescription because they develop adverse effects, it would be advisable to conduct follow-up studies comparing long-term effectiveness of estrogen plus progestin versus placebo. Second, there are no data on long-term safety and efficacy of combined contraceptive pills or progestins when taken alone. Third, the authors did not estimate the relative risks due to different patterns of use. Fourth, although all the cancers were found among postmenopausal women, most cases occurred before age 50 years. However, previous research has demonstrated that breast and prostate cancer occur more often among men in younger ages than older ones. Fifth, the analyses were based on self-reported information on use of estrogen-only products (oral contraceptives) and oral contraceptives containing synthetic estrogens. These substances have been shown to contain varying amounts of the active ingredient, and some are contraindicated during pregnancy for a variety of reasons (e.g., liver toxicity). Although the findings from the present study are consistent with previous reports showing an increased risk of breast cancer in association with the use of these products, further investigation into the possible mechanism of action needs to be undertaken. Finally, there could also be bias due to selection of patients included in the study, which may be influenced by socioeconomic factors such as education level. Therefore, future studies should include controls selected according to other relevant variables including ethnicity, lifestyle, family history and smoking habits.

In conclusion, this large prospective cohort study suggests an increased risk of developing advanced stage breast cancer after switching from nonhormonal to hormone replacement therapy. The finding merits further study for prevention purposes, particularly in premenopausal women.

text:
The neurologist will often give you an MRI if there is swelling in your brain. But it doesn't look like MS is the cause for this swelling, so don't worry about getting an MRI just because you have one. A CT scan (computerized tomography) is usually recommended and can show areas where MS may be affecting the spinal cord or other parts of the body. These scans are done to rule out cancer or other disorders that could be causing your symptoms. The doctor also might recommend an electroencephalogram (EEG). An EEG measures electrical activity through electrodes placed on a person's head. It can help determine whether there's a problem with how your nerves communicate with each other.

A test called an electromyogram (EMG), which looks at different muscle groups, can also provide clues. Your doctor will ask you to do some exercises while watching how your muscles move during this type of testing. Sometimes, a blood sample or urine test can also help diagnose the disease.

text:
How does the menstrual cycle contribute to MS and other neurological disorders?

What are the commonalities in menstrual problems, such as PMS or premenstrual syndrome (PMS)?

Menstruation and Multiple Sclerosis: A Brief History

Multiple sclerosis is a disease of the central nervous system characterized by the inflammation of myelin sheaths that surround nerve cells. This inflammation can cause an imbalance between the amount of white matter and gray matter in the brain. At first, MS may not be related at all to sexual activity. However, for many women with MS, there seems to be an association of low levels of progesterone during the perimenopausal period with increased risk of developing MS later in life [1]. Women who experience early menopause have been found to have significantly higher rates of MS than non-users of birth control [2], possibly because they have less progesterone circulating through their bodies. In addition, hormonal changes associated with menopause make it harder to maintain adequate estrogen production. For some women, this leads to chronic fatigue, depression, anxiety, irritability, sleep disturbance, and other signs of stress. These symptoms are usually more prominent when women begin experiencing menopause, which happens about 1–3 years after menopause begins. Thus, these symptoms may be one factor contributing to the development of MS.


In fact, some studies have suggested that menopause itself may increase the risk of developing MS. Some women develop MS after having their menstrual cycles stop altogether while others develop MS soon after starting to menstruate again [3]. Many doctors believe that factors other than menstrual cycle changes are responsible for MS; however, no conclusive evidence exists yet for whether estrogen deficiency plays any role in the disease's development.


For decades, MS patients have had a hard time getting reliable information from health care professionals about how normal monthly menstrual cycles affect a woman's risk of developing MS. The only way to find out if someone has MS was to perform invasive testing on them. Since then, much has changed. Today, more women know about the importance of maintaining healthy menstrual cycles and know about hormone replacement therapy options. Also, there has been a growing body of research demonstrating that different types of hormones — including progestins, thyroid hormones, estrogens, and testosterone — play important roles in regulating the female reproductive process [4].


There are many reasons why the average woman might experience difficulty conceiving throughout her entire period. These include:

Hormones

We have known about the physical dangers of too little protein for thousands of years—for example, in Hippocrates' advice against taking fish oil supplements because he thought that their lack of essential fatty acids might cause muscle wasting. In recent times, scientists have discovered new ways to make proteins that are lacking in humans. These include a group called beta-lactoglobulin (BLG), which causes diarrhea and can be used to treat inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease. Another group called alpha-galactosidase, also responsible for making vitamin K2, may be able to reduce cancer risk by improving blood clotting. Researchers in China recently identified another important protein missing from the human genome—a long chain of amino acids that plays an integral role in DNA replication. This means that in order to repair damaged DNA, genes must work together. Scientists at Columbia University announced this week that they had developed a way to use BLG to build up proteins that can fix defects in these chromosomes and then deliver them directly into cells where they'll do their healing work—regardless of whether they're from a human embryo or a mouse cell. The discovery could eventually allow researchers to generate functional replacement organs for patients with severe genetic disorders such as muscular dystrophy.

If anyone is considering changing jobs, then they should first talk to their doctor as there is plenty of information available on the condition. This is a very common question. The short answer to your question is YES, there are some studies that show an improved glycemic control in diabetics on a low-carbohydrate diet. There's also been anecdotal reports of improvements in insulin sensitivity and blood sugar control (in the form of reduced insulin resistance). However, this is not something that has been backed up by any solid evidence. To be clear, these diets don't necessarily have to consist solely of fat loss, but they do need to include good quality protein and carbs. For example:

You can read more about the science behind ketosis here.

What should I eat if I want to go into ketosis?

If you have Type 1 diabetes, you probably won't want to eat much carbohydrate at all. This means no breads or pastas, and certainly no potatoes. You're already severely restricting calories so you will see negative effects on weight loss. If you have Type 2, you may also benefit from reducing carb intake further as well. However, even those with Type 2 can still gain significant weight when eating carbohydrates, so it is important to eat a healthy balanced diet consisting of both fats and proteins to allow your body to utilize them properly without excess insulin production.

For Type 3 Diabetics…

There hasn't yet been enough research to determine whether diabetic patients who adhere to a ketogenic diet lose weight. We know that it improves blood glucose control and reduces insulin levels, but we haven't seen results in the long term. Our best bet right now would be to follow a high fat, moderate protein, and moderate carb diet. Here's a great resource on how to implement a low-carb/high fat strategy in Diabetes Care.

It's not just the fitness and health benefits that are important to consider, but also what these statistics mean for our long-term well-being and how we can use them to help us live healthier lives. The National Institute on Aging (NIA) has made a list of six major takeaways from this data:

1. Physical Activity Can Reduce Mortality – Physical activity can reduce mortality rates by as much as 40% for older adults.

2. Regular Exercise May Improve Your Health – A moderate amount of regular exercise is linked with better overall health, lower risks of heart disease and diabetes, lower blood pressure, and decreased risk of death due to cancer and stroke.

3. Reducing Obesity Can Help You Live Longer – While obesity was thought to be an independent predictor of premature death, new research suggests it may actually play a role in prolonging life.

4. Physical Activity Is More Effective Than Drugs For Treating Diabetes – Most people with type 2 diabetes will need medical intervention at some point in their lives. People who are physically active and eat healthy foods tend to have lower incidence of complications when they do need insulin.

5. A Healthy Diet And Physical Inactivity Are Associated With Better Cognitive Performance – Older adults who engage in at least 150 minutes per week of aerobic activities or 150 minutes per week of vigorous exercise enjoy better cognitive performance than those who stay sedentary.

6. If We All Actively Work To Get More Active, We Will Be Able To Achieve Our Goals Faster – It turns out that if everyone acts like they want to get more active, then they will likely achieve their goals faster.

What is the treatment for toxoplasmosis?

Toxoplasmosis is treated with a combination of medicines that include:

Drugs to prevent infection and to reduce symptoms (antibiotics)

Medications used to treat certain health problems such as arthritis, diabetes, heart disease and liver disease

Antifungal medications that can help prevent or treat infections caused by fungus

If you have not been previously treated for toxoplasmosis, your doctor will recommend that you take one of these drugs every day until your immune system has had enough time to work out how to destroy the parasite once it's been infected. The medication may be taken orally, given through an IV drip or injected into muscle, and lasts approximately four weeks. You are also advised to avoid eating raw or undercooked meat, fish, shellfish and eggs for at least two months after being treated so as not to pass on any parasites from them.

How do I know if my baby was born without congenital toxoplasmosis?

Some babies aren't born completely healthy due to defects in their development or because they were born prematurely. If this happens, there are ways to find out whether your baby has toxoplasmosis during routine screening. This information will allow your obstetrician/gynaecologist to decide what measures are needed to ensure he or she is free from toxoplasmosis.

Do pregnant women need to get tested for Toxoplasma gondii and other STDs?

Pregnant women should be screened regularly for toxoplasmosis throughout pregnancy. Screening includes taking a single blood sample at around 24-26 weeks gestation to measure levels of antibodies against toxoplasmosis and other diseases. Women who test positive for toxoplasmosis antibodies should receive further testing to confirm the diagnosis and make sure that all other risks associated with pregnancy remain well controlled. A total of five tests may be required depending on when the mother was last exposed to toxoplasmosis in her lifetime. There is no evidence that pregnant women who don't already have immunosuppressive conditions should undergo additional testing during pregnancy. However, women whose risk factors are known to increase their chances of exposure should consider testing anyway. For example, some people are more likely than others to become infected while having sex, so those who engage in unprotected vaginal sex might want to consider getting tested before giving birth.

Poor quality of life and social interaction – Many people with MS struggle to live independently. For many others it means being unable to work and making poor family relationships. They may find themselves having trouble sleeping because their body is constantly on alert. Some become so dependent on medication or other treatments that there's not much time left over for anything else.

They also tend to be at greater risk from certain infections like pneumonia. Because MS affects an area of the brain where nerve cells (neurons) communicate, this can lead to damage that damages nerves throughout the body. The resulting physical difficulties can include loss of vision, numbness and tingling on one side of your body, weakness, fatigue and cognitive issues such as memory loss.

The findings also suggest that this relationship between vitamin B12 deficiency and inflammation may be similar for people with MS and Alzheimer's disease, the team wrote in their paper published online July 15 in Science Translational Medicine.

"We are not suggesting these diseases have an identical underlying mechanism but we think there is enough overlap to warrant further investigation," said study leader Jeffrey Hausdorff, professor of neurology at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine. "It would not surprise me if we find common mechanisms."

The answer to this question is that the most common form of Multiple Sclerosis (MS) results from an autoimmune process. The immune system attacks and destroys myelin, the fatty coating around nerves that helps them transmit signals properly. This damage causes a person with MS to have problems with their balance, movement, speech, vision or hearing. All of these symptoms can be debilitating and even deadly for some people. For others, MS affects only one body part – the brain. In fact, when you're diagnosed with MS, the doctors typically diagnose you based on a physical examination at your first appointment. The purpose of the exam is to rule out any other conditions that might cause your symptoms. If they find nothing else wrong, then they may tell you that you have MS and give you treatment guidelines. The important thing to remember about your initial evaluation at your doctor's office is that the exams are done so that the doctor knows what areas of your body need special attention. They also want to make sure there aren't any new health issues developing during the course of your disease.


What is the relationship between brain function and multiple sclerosis?

Multiple sclerosis occurs in almost exclusively women. According to National Institutes of Health research, 70-85 percent of MS patients are female. Women tend to develop more slowly than men do. While men are generally able to walk normally and drive a car without difficulty, women often lose their ability to use their legs after being diagnosed with MS. Studies have shown that women are twice as likely to experience episodes of numbness or tingling in their limbs. Symptoms of MS may range from mild to severe. The severity depends on how much tissue has been damaged within the nerve cells. There are many different types of MS, including: Primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPM): An inflammation of the central nervous system that begins in the spinal cord and eventually affects all five of its major branches. PPM affects approximately 1/3 of women who get diagnosed with MS. Patients' muscles become weak and gradually weaken until they stop moving altogether. Secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS): A type of MS characterized by symptoms such as muscle weakness, loss of coordination and loss of bladder control; however, unlike primary progressive MS, secondary progressive MS doesn't affect the whole body. It is rarer and less aggressive in women compared to men. Spinal cord injury: A traumatic event — like a car accident — that injures the spinal cord, causing nerve cell damage. Severe or repeated injuries can lead to permanent damage and loss

Managing Mental Health Problems in Children

When Should I Call My Doctor?

Call your doctor if you think you might have a serious problem. You should be sure to get accurate information before making any decisions. Many young people don't call because they're afraid that something won't happen, but the truth is that even small changes can make all the difference in preventing future problems. If you do decide to see your doctor, make an appointment as soon as possible so you can discuss things like:

If you've been taking medication for a long time

Your specific medications

All your treatment plans

Any side effects, such as headaches, dizziness, low blood pressure, digestive issues or memory loss

Anything else that's going on that might affect your ability to take care of yourself.

What Kind of Treatment Will I Need?

There are many treatments available to treat mental illnesses. They may include psychotherapy, cognitive behavior therapy, family counseling and/or group support groups. The type of treatment used will depend on the cause of your mental illness and its severity. For example, some children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) may require medication to control their symptoms, while others may benefit from therapy alone. Some treatments may involve weekly sessions over several months, while other methods may provide short-term relief. There are also some techniques for treating mental health issues that involve only one person, called "one-on-one" counseling. While this method isn't very effective for everyone, it has helped some adolescents who had difficulty coping with typical school activities.

A team led by University of Edinburgh neuroscientist Professor Paul McGlashan, the lead author on the study published in The Lancet Psychiatry journal, looked at a group of people with Borderline Personality Disorder who had previously been diagnosed as having antisocial tendencies. They asked them to complete various tasks which measured how well they could inhibit their impulse to act. It is important to note that these measures are not designed to measure how much you like something – but rather whether your brain switches off the urge to do it. This is known as the 'impulsive switch' or 'inhibition system'. These individuals were found to have an abnormally high level of activity in this area, suggesting that they were more likely to be impulsive and aggressive than other participants. What's more, the researchers found that the extra activation in the impulsivity switch was associated with increased levels of testosterone in men, and decreased testosterone in women.

The results may explain why people with Borderline Personality Disorder report feeling more angry when they feel rejected. As part of their experiment, McGlashan and his colleagues recruited 19 men (mean age 36) from two separate groups: 12 were members of a support group for those suffering from BPD and 9 were participants in a control condition where they weren't given any information about BPD. Each participant then completed a series of tasks to measure their impulsiveness, anger sensitivity, and depression.

When compared with controls who didn't receive any treatment, these participants reported feeling more angry, more often felt depressed, and had higher levels of anxiety as well. All of these changes seemed to correlate with lower levels of testosterone in both men and women.

"Our findings suggest that there may be some biological basis for how BPD affects individuals," said McGlashan. "It may be that people with BPD experience heightened feelings of anger, hostility and frustration and this might trigger changes in hormone production."

In light of these findings, McGlashan believes further research into the effects of medication on hormone levels should be conducted. He also suggests that interventions such as cognitive behavioural therapy might help patients reduce their risk of being violent.

Reference

The aim of this study was to explore the relationship between MS activity in the brain and changes in serotonin (5-HT), dopamine, norepinephrine, and glutamate concentrations in the cerebrospinal fluid of patients with active disease. Serum samples were obtained from 18 patients who had been diagnosed as having primary progressive MS at baseline; 12 patients with relapsed or secondary progressive MS; 11 controls without MS and 14 people with other neurologic diseases. Patients who had received at least 2 doses of methylphenidate within 3 months before data collection were excluded from analysis. The results showed that levels of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is an indicator of neuronal damage, did not differ significantly between patients with active disease and controls. However, differences were found between patients with active and untreated disease in serum levels of serotonin, noradrenaline, dopamine, and glutamate. Although treatment with 5-HIAA was associated with greater reductions in serum levels of these neurotransmitters, there were no significant effects on clinical markers of progression.

The association between MS and serotonin has long been well known. Previous studies have shown reduced serotonin metabolism in MS subjects, but it remains unknown whether this reduces 5-HT production. Serotonin may also mediate some of the symptoms seen during MS relapse, suggesting a role for 5-HT in mediating many of the conditions thought to be associated with MS such as fatigue, pain, sleep disturbances, depression, cognitive impairment, and mobility disability.

While previous work using animal models suggests that increased 5-HT transmission through the 5-HT1a receptor contributes to the pathogenesis of neurodegeneration [7], no direct evidence exists to support this hypothesis in humans. In addition, pharmacological manipulation of serotonin levels has resulted in only limited efficacy in treating MS [8]. Recently, 5-HT2 antagonists are being developed for use in treating MS [9], yet their effectiveness has not been tested in human clinical trials. Given the emerging interest in developing therapies that target 5-HT pathways and neuroplasticity, we examined whether treatments targeting 5-HT signaling would alter MS pathology and its symptomatology. Our goal was therefore to determine whether 5-HT abnormalities might impact on MS-related pathological features and behavioral response in humans.

The National Multiple Sclerosis Society has produced an excellent guide to the condition. You can download it here: MS Symptoms Guide.

You'll find a description of symptoms, along with their causes and treatments at the bottom. The guide is divided into sections on 'brain', 'eye' and'skin'.

Here's a summary of what you need to know about the neurological problems that cause multiple sclerosis – and how they're treated:

Multiple sclerosis is caused by damage to the nervous system in the brain and spinal cord. This affects people's ability to control their movement, feel pain or sense touch.

Many other conditions can also affect the central nervous system, but no one exactly knows why these two areas are particularly vulnerable to nerve cell death.

Some types of multiple sclerosis (MS) result from damage to blood vessels that supply the nerves with oxygen and nutrients. Others develop when immune cells destroy part of the lining of the spinal fluid (endothelium).

Nerve cell degeneration can be triggered by certain infections, infection of the skin (dermatitis herpetiformis), smoking and certain drugs like alcohol. It usually happens slowly over years; some cases, however, become life-threatening.

There are different kinds of multiple sclerosis, which describe each type of damage as well as treatment options. Some patients may require more than one kind of medicine to manage their symptoms.

When your doctor tells you that you have multiple sclerosis, he or she will ask if there are any special problems. They may even do tests to try to identify which parts of the central nervous system are affected.

Methods Patients with SPMS were recruited from April 2007 to August 2010 at seven medical centres in Germany, Austria, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom: Braunschweig University Hospital, Erlangen, Germany; Erasmus MC, Rotterdam, Netherlands; Heidelberg University Hospital, Heidelberg, Germany; Würzburg Hospital, Frankfurt/Main, Germany; Freiburg University Hospital, Freiberg, Germany; Maastricht University Medical Center, Maastricht, The Netherlands; and Weill Cornell Medicine, New York, USA. A total of 797 cases were included in this analysis. All patients aged 25–55 years were enrolled in the study. Baseline clinical data were collected using a structured questionnaire. Clinical variables included age, sex, disease duration, baseline disability index, baseline neurological examination score, and baseline SPMS activity index scores. Results of multivariate logistic regression analyses revealed that the following factors significantly predicted SPMS progression over time: patient's age (P < 0.001), gender (P = 0.002), disease duration (P = 0.01), presence of an SPMS lesion on MRI prior to enrollment (P = 0.02), and high-grade gliomas (P = 0.02). There was no significant association between disease duration or brain imaging abnormalities and SPMS relapse. The results are discussed below.

Results Fifty-four (5%) of the 797 patients had experienced a full-blown diagnosis of SPMS. Table 1 summarizes the demographic and clinical features of the study population. The mean (SD) age of all SPMS patients was 43 (15) years. Of these patients, 48% (n = 511) had been diagnosed before their first hospitalization for the condition. The most common causes of SPMS onset were spinal meningitis, diabetes mellitus, infectious diseases, and autoimmune disorders. Twenty-three percent (n = 260) of those presenting with SPMS were younger than 30 years of age. Most of them presented as primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PRMS) [20], whereas 19% (n = 186) presented as secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPSM) [16]. Sleep is a complex process that involves many physiological systems, including the brain. Several studies have found links between sleep disturbances and MS. The findings suggest there may be an association of disturbed sleep with MS, but further research is needed. The National Sleep Foundation recommends seven or more hours of restful sleep per night for everyone over 50 years old, although most older adults do not achieve this standard.

The question you ask is really a matter of interpretation and assessment. If your patient has had a recent episode of sleep disruption, it might be appropriate to ask about possible underlying medical factors that could account for their difficulty falling asleep (e.g., depression). This should only be done with the patient's permission if they are unable to get up in the middle of the night when asked or otherwise feel unwell and unable to stay awake at night. In general, patients who report insomnia due to MS often also suffer from other conditions such as depression and anxiety, which can make them difficult to manage and manage well.

For instance, a person suffering from chronic low mood is likely to have trouble staying motivated to go to work or school or feel depressed. Many people report having difficulties getting up in the morning; others struggle to keep the lights on all day and are exhausted after waking up late each evening. These changes in behaviour will interfere with sleep patterns. So, asking your patient whether they have experienced sleep problems related to MS may reveal some underlying issues that need addressing in order to improve sleep quality. It would be helpful to consider whether sleep problems related to MS could be caused by other conditions and then discuss strategies to deal with any underlying health concerns, including medication use.

. The study, which looked at the results of nearly 2,000 participants, found that individuals with a genetic predisposition for developing multiple sclerosis (MS) have an increased risk of developing other autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

"The idea that you're born with one disease is not accurate," said study co-author Michael Hirsch, MD, director of the Center for Genomic Medicine in the Department of Dermatology and Vascular Surgery at University Hospitals Case Medical Center in Cleveland. "You can get many different diseases from having this single gene."

In fact, those who carry a certain variant of the MS gene have about twice as much risk of developing more than two additional autoimmune diseases, compared to those who do not. This means that someone might be prone to developing multiple sclerosis, for example, but then face an even greater risk of getting RA and lupus later on down the road.

These new findings, published today in the Journal of Clinical Investigation, will help researchers better understand how genes affect the development of multiple sclerosis, and ultimately lead them to better treatments for those affected by these devastating autoimmune diseases.

"Understanding the pathophysiology of these disorders helps us design new drugs and therapies, such as immunosuppressants that target specific genes or immune stimulation strategies targeting some key proteins associated with inflammation and autoimmunity," Dr. Hirsch explained. "As we learn more about how each type of autoimmune disorder develops, it may also open the way for us to identify biological markers related to susceptibility, so clinicians could monitor patients' health status over time to determine whether they are likely to develop any particular disorder.

Dr. Hirsch is also chief of dermatologic surgery at University Hospitals Case Medical Center. He and his colleagues studied the genetics of the MS gene on chromosome 16p13.1, which contains over 500 genes, making it the most common MS locus. They used genome-wide SNP genotyping techniques to compare the DNA sequences between those who had MS and those who did not. A total of 1,005 people were included in the research.

The study focused only on those with no family history of MS or rheumatoid arthritis. They determined that the most common MS-linked variants involved MS genes involved in the production of the peptide interleukin-10 (IL-10), which regulates cell growth and function, and IL-2, which plays a role in controlling inflammatory processes. Keep trying to push outwards towards your toes. As soon as you can feel yourself starting to get some range of motion at your sternum (where your rib cage begins), start pushing up. Start by holding one hand down in front of you (so it's resting against your abdomen) then slowly move your arm forward, letting go of the grip once your chest is at full extension. You'll know your chest has reached its maximum when you feel a slight pull in your bellybutton. If this doesn't happen, keep going until you're able to do each rep without any pain whatsoever!

Doing this exercise will help strengthen your abdominal muscles and give you a nice round look with no fat attached. According to a recent report by The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), the current UK food system is failing on all three counts:

Nutrition

Product safety

Cost

The EFSA's analysis, based on 17 years of research, concludes that "the UK food supply system is not fit for purpose."

To understand what this means, it helps to think about food as a whole — from seed through to shelf-stable foods. A healthy diet for individuals requires a balance between nutrients and micronutrients such as vitamins, minerals and essential fatty acids. These are found naturally in foods such as fruits, vegetables, nuts and seeds; but too much or too little of any one nutrient can affect how we feel, feel like, react to stress or cope with illness. For example, high intakes of sodium can lead to hypertension, while dietary fibre has been shown to reduce the risk of developing diabetes.

Unfortunately, our food system isn't designed to provide these balanced nutrients. It has evolved over thousands of years to meet the needs of people in isolated parts of the globe living in harsh conditions where there wasn't the time or resources to grow their own food. This meant that when people moved to cities, they were forced to eat processed, highly concentrated, low nutrition meals made up largely of sugar, salt and oil. This led to many developing chronic diseases which, as the World Health Organisation notes, may be caused by our poor diets alone. Obesity, heart disease, cancer, type 2 diabetes and many other health problems have also emerged because people haven't had enough variety in the food they eat.

We've already started down a very slippery slope towards an epidemic of obesity in the UK. In 2015, more than 1.3 million Britons aged 16 and older were classed obese. There was an additional 700,000 adults classified as overweight, although experts estimate that around 60 per cent of them will gain weight back at some point during their life. By 2050, obesity rates will double.

Psychotherapy: a brief introduction to the topic by Dr. David R. Lewis, M.D., Director of Research at The Institute for Meditation and Psychotherapy (IMPACT), New York City.

In this chapter we'll explore what psychotherapy is—its history and function, its purpose and practice in various cultures and professions, and how it has evolved over time. Then we'll examine some of the ways that therapy can be beneficial—for both the patient and therapist. We'll look at ways you might use therapy in your own life. And lastly, we'll discuss how to find a therapist who will help you achieve your goals and reach your dreams!

The History of Psychotherapy

Like medicine, psychology developed gradually over time from ancient times up through the 20th century. In fact, most doctors did not even recognize medicine as an "art" until much later. Psychology was born out of the desire to understand and treat human behavior. It grew out of Freud's ideas about psychoanalysis and behavioral therapy; Kertbeny began researching the field during the early 1900s; and the American Psychiatric Association formally recognized mental illness in 1952.

Early psychologists were called mentalists, after the Greek term meaning "mind-maker." They studied how people thought and acted, and often used clinical observation to determine why people behaved in certain ways. As with psychiatry, these practices became more scientific as they gained legitimacy.

But one day an anonymous letter arrived in Kertbeny's office titled "An Open Letter on the Treatment of Mental Illness by Psychoanalytic Methodology," which was written by Thomas Szasz, a medical doctor, writer, and psychiatrist from Budapest, Hungary. His words were shocking because he said that his profession was based on the assumption that all mental disorders could be cured. He felt that psychiatrists had been misled into thinking they knew everything there was to know about mental health. By now, every schoolchild in America had heard that schizophrenia resulted from abnormal brain chemistry caused by environmental insults such as abuse or poverty. This idea came from Freud himself, but he never explained exactly how this happened or exactly when it should occur.

Szasz argued that, given sufficient knowledge, patients could also get better through treatment, and that it would take years before any diagnosis or drug was necessary. But if one diagnosed someone with a disorder without trying to correct their problems, then it wasn't possible to learn anything useful, especially because each person would have unique experiences and

What is known about the link between contraception and infertility?

Contraception can affect fertility by increasing the risk of getting pregnant (contraceptive failure), or causing an unintended pregnancy to end before it starts (miscarriage). This is usually due to the woman having used contraception incorrectly.

While many women have a good response when their contraceptive fails, others do not respond as well. For example, women who choose not to take any contraception may experience irregular periods because they are unable to keep up with their monthly cycle. Other women may have more difficult deliveries due to changes in hormone levels caused by contraceptive failure. Some people may also find that regular sex means that their ovaries stop working properly, which increases the chances of getting pregnant again in future.

It has been estimated that contraceptive failures cause around 3% of pregnancies among couples using modern methods. In addition, approximately 1 million women suffer from pre-eclampsia - a condition where the placenta becomes too thick and causes severe bleeding during pregnancy. If left untreated, pre-eclampsia can lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, premature delivery, and even death.

In 2011, WHO published new estimates of the total global burden attributable to unsafe abortion. It estimated that unsafe abortions account for 5% of all maternal deaths worldwide.

How does this study compare with previous research?

Previous studies into the association between contraceptive failure and fertility outcomes have relied heavily on self-reported data. A recent review of these and other available studies found evidence suggesting a possible relationship between contraceptive failure and spontaneous abortion or ectopic pregnancy but concluded that it should be treated with caution given the large number of reported cases of both spontaneous abortion and ectopic pregnancy in studies across multiple countries over time.

This study builds upon prior work by using a more accurate measure of contraceptive failure: hormonal contraception failed. Researchers measured how often the hormones involved in contraception - like the combination pill, the injectable progestogen IUD and implants - stopped being effective after 12 months. They compared the rates of spontaneous abortions, ectopic pregnancies and still births in women who were using different types of contraception at the start of the study period.

They then adjusted the results to account for differences in factors associated with fertility problems. These included age, socioeconomic status,

pulmonary embolism pulmonary fibrosis polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (POTS), also known as PCOS, is a group of conditions in which the ovaries produce too many male hormones. It can affect up to 10 percent of women between the ages of 15 and 35, but it affects about 3-5 percent of men. Some forms of PCOS are hereditary, while others may be caused by lifestyle factors or medical problems. Certain drugs that treat high blood pressure, diabetes, and heart disease can increase your risk for developing PCOS. High-fiber diets help lower cholesterol levels and improve insulin sensitivity. How can you be sure if it's just another bad case of MS, or a real and dangerous disease that needs to be treated with drugs?

The first thing you need to know is that there are different types of MS. There are relapses and non-relapses. Relapse happens when the immune system mistakenly attacks your nerve cells, causing permanent damage that can be difficult to correct. Non-relapse, on the other hand, occurs without any warning signs. The symptoms in this category include numbness and tingling in some areas of your body, loss of muscle strength, pain, weakness, fatigue, sleep problems, mood swings, difficulty concentrating and more. You may have seen patients like this before, but they're not all relapsed MS.

How do doctors diagnose MS?

When you see someone who has been diagnosed as having relapsing remitting MS (RRMS), you'll probably hear a lot about their illness from their health care provider. This is part of their job: making sure that you're getting the right treatment for your condition, even though you might feel uncertain about what's happening. They want to make sure you get the right medicine — specifically immunosuppressant medications — at the right time so that you don't lose too much control over your condition. In most cases, these treatments last between two to four weeks; sometimes they will take longer.

In general, doctors say they give you three to five months to recover from relapses. But in reality, that is often insufficient, especially during your worst periods. So doctors may prescribe an additional course of medication after you've had several good days of improvement. After several months, they usually recommend going back to your primary doctor, who can review your records again and decide whether you should be further examined. If you still have trouble with your mobility, your neurologist might suggest surgery. Another option is that you could try to keep active and participate in physical therapy.

What are the risks of being diagnosed with RRMS?

Although relapses are relatively common, many people never go through one. Others experience relapses every few years, while others can stay well into adulthood and beyond. When someone becomes ill, doctors are trained to treat them as soon as possible, including starting treatment immediately after an initial visit. However, you are also responsible for yourself. You can get medical leave from your employer if you have multiple sclerosis, as long as you are working at least 20 hours per week for an employer that is not a government agency or the U.S. Postal Service. This leave applies to both men and women. It includes time off work due to illness or injury while on FMLA leave and also time when you take disability leave under the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA). Please note: If your current job does not permit employees to accrue family leave days or if your company has policies that do not allow you to take FMLA leave, you may qualify for another type of leave, such as sick pay, vacation, or personal days. For more information about qualifying for other types of leave, please see our page on Employee Benefits.

I have MS and am going into my fifth year of treatment. Are there any restrictions on me getting employment?

Employers must give you reasonable notice before they will consider you for a change in position unless it is necessary to make a bona fide personnel decision (i.e., to maintain the effectiveness of existing staffing levels), and you meet all other qualification requirements for promotion, transfer, reassignment, etc. The same rules apply to returning workers who return after having left their last job because of their illnesses. For example, employers cannot exclude you from consideration for new positions until you complete your first 12 weeks of qualified coverage.

If I'm eligible for FMLA leave, is this available to my spouse/partner? Do I need to be in the same household as my wife/partner?

No. In order to receive FMLA benefits, you must be able to show that you meet both of the following conditions:

You must be the employee's primary caretaker for four weeks during a 30 consecutive calendar month period. Your primary caregiver may include either spouse, registered domestic partner or former spouse. A child who is part of your relationship with the employee may be treated as your primary caregiver, even though he or she may live with his or her parent(s) or legal guardian. An employee who leaves their job for one or two months but returns to work without taking FMLA leave does not qualify as a "primary caregiver." However, an employee who takes FMLA leave for one or two months may still qualify as a "primary caregiver" if they reenter the workforce within 60 days of leaving, assuming that they did not use up any FMLA leave.

Frequently Asked Questions About Shingles

What is Shingles?

Shingles, also called herpes zoster, is a painful rash caused by the reactivation of dormant virus in your body. There are two types of shingles:

Herpes zoster. This disease causes small blisters that erupt on one side of the body first. The rash will appear as red-brown spots with raised dots at the center. They may be raised and wrinkled or smooth and flat. After five days, they usually fade away.

This disease causes small blisters that erupt on one side of the body first. The rash will appear as red-brown spots with raised dots at the center. They may be raised and wrinkled or smooth and flat. After five days, they usually fade away. Herpetic neuralgia. This disorder can cause blisters and/or an area of raised scar tissue called nodules above the joint where a nerve root enters the spinal cord. It has no symptoms.


How Common Is Shingles?

The incidence of shingles varies from year to year but it can affect anywhere from 2% to 20%.

Does Everyone Get Shingles?

No, not everyone who gets shingles develops a fever, rash, or other signs and symptoms. When you get shingles, about 1 in 4 people who do develop a rash will have fever. However, this is only true if you are exposed to the disease.

Can I Stop Getting Shingles?

Most likely not. The immune system can still recognize certain viruses as being dangerous, such as flu, hepatitis C, or HIV, even after you stop having contact with them. Participants were randomly assigned into three groups, each consisting of 30 individuals, each receiving 1 hour per week of either resistance training (RT; n = 30), high intensity interval training (HIIT; n = 30) or no intervention group (control; n = 30). text:
What are the symptoms of MS and how do I know if it is affecting me?

Is there a cure for Multiple Sclerosis (MS)? If so, what treatments are available?

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system attacks its own nervous system. There are two main types of MS: relapsing-remitting (RRM), and secondary progressive (SP). RRM is characterized by flare-ups, often with severe pain, fatigue, weakness, numbness or tingling in parts of your brain and spinal cord that control movement. SP affects people over 50 years old, usually slowly but sometimes painfully. It can have no obvious physical symptoms, such as muscle stiffness. It starts off like SP, but over time you may get worse symptoms and eventually lose your ability to walk or speak, or develop other problems. For more information about the three forms of MS, visit our Fact Sheet on the four basic types of multiple sclerosis.

Do children with MS have seizures? Are they at increased risk of other neurologic diseases later in life?

Yes. Children who begin to show signs of MS in their early teens and remain symptomatic into adulthood tend to be diagnosed with RRM rather than SP. Seizures are a common feature of both RRM and SP, although they occur less frequently during SP. However, this does not mean that children without seizures do not experience other neurological problems, particularly as they grow older. Many kids and young adults with MS experience other symptoms that make them feel very different from others. They may also suffer from depression, irritability, difficulty concentrating, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), anxiety disorders, or substance abuse. Because some symptoms of MS may appear differently between subtypes, it is important to learn how to distinguish between SP and RRM before trying to manage any of these conditions independently. For more information about epilepsy, visit the Epilepsy Foundation.


Are there treatment options for patients with MS?

There are currently no proven therapies for treating MS, nor is there a drug approved to treat it. Currently there are several medications used to slow or stop disease progression. These include corticosteroids for SP and interferon beta for RRM.

A: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disorder of the nervous system that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord. It can cause problems with movement, balance and coordination. MS affects about 2 million people worldwide. The disease begins during childhood or adolescence and usually progresses slowly over time. However, if you have the condition more than 20 years before your symptoms begin, an earlier diagnosis may help protect you from complications and make treatment easier. As long as there are no other causes for your symptoms, early testing can be helpful to determine how serious your illness is and whether further tests might be needed. Some things to look at include: Your family history

Your physical exam — especially when someone has a seizure or changes in their vision

Your medical records — including lab results, X-rays or MRIs

The medications your doctor prescribed to treat your symptoms

If you've had any recent infections, such as flu, meningitis or strep throat

What should I do if my child has been diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS)?

What happens after a child is identified with MS? What types of care will they receive?

There's no cure for MS but treatments can improve some of the symptoms. Most children who get MS in infancy survive into adulthood, although many don't fully recover completely. Many kids who develop MS later in life need special care because many factors affect their ability to function safely. For example: They're sometimes less able to move around properly because of weakness in their legs and arms

They often need support to stand up, walk or use a wheelchair

When they first start using a wheelchair, they may not be able to reach high enough to get off easily

Children may experience developmental delays, which may require extra attention from caregivers or even specialized services, like speech therapy

How do doctors diagnose MS?

Doctors perform several different kinds of diagnostic tests and procedures to confirm the diagnosis. These may include: Blood test: This lets them see if antibodies called beta-amyloid proteins build up in your body. Researchers think this process may play a role in causing memory loss, seizures and other neurological problems. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): A CT scan shows a picture of the inside of your head. This image helps show where damage occurs, for instance in areas that control movement and thinking skills. text:
In the United States, people are increasingly coming to understand that holistic health care can be an effective, cost-effective option for people in need. A growing number of studies have shown the effectiveness of this approach. The National Institute of Health (NIH) has stated: "The evidence demonstrates significant improvements with a combination of lifestyle changes, dietary interventions, and psychosocial therapies."

Although the term "holistic" may not have been around before the 1970s, the concept of "holistic health" emerged during the last decade of the 19th century when physicians began using the term to describe their medical practices. By using this label, they were able to refer to a group of health care providers who shared common principles — such as prevention and early detection — based on careful examination and analysis of individuals' bodies, rather than relying solely on clinical tests. In fact, many medical schools still use this terminology today.

While there was no formal definition at first, physicians soon recognized that certain aspects of traditional and alternative medicine would benefit patients but lacked scientific proof and/or were dangerous or ineffective in treating specific conditions. The term "holistic" refers specifically to those approaches that are rooted in natural science and offer real solutions to human problems through physical, mental, emotional, spiritual, or other means.

What are some examples of holistic health care in practice?

Holistic health centers exist everywhere from suburban backyards to large urban hospitals. Some provide treatments such as acupuncture, chiropractic adjustment, homeopathy, massage therapy, nutrition counseling, nutritional supplements, yoga, meditation, reiki, tai chi, deep breathing, reflexology, body work, and more, while others focus on the promotion of social connections or the healing power of plants, minerals, herbs, crystals, minerals, and more.

Some holistic health practitioners also specialize in a particular treatment area, such as naturopathic medicine, herbalism, osteopathic medicine, acupressure, homeopathics, massage therapy, hypnotherapy, or acupuncture.

How can I get started in holistic health care?

There are plenty of resources available online to learn about healthy living and how to find an appropriate practitioner. Here are three good places to start:

MyHealthyPal offers free and affordable information to help you make informed decisions about your healthcare. It includes the Healthy Living Index, which ranks health care providers by overall rating; ratings of the quality of care provided; and a database where you can search providers

My colleagues have a lot of experience treating patients with MS who have had major traumatic brain injuries (TBI). The most common problem is damage to the optic nerve. This damage can occur when a person is knocked down or falls from a high place; it's called a concussion. Other symptoms include headaches, loss of vision, dizziness, disorientation, nausea, vomiting, weakness or numbness, tingling in parts of the body, depression, memory problems, changes in personality, difficulty speaking and understanding speech, anxiety, concentration difficulties, sleep disturbances, blurred vision, seizures, lack of coordination, and more. MMS is not a cure for MS, but it can be used as an adjunct therapy for people with the disease.

The treatment may also help ease the pain associated with MS.

How MMS works

You may have heard that a liquid form of MMS called Exsero is effective in treating MS symptoms. But what exactly does MMS do? And are there any side effects?

What is MMS?

MMS (melamine monohydrate) is a medical product made from salt water and magnesium sulfate. It's been approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), which means you can buy it without a prescription.

It was originally developed as a treatment for cystic fibrosis. The FDA says the chemical compounds in melamine work on the same mechanism as certain other drugs — namely blocking toxic substances produced during the process of breaking down collagen in your body. Melamine also kills bacteria and viruses.

Melamine may also reduce or eliminate inflammation in the joints, skin, and heart muscles.

When taken orally, MMS causes no known side effects. When given intravenously, it causes gastrointestinal irritation and possibly vomiting. In high doses, however, MMS can cause serious and life-threatening problems.

According to research done at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, MMS may cause:

Kidney failure

Nausea

Irritation of the bladder

In rare cases, kidney damage has resulted in death. This occurs when someone who takes too much MMS consumes too large quantities over time.

Most people should avoid taking higher amounts than prescribed because they could lead to significant health complications.

Who uses MMS?

People with multiple sclerosis are treated differently based on their disease severity. Some take oral medications like prednisone or interferon, while others use muscle relaxers or anti-inflammatory medication. People with less severe forms of the disease may take different combinations of these treatments.

Some experts say MMS might even be more helpful for some patients compared to traditional therapies such as steroids. Others disagree.

One study found that about 40 percent of MS patients using oral steroids showed improvement in fatigue. Of those treated with MMS, only 20 percent experienced relief from fatigue. However, several studies suggest that MMS reduces the duration of fatigue and makes people feel better overall.

INTRODUCTION Multiple sclerosis (MS), also known as demyelinating polyneuropathy, is an inflammatory disease affecting the nervous system. It occurs in more than 1 million Americans every year and is one of the leading causes of disability worldwide. MS affects nearly 10 percent of adults aged 60 years or older and almost 7 percent of children younger than 2 years old [1]. More than half of these individuals have been diagnosed by age 65 [2]. Although there are no cures for this devastating neurodegenerative disorder, patients can significantly reduce their symptoms through proper medical treatment [3-5] and lifestyle changes such as exercise, diet, and weight loss [6,7]. The prevalence of MS varies widely from country to country and across socioeconomic status. The majority of patients live in high income countries while about 40 percent reside in low income countries [8]. Most studies suggest that the prevalence of MS is lower in women compared to men but is similar in both sexes. In fact, women tend to be twice as likely to develop MS after age 50 than are men [9]. Currently, MS is estimated to affect approximately 4.4 million persons in the U.S. alone [10], with about 5 million new cases annually in the United States and some estimates suggesting that at least 20 percent of American residents may have MS [11]. While most MS patients exhibit considerable improvement upon initial diagnosis, most experience substantial relapse within five years [12]. Furthermore, MS has been shown to correlate with several factors including depression and health behaviors, which often lead to increased risk of mortality [13-17]. There is now compelling evidence to support the concept that MS may result from various underlying conditions that impair brain function and lead to the development of MS [18]. This hypothesis was first proposed in 1988 based on clinical observations showing that those with MS exhibited fewer cognitive functions as well as poorer memory and attention than controls [19]. However, other researchers have suggested that several of these behavioral abnormalities could be related to fatigue rather than impairment in cognition [20-22]. Therefore, it remains unclear whether these findings reflect true biological differences between the two populations or if they represent other underlying factors associated with MS [23]. Several studies have investigated the relationship between sleep and MS, and although some studies have found conflicting results, a few findings do seem

Can I donate my body to science?

It is illegal in many states to use a donor's body for research without informed consent from the person who donated it. Most states require an advance written consent or an oral consent form that includes information about potential risks to the donor (such as infection). There are some exceptions: Some state laws allow people to donate organs after death if they have given full written consent to do so; some may also allow partial or no written consent; some permit transplantation even when a living person cannot be found; some states allow organ donations in cases where a deceased relative could not give permission because he or she lacked health insurance coverage or was too ill at time of death to understand what was being asked of them; some provide exemptions for specific types of donation (e.g., for those whose kidneys or hearts were removed for research); some permit organ donations even when the dead person is unable to sign a document allowing his or her organs for research; and some allow donors to waive all legal rights to privacy regarding medical records concerning their donor status.


What happens to a donor's organs after they die?

The National Organ Transplant Act requires that all human cadavers be cremated or buried before they are donated to science or used for scientific experimentation. The remaining tissues are typically sent through either bone marrow transplants or autologous blood products to patients with diseases such as leukemia, lymphoma, myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), or multiple myeloma. Occasionally, stem cell therapy is performed on selected cadavers to treat cancer or other conditions. All organs must meet certain criteria established by federal law. In some instances, the recipient needs only one kidney, heart, lung, or liver but in others three or more organs are needed. A patient usually receives up to four livers per year depending on age, condition, and severity of illness. In the case of advanced kidney failure, kidney recipients receive two kidneys per day.

When are people legally responsible for me?

In most states, a person has the right to choose how to dispose of tissue that they gave voluntarily. However, this does not mean that they need never pay taxes on their gifts, nor does it make it okay to sell or give away material taken from them without their knowledge or consent. If someone else uses your remains in violation of these rules, you can sue them in small claims court

This study was approved by the local research ethics committee and written informed consent was obtained from all participants before the commencement of the trial (Supplementary Table 1). Written informed consent was also obtained for patients undergoing chemotherapy. The protocol was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines, and the study complied with UK National Health Service guidance on ethical conduct at research sites. All clinical investigations were carried out under full scientific and institutional review board approval.

Study design

The trial was a randomised, double-blind, placebo controlled trial designed to assess the efficacy of an investigational product comprising LNG-F-2M as part of a combination treatment compared with a placebo in lung cancer patients with stage 3/4 metastasis or high risk of relapse who are not eligible for surgical resection (stage 5–9) (see Supplementary Table 2 available online). A total of 60 patients were enrolled, of whom 45 completed follow-up assessments. Patients were randomly assigned into two groups: Group 1 received a single dose of 30 mg/kg LNG-F-2M; Group 2 received a single dose of 15 mg/kg LNG-F-2M followed by 10 mg/kg folic acid once daily. Study drug was supplied by Sigma Diagnostics (Stratford-on-Avon, United Kingdom). Participants provided written informed consent before participation and the study was registered at www.clinicaltrials.gov as NCT00008181. The trial was conducted in accordance with the Good Clinical Practice Guidelines for Human Research, UK.

Patients and interventions

Participants were recruited between April 2012 and July 2013 through the Cancer Research UK community medicine clinics, general practice services and secondary care organisations. Eligible participants were adults diagnosed with lung cancer presenting with stage 3/4 metastases and high risk of relapsing. The following eligibility criteria were used: age 18 years or over; good general health; stable lifestyle including regular physical activity; no history of smoking; adequate diet (≥5 g/day carbohydrate, ≥1.7 g/day protein), moderate alcohol intake (<6 g/week); a BMI of 22 kg/m2 or less than 25 kg/m2; blood pressure <140 mm Hg; serum creatinine concentration <10 µmol/L; normal renal function; no previous surgery; and no known adverse reaction to study drug.

In addition to the fact that all meat is not created equal, we also need to look at the environmental impact of each type of meat in order to better understand how we can best use them for our health and well-being. A review of 16 different studies found that red meats like beef have a significant environmental footprint due to their large amounts of water used per pound (approximately 1,500 gallons), nitrogen fertilizers used as fertilizer on pastureland and land used for grazing livestock, as well as carbon emissions from fossil fuels.

While the global demand for beef has doubled over the past 50 years, this increase doesn't mean that we should be eating more beef. Instead, it means that we are consuming less beef than we did 50 years ago. In reality, when it comes to meat consumption there is no such thing as "too much." We need to focus on how much meat people actually eat rather than how many pounds they put down on the plate.

As an example, consider what happens with dairy products and meat alternatives. According to the USDA's National Nutrient Database for Standard Reference:

Dairy

Fats

Seeds and nuts


Grains

Vegetables

The Environmental Working Group recently released a report entitled "Where Fish Meets Food," which concluded that while seafood may be healthy and delicious, it contains higher levels of contaminants than fish from farms where antibiotics are routinely given to farm animals to boost growth rates, and even arsenic in some cases. If you aren't already making the switch away from eating fish that come out of factory farming, then now might be a good time to start!

For more information about the negative impacts of animal agriculture, check out these links below:

What you can do – Avoid Meat

When it comes to avoiding meat, I believe everyone should learn to cook without killing any living creatures. By learning to prepare your meals from scratch every day, you will reduce the amount of time you spend purchasing processed foods and thereby the amount of greenhouse gas emitted by your food production system. As mentioned above, even small changes in how we consume food can have a huge impact on the environment. Making the transition from pork to chicken or using tofu instead of ground beef can both reduce greenhouse gases and decrease energy costs. For anyone who prefers plant based protein sources like chickpeas, black beans, tempeh, and edamame, vegan cooking techniques and recipes can help you cut down on your meat consumption and save money too.

That's why I have been a strong advocate for raising the drinking age to 21 in this country as well as around the world. Because when teens start drinking before they are ready it can lead them down a dangerous path that ultimately puts their health at risk.

While it is true that most teenage drinkers do not get drunk on an everyday basis, studies show that about 40 percent of them eventually drink alcohol heavily enough to cause problems with driving or other activities that put themselves and others at risk.

This is a sobering reality because young people who begin drinking during adolescence tend to be more likely than older teenagers to binge drink (i.e., consume five or more drinks within two hours) or use drugs while intoxicated — and to become dependent on these substances. In fact, in recent years many states have passed laws restricting access to alcohol by those under 21 years old.

These are critical issues to address because if we don't protect our youth from getting behind the wheel impaired then we may end up causing more harm to our own communities through accidents and injuries caused by teen drivers.

Alcohol-impaired driving kills over 3,600 Americans each year, more than motor vehicle crashes and gun homicides combined. And although only 2.1 percent of all traffic deaths involve alcohol-related accidents in California, these accidents account for nearly half of all fatalities among underage drivers, including more than 400 lives lost annually. It also has tragic impacts in our families: One study found that one out of every eight children in the U.S. will suffer some form of maltreatment as a result of substance abuse.

Our efforts must go beyond increasing penalties for minors who drive under the influence of alcohol, because these measures alone are unlikely to prevent the harms caused by excessive drinking. That's because there are too many factors at work at any given time that contribute to risky behavior. For example, teenagers with lower incomes, limited education and less stability in their lives often face increased challenges in finding employment or financial resources to pay for alcohol, making it even harder for them to resist the temptation.
