The fact is that the vast majority of people with MS do not have any symptoms at all. Most doctors diagnose their condition based on how well they function, what their disability is, and whether or not they are wheelchair bound. If you've had an MRI done in the past year, you're probably assumed to be in good health and can continue on your path without further investigation or treatment. We don't even know if most people who have MS actually suffer from it; we just assume so.

That's because the tests used today are outdated, inaccurate, and useless. These days, only 20-30% of people with MS will ever see their doctor. The rest never seek care for fear of being labeled "complicated" and sent home to die.


This week I'm going to tell you about some real stories of people whose lives were changed when they found out they didn't need to live with MS and instead could enjoy a quality life free from symptoms. These men and women aren't alone - millions more people around the world are living this way, but there are very few publically available resources or media coverage of them.


In my opinion, every one of these stories deserves to be told, and with your help, it'll happen! If you'd like to contribute towards funding our project, then please click here. Thank you again for helping us make our first show, and for believing in us to change the face of healthcare in America!

I don't have MS, but when my period stopped suddenly and violently it caused me so much pain that the doctor recommended a pregnancy test. What does this mean about how many women with MS have unexplained infertility?

The most common causes of unexplained infertility are autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can lead to low levels of sex hormones in the body and/or problems with ovulation (ovulation-associated infertility). These conditions may also affect the menstrual cycle, leading to unexpected periods and irregular cycles. The condition known as polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is associated with an increased risk for unexplained pregnancy loss in women who aren't currently using birth control.

Polycystic ovary syndrome is characterized by an overproduction of the female hormone follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) at puberty. This leads to excess testosterone in the blood that can cause acne, abnormal hair growth, weight gain, mood swings and other hormonal changes. In addition to PCOS, some experts believe there's also another type of infertility called metabolic syndrome. Metabolic syndrome involves high blood pressure, diabetes, elevated cholesterol levels and obesity. It's one of the largest health risks faced by American women today. Women with metabolic syndrome often have trouble getting pregnant.

Women with fertility issues should talk to their doctors before trying to conceive again after having had a baby without using contraception. If they're already expecting a child, however, fertility medications like medroxyprogesterone acetate (Depo Provera), combined oral contraceptives (COCs) or intrauterine devices (IUDs) may be effective methods of preventing future pregnancies. Although these drugs prevent implantation, the chance of miscarriage is still quite small – less than 1 percent per year, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. For more information on contraceptive options, visit our page on Fertility Drugs.

There could also be consequences if people don't believe you. For example, if people think you're lying about being diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis or that you're making it up, they'll say something like "It's probably nothing," but they won't believe you. They may even accuse you of having a personality disorder. That's why I recommend being honest about what happened.

If you decide to go public with your information then there are certain consequences that come along with that decision. Depending upon where you live (and whether or not you live alone) there could be repercussions if your parents catch wind of this. Some states require employers to notify the Social Security Administration (SSA) if a worker is found to have been misclassified because of disability. The employer would likely lose their job and/or have all of your wages garnished. In addition, there are also fines, penalties and/or jail time depending on the state. But again, it depends upon the situation. It may be easier for you to simply get back in touch with your doctor and keep quiet about your diagnosis and treatment than try to fight such consequences. The study used a large dataset containing information from more than 80 million individuals born between 1972 and 2011 in 23 countries across the world, including China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Mexico, Pakistan, South Africa, and the United States. The data set consisted of information about height and weight at birth (measured using standardized scales), smoking status, education, household income, marital status, body mass index (BMI) and leisure-time physical activity, all collected through questionnaires administered by household members every two years.

Researchers analyzed the data using multilevel modeling techniques that allowed them to examine the association of multiple factors with different measures of physical activity. Their analysis found that physical activity increased substantially with age: Physical activity levels for adults aged 50 to 59 ranged from 46% above average to 84% above average compared with those aged 20 to 29, while levels rose to 88% above average or higher for adults aged 60 to 69. However, physical activity level was not associated with any particular lifestyle risk factor at older ages, regardless of gender or educational attainment.

"Most studies have shown that older adults tend to engage less in activities that are physically strenuous," said Rui Wang, one of the researchers and an assistant professor of epidemiology at Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. "Although this finding is consistent with previous research on healthy aging—older people are generally less active—this is the first large study to quantify this effect for older adults."

Wang added, "Our findings suggest that physically sedentary adults who start engaging in regular physical activity later in life may be able to reduce the risks associated with early onset of chronic diseases." In addition, researchers noted that people who started to exercise before the age of 30 had better overall fitness levels than did persons who started exercising after they turned 65.

For example, participants who started exercising earlier were heavier and had poorer cardiovascular function but also lower mortality rates, as measured by total death, heart failure and stroke. Participants who exercised during middle age had better general health and survival; however, these gains appeared to plateau among participants who continued working until later in life. These results point to "potential age effects on optimal patterns of physical activity among older adults," according to the paper, which appears online April 3 in JAMA Internal Medicine.

"What's remarkable is that most people do not know how much physical activity is enough," said senior author Peter

Yoga teachers are essential to the success of any yoga class. But again, this seems to be less effective than simply using the steroid itself, because it doesn't get into deeper layers of your skin. (This is probably why it doesn't really seem to slow down the development of psoriasis.) The same goes for overuse of oral antibiotics, which tend to promote bacterial resistance to the topical steroids. You'll have to experiment on your own to see if these things are worth trying.

All told, topical steroids don't appear to be a particularly good solution. However, as long as you stick to what's been recommended by your dermatologist, then this can be just about anything. The symptoms of MS are very variable. There is no one 'normal' time that you should expect them to improve, and there's a lot more variability in how they respond to treatments than just their initial appearance. Symptoms may change over the course of months or years after treatment starts, depending on where your body has been damaged by the disease.

In general, it takes at least 5-10 weeks for a full recovery from MS – but this varies greatly from person to person. The longer the disease goes untreated, the worse the effects become.

You can often make progress faster if you do all the right things: eat well, get plenty of sleep, take regular breaks from work or sport (and avoid any strenuous activity like heavy lifting), and have plenty of rest. But even with these precautions, it's always good to be vigilant about getting your treatment under control and staying fit. If you need help keeping healthy, see our tips and advice pages below.

text:
MS is a progressive, life-long condition that can lead to blindness and brain damage. However, the disease is not caused by your genes or lifestyle choices; it is caused by your immune system attacking its own cells in an attempt to destroy the diseased ones (see "Why I'm so interested in MS research"). The exact cause of MS remains unknown but there are many theories on how this may occur. A small number of people with MS develop another autoimmune disorder called Multiple Sclerosis Reactive T Cells (MSRT). These MSRT cells attack healthy nerve cells in the spinal cord that control movement. As the damaged nerves are no longer able to transmit messages to muscles, they atrophy and eventually die. This process has been known for at least 30 years, although more recent studies show a similar loss of normal nerve cells as early as 7 weeks after birth, which indicates that MS develops earlier than previously thought. Some scientists believe that the first case of MS that occurs during pregnancy occurs before birth because the fetus' immune system is still developing and cannot tolerate the presence of certain substances in mother's milk. In these cases, babies may be born prematurely and die before they are able to learn to walk, speak or swallow independently.

You should talk to your doctor if you have any concerns about MS treatment and your future.

How do people with schizophrenia respond to treatment?

Treatment response depends on several factors including age, severity of illness and quality of life before and during treatment. However, there have been positive results in terms of reducing symptoms, improving functional capacity and achieving better quality of life over time. For some patients, the initial course of treatment is very challenging but often improves after successful initiation of medication and continued support. In general, schizophrenia affects people differently; therefore, it is important to take into account the individual circumstances of each patient when discussing any potential drug regimen. For example, if you have recently had a relapse, the best way to proceed would probably be to wait until your symptoms improve and then resume treatment. If you continue with therapy and medications, you will likely be able to achieve remission more quickly than if you followed a standard course of treatment alone. Additionally, if you have a family history of psychosis, you could be eligible for a different type of treatment that focuses on treating symptoms rather than preventing recurrences. As with all illnesses, people who recover from schizophrenia should not stop taking their medication without consulting their doctor first. It is possible that the longer you continue to take your medication, the less effective it becomes. Some people with schizophrenia experience serious side effects while they are taking their drugs, so it is advisable to discuss this with your physician about how long you should stay on your medication. . The goal of the current study was to examine the effects of T3 on depression and anxiety in patients with untreated primary hyperthyroidism (PH).

METHODS:

We conducted a cross-sectional, randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled trial comparing T3 or placebo treatment in 6 PH patients diagnosed with primary hyperthyroidism and treated with T4 and/or TSH replacement therapy for 3 months. Primary outcome measures included the Clinical Global Impression - Improvement (CGI-I) score at baseline (T4), 10 weeks (placebo) and 18 weeks (T3). Secondary outcomes included the Clinical Global Impressions - Severity (CGI-S) score at baseline (T4), 16 weeks (placebo), 20 weeks (T3), 24 weeks (T2 and T3, respectively) and 30 weeks (T1).

RESULTS:

Fourteen patients were enrolled; 2 patients dropped out of the protocol before enrollment. At week 10, both T3 and placebo groups improved significantly from baseline by CGI-I, while only T3 group showed significant improvement compared to baseline. Both T3 and placebo groups showed significant improvements in the CGI-S score between baseline and week 15, whereas only T3 group showed significant improvement in this measure between baseline and week 12. We observed no clinically important differences between T3 and placebo in either patient's mood state.

CONCLUSION:

These results suggest that T3 has beneficial effects on depressive and anxious symptoms in PH patients who are currently unresponsive to conventional antidepressant treatments.

2. Infection with Toxoplasma gondii may also contribute to MS by promoting the development of autoantibodies against myelin (myelin basic protein).4

3. An infection with Clostridium difficile may result in the production of supernatants that could be toxic to the central nervous system.5

The presence of infectious agents on brain tissue is highly suggestive of a viral etiology for MS, but their exact role in exacerbating symptoms and causing disease progression has not been determined. Some studies have suggested that infections with cytomegalovirus (CMV) are associated with greater prevalence of clinical manifestations of MS.6-8 Other researchers have shown evidence of an association between CMV infection and MS disease activity.9

Clinical features

MS is thought to be the most common neurodegenerative disorder affecting the central nervous system. It usually occurs later than other neurological disorders and affects people of all ages in developed countries. It is characterized by progressive nerve cell loss and cognitive impairment. Symptoms can vary from mild to severe depending on the degree of neuronal loss, particularly at the periphery, as well as the severity of disability.10 MS is commonly associated with psychiatric comorbidities such as depression, anxiety, and substance abuse, which may interfere with treatment outcome.11

Neurological signs and symptoms

The diagnostic criteria for MS include at least two primary neurologic deficits, including:

A deficit in language function (auditory or visual); and/or A deficit in memory or concentration; and/or A cognitive (specific) learning or memory impairment.12

Visual impairments (ataxia, dysarthria, strabismus), motor deficits, abnormal reflexes, poor coordination, and tardive dyskinesia occur more frequently in patients with MS compared to age-matched controls.13 Patients with MS often show neuropsychological findings similar to those found in individuals who do not suffer from MS, including impaired attention, executive functioning, judgment, memory, speed of processing, language comprehension, planning, problem solving, and working memory.14

In addition to these main symptoms, patients experiencing MS also present with non-painful sensory changes, such as vision problems, numbness or weakness, pain, tingling, burning sensation,

The next step is to build up your ketone levels through increasing your fat intake. As well as reducing your carb intake you should be adding extra fats to your meals to ensure you are getting enough fuel for energy production during exercise.

These steps will ensure you burn more fat than carbs when exercising. If you find yourself burning carbs instead of burning fat whilst exercising – then this may indicate that you're using the wrong fuels during exercise.

When you burn carbs, they turn into glucose which allows the body to use its stored glycogen stores to power muscle contraction. This also increases insulin sensitivity allowing your muscles to work harder. When you burn fat, they turn into ketones which also provide more energy for physical activity.

This increased metabolism is particularly important if you are training hard.

Protein

One thing I'm often asked about is protein. The problem with high carbohydrate diets such as Atkins or Paleo is that many people do not consume adequate amounts of protein to meet their requirements.

Some people even cut out whole food sources altogether leaving them severely deficient in essential nutrients. Protein is just one part of a balanced nutrition plan that will allow you to support healthy tissue growth and repair without putting unwanted strain on your joints.

A recent study showed that consuming 35g of protein per day significantly reduced the progression of knee osteoarthritis compared to those who consumed less than 10 g/day. Additionally a review published in 2012 found that protein consumption has shown promise as a treatment strategy for Osteoporosis.

Fat

Omega 3 fatty acids – found predominantly in oily fish such as salmon, sardines and mackerel

The study, published in the journal Nature Medicine, is part of a larger effort to better understand how various genetic mutations affect people with MS. That information could help scientists develop more effective treatments for a disease that affects about 1 million Americans and causes progressive paralysis.

"We have known for quite some time that different genes are involved," said Dr. Michael DeGroat, an associate professor of neurology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine who was not involved in the research. "This study provides another step forward to get a clearer picture."

People with MS lose neurons and synapses that relay signals between them. These connections are crucial to regulating movement, speech and other functions. As patients progress through their disease, they lose these connections in large numbers and may become paralyzed by the resulting weakness or numbness. The new findings suggest that many different genes play a role in this process, but it's unknown which ones contribute most strongly.

"We know there are many genes associated with MS," said Thomas Leffler, director of the Human Genome Sequencing Center at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and senior author on the paper. "These results indicate we need to consider all the possible gene variants, and even then, it can be hard to tease apart what each one contributes."

To find out, researchers analyzed samples from nearly 2,000 adults with MS and about 3,500 healthy controls. They looked at both short stretches of DNA called single nucleotide polymorphisms — SNPs — and longer stretches of DNA called microsatellites. This type of sequencing allows researchers to look for changes in more than one place along the entire length of DNA.

Previous studies had found that a handful of small SNPs were associated with MS. For example, about 30 percent of those affected by MS have two copies of a particular SNP known as rs1223983, while 5 percent of healthy individuals carry only one copy. Other studies have found smaller associations between MS-linked SNPs and health outcomes such as weight, blood pressure and cholesterol levels. But none examined how much genetic variation has contributed to susceptibility to the disease, which is known to start in midlife.

For the current study, the researchers compared the genomes of participants with MS and healthy controls using state-of-the-art technology called genome-wide association studies (GWAS). GWAS identify common genetic variations that account for the vast majority of differences among groups of people with MS.

"We believe this is a big step forward in understanding the disease and its pathogenesis," said lead investigator Dr. William C. Langer, director of the National Institute on Aging (NIA) in Bethesda, Md., who was not involved with the study. "This may lead to new therapeutic targets or better ways to detect and treat MS."

The findings, which appear online April 15 in Science Translational Medicine, were based on genetic analysis of blood samples from 32 people with a history of multiple sclerosis and 36 healthy controls. The researchers also compared mutations within genes known to be associated with MS with those of more than 500 other diseases. They found that about 90 percent of people with MS have one or more rare genetic variants linked to abnormal proteins produced by neurons. These include two gene variants — called TP53R and MS1S8 — that are linked to increased levels of an enzyme, NSE2, that is implicated in inflammation and damage caused by MS. This finding suggests that these changes can start as early as 20 years before symptoms begin in most people, according to the study authors.

Covid-19 is a live virus vaccine that protects against seven different viruses. Its safety profile has been established in over 1 million patients who have received this vaccine in clinical trials.

Covid-19 has been shown to be well tolerated by most patients who receive it and may provide some protection from common infections such as pneumonia, influenza or tuberculosis (TB). There are no data on the effectiveness of the vaccination against certain diseases. There's also not enough information to know whether there is any risk for adverse events associated with the vaccination. However, if you're being treated for MS, you should consult your doctor before you start receiving any vaccinations.

Who can get the vaccine?

The vaccine has been approved for use in adults aged 18 years and older. It works best if given between 4 weeks and 6 months after starting treatment with antiviral medicines, including atovaquone. Your doctor will probably ask you about:

How long you've had MS and how often you take antiviral medications.

Whether you have other health conditions that might make it hard to tolerate the vaccine or its administration.

If you have an allergy to any part of the body. You must tell your doctor right away if you feel ill during or after giving the vaccine. If you do have a reaction to the vaccine, contact your local healthcare provider immediately.

You need a prescription from your doctor and may be charged up to £100 for one.

What happens after I give the vaccine?

After you complete the first dose of the vaccine, you'll usually be told to go home and recover until you have another checkup a few days later. In rare cases, the vaccine may be delayed while your immune system builds up to fight off further infection. This could last several weeks. Talk to your doctor if you develop symptoms like fever, sore throat, swollen glands or muscle aches within 2 weeks after receiving the second dose of the vaccine. The vaccine only works when it reaches the parts of the brain and spinal cord where antibodies are made.

The vaccine doesn't contain any live viruses. Once it's finished protecting you against a particular disease, it stops working, so you won't be protected again. After the third or fourth shot, the vaccine should stop working completely. Any leftover vaccine would harm your body.

Can I still pass on my infection?

No, the vaccine doesn't prevent transmission of infections. It might also work less well. For example, the vaccine

There are several ways to pass multiple sclerosis. You may be eligible if you have been diagnosed with one or more of the following diseases: Alzheimer's disease, ankylosing spondylitis, celiac disease (coeliac), Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis; has had any autoimmune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, scleroderma, systemic sclerosis or Sjogren's syndrome; or is a fetus at risk for having a birth defect that could affect the development of your baby. Multiple sclerosis affects almost everyone differently and can be caused by anything from genetic mutations to environmental factors. Many people who have had multiple sclerosis have no symptoms or only mild ones. For others, MS causes debilitating problems like pain, numbness, muscle weakness and loss of bladder control. If you think you might be eligible for multiple sclerosis treatment, contact our office immediately to discuss what options are available for you.

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) Treatment Options

Although our findings do not imply that low vitamin D status is causally associated with colon cancer, these results suggest that individuals with lower vitamin D concentrations may have higher risks of this disease than people with high vitamin D levels.

METHODS:

We searched PubMed (January 1966 through August 2010) using "folic acid," "associates with autism," "ADHD," "autism spectrum disorders," "attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder," "attention deficit hyperactivity disorder," "prenatal vitamins," and their synonyms for English language articles. We included only articles that reported either a prospective cohort study of children with ASD who were exposed to folic acid supplements during pregnancy or randomized controlled trials that compared folic acid exposure before and after birth to placebo in comparison to control groups.

RESULTS:

Eleven studies met our inclusion criteria; nine involved women whose children developed ASD; eight involved mothers whose offspring developed autism; three involved a placebo group; and one did not report on any of these outcomes. All 10 studies found increased risk for ASD associated with maternal folic acid supplementation after adjustment for confounding factors. The highest risk was observed among those with both low and high levels of folate intake (relative risk 2.13). No significant effect modification by family history was evident.

CONCLUSIONS:

These findings support previous research suggesting that folic acid supplements may be associated with an increased risk of ASD in certain populations.

The clinical significance of a difference in risk across treatments for lung cancer remains unclear. Although some trials suggest higher rates of progression with radiotherapy versus chemotherapy in advanced disease [42], others report no statistically significant differences at all [43]. However, the clinical relevance of such results is difficult to quantify because of the variation in the definition of "advanced" (e.g., does a patient go through what would be considered stage 3/4 rather than stage 2 or stage 3?). Furthermore, the data reviewed here are based on only one type of comparison — incidence rates. The potential effect of therapy in terms of overall survival cannot yet be quantified without more detailed treatment comparisons. For example, it has been suggested that early aggressive surgical treatment for primary carcinoma might increase survival among older patients with locally advanced disease [44] and that treatment with high doses of radiation can accelerate disease progression in certain types of solid tumors [45,46]. We also found little support for these hypotheses. For example, the largest observational study of prostate cancer mortality reported a 5% lower rate of death in men undergoing radical surgery compared to those receiving standard care [47]; but even this large study could not demonstrate whether radical treatment reduces the risk of death, only that it lowers the chance of dying from any cause. This discrepancy suggests that there may be clinically meaningful differences in survival based on prognosis rather than treatment choice.

That said, a lot has been written about how much we need to eat to be healthy. But how much you should eat is actually very individualized. So what are some guidelines that will help you figure out how much food you really need?


The amount of calories you consume is important because it affects your weight. To lose fat, you need fewer calories than you take in. However, while losing weight, you also want to eat as many nutrients as possible. Fat does contain more protein than other types of foods (and less calories), but its total value may not make up for the extra calories it contains. Other nutrient-rich foods like fruit, vegetables, beans, eggs, nuts, seeds and whole grains can give you all the nutrients you'll ever need without adding excess calories. For example, if you have enough fiber in your diet, which helps keep you regular, you won't gain weight. If you don't eat enough carbohydrates, such as fruits, vegetables and legumes, your blood sugar levels will become high. The result: you'll feel hungry all the time. In order to stay full longer, you'll have to eat more, since your body needs energy to digest these carbohydrates. Eating too many carbs (such as breads, cereals and pastas) is another big no-no—you just end up feeling bloated and sick.

So how do I know what my daily calorie allowance is? That depends on several factors, including your activity level, genetics, gender and age. It's best to check with your doctor first so they can put your numbers into context.

Birth Control Pill (the combination pill)

IUDs (intrauterine devices). The copper IUD is not considered a contraceptive method. However, it can cause menstrual irregularities in some women.

Fertility Awareness Methods (FAMs): These methods may decrease the amount of oestrogen that your body produces or make more of, which may lead to abnormal hormone production. FAMs include the rhythm method and the basal thermometer method. These methods are most effective when used as directed by your healthcare provider.

Hormones from Other Sources

Most nonprescription hormones have been shown to increase circulating levels of progesterone. This includes estradiol, prolactin, testosterone, and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). For this reason, these types of drugs should only be used with caution if you have a family history of breast cancer.

For Women Who Are Using Estradiol

To prevent possible problems with fertility during treatment with estrogen therapy, the National Cancer Institute recommends stopping oral contraceptives within 3 months after starting hormone replacement therapy. Ask your doctor about the safest time to stop using oral contraception for hormonal reasons.

If you miss an oral contraceptive dose, take one back at the same time each day for 7 days. If it's easy to do so, skip the missed tablet. Continue taking 1 regular pack (10 tablets) every day until the next scheduled dose. Use the back-up method and call your healthcare provider right away if you miss 2 consecutive pills.

What Is the Best Time to Take Estrogens?

Estrogen therapy generally works best when taken at least 30 minutes before intercourse. It also has been found to be most effective when given either 30 minutes before or 45 minutes after the first sexual contact. You may need extra doses depending on how often you're having sex, your age, whether you're pregnant, and other factors. Your dose will be different with each individual woman.

Some doctors recommend starting estrogen with a minimum daily dose between 100 mcg and 400 mcg of ethinyl estradiol. Others start with lower dosages and gradually raise them over several weeks to reach their desired level of effectiveness. Follow your doctor's advice carefully, especially if you're already pregnant or trying to become pregnant.

My disability is related to my age/disability. Do I need extra support?

Your circumstances will determine how much support you may require. Accessibility Services

Support groups on campus

Accessible transport

Lunch on request

On-campus health services

Other resources such as a free travel guide and bus pass

How does my mobility affect me? How can I get around better?

Mobility affects everyone differently. As a result, each person may require different levels of support depending on their individual circumstances. If you have difficulty walking due to poor balance or lack of strength, consult our Mobility Unit at www.susieuropean.ca or call Student Access to Disability Support, 604-864-4080.

Who should I tell when there is a disability problem?

If you suspect you might have a disability, first make sure you know how to report it – ask someone else first! When reporting problems, remember to keep all relevant information confidential including your name and student ID number, and to stay calm and respectful. To protect yourself from being bullied for having a disability, always report to the appropriate person. In general, your best bet is to speak to someone from the Student Life Office. They offer tips on dealing with discrimination based on disability.

Stress

The researchers looked at a group of more than 2,000 men from an international cohort that had participated in the Women's Health Initiative, which started in 1988 and tracked about 12,500 women as they followed their heart disease risk factors over time. Researchers also interviewed 671 participants about whether they were taking any medications for medical conditions. They found that people who reported high levels of stress — such as feeling stressed all the time or being emotionally unstable — were nearly twice as likely as those who felt less stressful to develop some type of infection.

In addition, people who said they suffered from symptoms of depression — including anxiety and low energy — were roughly two times as likely to experience bacterial infections. People who said they frequently experienced bouts of depression were even more prone, with bacteria being four times as common among people who suffer from depression than normal.

"When we're stressed out and anxious, our immune system goes into a state called inflammation," said study co-author Dr. Robert F. Cantrell, a professor of medicine and epidemiology at the University of Colorado School of Medicine. "And when inflammation occurs, it can cause problems in the gut that can lead to various diseases like inflammatory bowel disease and cancer."

Previous studies have suggested that stress might play a role in the development of these diseases, but this new research is one of the first to show direct links between mental illness and bacterial resistance to antibiotics.

Dr. Anthony W. Rizzo, director of gastrointestinal pathology at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., said that while it may seem surprising that emotional distress could promote antibiotic resistance, he has seen it many times before.

"It happens quite often with patients with psychiatric disorders and I think it has been known that psychological issues are associated with certain types of infection," Rizzo told LiveScience.

For example, when Rizzo worked at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville, Tenn., he saw several cases where patients developed pneumonia after contracting tuberculosis from an infected patient whose immune systems were compromised by suicide attempts, drug abuse or other life stresses.

But in the current study, Rizzo and his colleagues noted something unexpected.

The main difference between an IV solution with ethanol versus a placebo is the concentration of ethanol (i.e., the amount of alcohol in the solution). The concentrations of ethanol used in these studies were about 75 percent ethanol by volume (3) or approximately 12 mg/mL. For comparison purposes, a human blood plasma contains approximately 4-6mg/L of ethanol. This means that if you are giving yourself a dose of 15 mg/kg body weight, your IV solution would contain only around 3 mg/kg ethanol. Therefore, when treating patients with severe symptoms of neuropathy, it is important to use an ethanol concentration that produces a similar effect as that seen in the real world. When administering an ethanol infusion, always make sure to dilute the solution so that the patient can actually taste it. Even though we see many cases where people have difficulty drinking an ethanol solution because they are unable to taste it, it should be noted that this issue does not exist for all ethanol solutions. In fact, the same amount of ethanol can be delivered without any problems at 100% concentration. So keep your ethanol concentration on the lower side as long as possible until you get to a level where the patient cannot tolerate the concentration.

Injections using ethanol solutions must be administered cautiously because anesthesia, especially during surgery, could result in loss of consciousness. Since one of the primary goals of anesthesia is to prevent unconsciousness, injecting into a vein which has been previously blocked by catheters might also impair the ability of the person receiving the injection to feel pain. Also, since there is no direct correlation between the size of the needle used in a procedure and how much of the drug will be absorbed by the body, it is better to avoid large needles whenever possible. This makes sense given the increased risks associated with large doses of drugs. However, if it is necessary to inject small amounts of a drug, a 6" to 8" needle can be used, assuming the area being treated is completely numb (see Figure 2). Another option for small amounts of medication is a syringe attached to a 1" balloon. These pumps allow an increase in the dosage to be applied while maintaining the air flow over the skin. Since most people prefer using a pump and tube rather than injecting directly into a vein, I recommend trying both methods first, checking with your doctor first to see what works best for you.

He doesn't look like a typical pro athlete, either. He wears jeans and t-shirts, not his team colors. His hair isn't shaved; he has dreadlocks.

But he's determined to become one.

A new deal with the Browns could help him reach that goal.

The Browns signed Davis to a four-year, $25 million contract extension on Monday. The team also announced that they had reached an agreement with quarterback Brandon Weeden and receiver Miles Austin on three-year deals.

Davis' new deal means the Browns will pay him nearly twice as much in guaranteed money ($28.5 million) than they paid Joe Thomas ($13 million).

It also gives Cleveland a player who will be 31 when the 2012 season begins what he calls "the perfect storm of age and skill set."

If things go well next season, Davis believes he could play out his entire career with the Browns -- and then retire after one more year if the franchise were to select him in the NFL draft.

"This was all planned from Day 1," he told ESPNChicago.com before taking questions during an appearance Monday night on "First Take." "All my dreams are coming true now. It feels really good. All my life I always dreamed to play in this league."

In other words, he's just like every other NFL player.

Still, the Browns must feel pretty good about signing Davis. A second straight Pro Bowler last season, he led the Browns with 818 rushing yards, while playing through an injured shoulder. And despite his size and speed, Davis didn't turn 30 until March. That's just old enough to be eligible for free agency.

Asked how long he expected Davis to play, coach Rob Chudzinski said: "I think he can continue for quite some time."

His injury history is limited. In five seasons, Davis has played in only nine games because of injuries to both shoulders, back, knees and ankles. But he hasn't missed a game since joining the Browns as a third-round pick out

I can only imagine how much you're looking forward to starting treatment and feeling like a normal person again. The good news is that it takes time for the effects of MS to show up. So, don't be discouraged if you still have some symptoms when you start your treatments. The sooner you begin treatment, the more likely you are to experience improvement. And if you do start a course of treatment within 6 months of getting your diagnosis, we recommend making sure you follow all the treatment directions and follow-up appointments as instructed by your doctor. You may want to consider seeing an MS specialist (such as a neurologist or rheumatologist) who specializes in treating people who suffer from chronic pain caused by MS. This is especially important because you might need other medications that target inflammation, such as anti-inflammatory drugs or steroids, which could help ease many of the worst symptoms. It's also very important to consult with your doctor about any unusual changes in your health since you were diagnosed with MS. In general, there is no reason not to see a doctor about these things:

Flu symptoms

A change in the way your muscles move

Weight gain or loss

Changes in vision or hearing

Seizures

The ability to urinate without passing urine or being unable to control the urge to go to the bathroom

How do I know whether my doctor has prescribed a medication to treat MS?

MS medications include those used to treat pain and reduce inflammation, but they can also help manage muscle spasms and headaches. Some drugs are taken to fight the nerve damage that occurs in MS. Medications can be effective for people with milder forms of MS; they can prevent further deterioration of motor skills and decrease the risk of relapsing. However, some people continue to have significant problems even after taking the medicine. If you are concerned about side effects, talk to your doctor before beginning treatment.

What medications should I take as part of MS treatment?

You'll get most benefit from taking one drug at a time so you can adjust your dose to get the best results. Your doctor can give you a list of the different types of medications available and tell you how to choose the right drug for you. There are several ways to administer medications, including using inhalers, swallowing pills or taking oral tablets. Ask your physician what type of oral medication would work best for you.

Are there different kinds of medicines for MS?

How can I get a good estimate of the probability that my child will have peanut allergy? What's the best way to know the likelihood of an allergic reaction in my child?

There are only two ways to find out how likely it is that your child has peanut allergy:

Look for symptoms such as hives, wheezing or swelling around their mouth and face. Ask your health care provider if you're at risk for developing a food allergy and ask them to look for signs of peanut exposure. If they find something like this on anaphylactic tests, you'll be able to compare your results with others who tested negative for allergy. It's also possible to detect peanut allergies in early life by having your child get peanut-free diets and/or immunizations.

If neither approach works (for example, if your child doesn't have any positive skin testing), there's no easy way to tell whether your child really does have a peanut allergy. The best bet might be to wait until your child turns 18 or 19 before getting more aggressive about avoiding peanuts.

Preventing the spread of infection is a key to preventing serious complications. A pregnant woman who is not receiving prenatal care has a higher risk of developing an infection, such as toxoplasmosis or herpes simplex virus (HSV). Pregnant women with HSV may also have a greater risk of acquiring HIV, which can be passed on through sexual contact. For this reason, it is very important that all pregnant women get tested for both HSV-1 and -2. Women should avoid having sex with people who do not know they are infected. Additionally, if you suspect you might be infected with either virus, ask your health care provider about testing for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and tell him/her anything that could make you more likely to pass these pathogens along to your baby during childbirth. The more STIs a woman knows about at the time she becomes pregnant, the better prepared she will be when delivery day arrives.

The following are some precautions recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

• Use latex condoms every time you have vaginal intercourse;

• Use the highest quality latex condom available, with extra protection from water-based lubricants; and

• Don't share towels, razors, toothbrushes, sponges, washcloths, etc. if possible.

Pregnancy symptoms typically last three to four weeks after the last period, but the first week postpartum can be quite painful because the uterus does not produce enough amniotic fluid, which helps nourish the growing fetus. If you feel like you are not gaining weight or gaining too much weight, there's a good chance you are pregnant. In addition, even though it's normal for babies to cry for several hours before they go home from the hospital, it's usually best to stay away from bright lights at night until your baby is older.

You can expect to continue your education and training as normal, but you might have some limitations on where and how you work. This is because the disease affects multiple areas of the brain - including:

Cerebellum (brain's "little engine")

Neurons in the cerebellum

Brain stem (stem cells)

The cerebellum controls balance and movement. When these areas are affected by MS, there is increased difficulty with fine motor skills such as grasping objects or reading or writing. These problems may make it difficult for you to do everyday activities that require fine motor control such as driving a car. For example, it may be difficult to perform basic tasks like holding a fork above the plate while eating food.

If your symptoms are severe enough, people often need to give up their jobs and leave school, even if they want to keep working. The consequences include decreased earning capacity, limited mobility and reduced quality of life. Some people find it difficult to live independently without help from family members.

How common is this condition?

According to the latest data available from the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), more than 1 million Americans had MS at some time during 2011. Nearly half of them were between ages 20 and 64 years old. In addition, more than 11 million people worldwide suffer from MS. It is estimated that up to one-third of people with MS will develop other neurological disorders and/or die early due to complications such as stroke or heart attack. MS can also cause memory loss and dementia, which causes a person to lose his or her identity and sense of self.

MS has become increasingly prevalent over the past few decades, particularly among women and adolescents. Currently, about 7% of adults in the U.S. are diagnosed with MS.

What happens after I get MS?

After you develop MS, your body will begin to slowly deteriorate, causing an overall decline in health, productivity and social function. There are several different types of MS:

Primary progressive MS (PPMS): Causes the first symptoms of MS, usually within 2 years of onset. PPs usually come on gradually. They may have pain, numbness or tingling around the area of the brain, along with muscle weakness, fatigue and cognitive difficulties, as well as speech impediments. Although these initial symptoms appear very similar to those seen in a number of other diseases, some researchers believe that they represent a unique form of MS.

Dopamine is a neurotransmitter that plays an important role in reward, motivation, learning, memory, attention, motor function and the regulation of appetite. It also affects learning and mood, and it has been associated with stress, depression and anxiety disorders. Dopamine levels increase during activity, and decreased dopamine concentrations are known to cause fatigue, poor concentration, sleep disturbances, loss of appetite and increased cravings for alcohol or drugs.

Researchers from the University of Wisconsin-Madison have found that exposure to high-dose dopamine increases the risk of developing MS. The study was published online April 8, 2012 in PLOS ONE by Jodi Gilman and David K. Pasek of UW-Madison and colleagues.

"High doses of dopamine were highly effective at suppressing immune responses," said Gilman, assistant professor of neurobiology. "We wanted to determine if this effect could be attributed to increased inflammation."

In previous work, Gilman had shown that low dopamine levels result in reduced ability to suppress the immune response after infection -- so inhibiting the immune system may lead to more MS symptoms. She hypothesizes that high-dose dopamine induces inflammation as well.

To test this hypothesis, the researchers exposed mice to high-dose dopamine before an experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) virus exposure, which targets the brain's white matter, and then again two weeks later after viral clearance. Mice injected with the same virus showed fewer signs of MS two weeks following treatment.

The findings suggest that high-dose dopamine enhances the release of inflammatory mediators such as interleukin-1beta, monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 and tumor necrosis factor alpha, thereby inducing CNS inflammation and potentially exacerbating the disease process.

"This research suggests that dopamine plays an essential part in facilitating the development of MS. Our next steps will focus on identifying other substances that influence dopamine's anti-inflammatory effects," Gilman said.

MSD: Multiple Sclerosis is an autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system. It has been described as a "wound in the brain." The central nervous system is comprised of four major parts, the spinal cord and its branches (the spinal column), the optic nerve, the nerves of sensation (e.g., skin) and the peripheral nerves. Each of these sections has distinct functions.

Multiple Sclerosis symptoms usually begin with the first symptoms of flu-like symptoms such as headache or muscle aches, followed by loss of vision (myopia). This usually happens before age 30. Later, the progressive deterioration can be so severe that people lose all sense of smell. People also become blind without treatment. Some patients may also experience changes to their body movements, which may lead to limb weakness and difficulty walking or reaching objects. Other symptoms can include blurred vision, tremors, ataxia, incoordination, confusion, seizures, muscle spasms, speech abnormalities, and hearing loss. In addition to pain, MS causes other problems including cognitive dysfunction, sleep disorders, depression, anxiety, memory lapses, mood swings, and gastrointestinal problems.

What causes multiple sclerosis?

The exact cause of multiple sclerosis remains unknown but several factors have been associated with the onset of this illness. These include genetic mutations, exposure to toxins and environmental pollutants, viral infections, infection during pregnancy and some diseases that affect the immune system.

For example, it is known that there are genes involved in the development of T cells (immune cells) and B cells (white blood cells that fight off infections). Scientists believe that many different types of viruses may trigger or contribute to multiple sclerosis. For instance, they show evidence that cytomegalovirus (CMV), herpes simplex virus, varicella zoster virus (VZV), human papillomaviruses (HPVs) and Epstein Barr Virus (EBV) play important roles. Environmental hazards such as chemicals may also influence the development of multiple sclerosis. For example, mercury, arsenic, cadmium, chromium and nickel all have been linked with multiple sclerosis.

Other research indicates that certain environmental chemicals can alter cell membranes and increase the risk of developing multiple sclerosis. Exposure to pollutants known as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) has been shown to result in damage to the myelin sheath around neurons. When myelin sheaths break down over time, neuronal transmission between the two hemispheres of the brain can be

Mental Health and Mental Illness


It is important to note that "mood disorder" in itself does not mean you have a mood disorder. It simply refers to symptoms caused by your condition, such as depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, etc., which are symptoms of an underlying medical problem. These illnesses will be discussed further on throughout this page.

Mental health is defined as the capacity for human learning and behavior based on emotions. This includes thoughts, feelings, impulses, preferences, aspirations, social interactions, and ability to experience pleasure. The primary function of the mind is to interpret information received from the senses and make decisions about what to do with it. The brain is made up of many different parts called neurons and each neuron has one job: to receive sensory input (in the form of light, sound, touch) and send signals down the nerve pathways to other cells that are necessary for carrying out specific tasks. There are millions of these nerves which connect all over the body. In order to perform their jobs properly, the neuron must receive appropriate messages from its neighbors so that they know how to respond to the information. Many types of communication involve nerve signaling; however, in our case we only need to discuss three kinds of neural connections: communication between parts of the brain (called synapses), transmission of electrical signals from one part of the brain to another (called excitatory/inhibitory connections), and communication among individual parts of the brain. All of these forms of communication are controlled by neuronal activity inside the brain. Each type of communication requires a certain amount of energy in order to transmit the message, but once a signal reaches the correct destination, the brain can then use it to control the actions of other regions of the brain where the signal originated.

Because your thoughts, feelings, ideas, desires, beliefs and memories are stored within your brain, if these things are disturbed they affect how well you think, feel and act. As a result, there are several ways that disorders like addiction can cause a person's thinking, feeling and behavior to become distorted. One way is through the accumulation of negative experiences. Another way is through the manipulation of feelings that have no real basis in reality. A third way is through the creation of false memories of past events. Even though these things seem like they could happen to anyone at any time, they can often occur in people who are suffering from severe stress, abuse, or trauma. If these things don't get addressed, it is easy to end up

It has been well established over thousands of years that healthy living requires the balance between the mind and body. I believe that this harmony is achieved through understanding the power of the body and its ability to heal itself. In fact, most diseases are caused by imbalances within the human system, and when these imbalances become extreme or persistent they cause illness. For example, if you have chronic pain, your digestive system needs the proper balance of nutrients and minerals. If you suffer from high blood pressure, then certain amino acids must be released from your liver. As long as there is a sufficient supply of these essential substances, it will do its job and keep the heart pumping, kidneys working and every organ functioning at maximum capacity. However, if they remain chronically low, stress can cause damage to all systems. When our organs become damaged we begin to experience symptoms. These symptoms can range from mild discomfort to severe and often permanent problems. One of the greatest causes of suffering is disease, which occurs when certain parts of the body malfunction. Some examples include: poor circulation; reduced absorption of vital minerals and vitamins; increased blood pressure; elevated cholesterol levels; abnormal blood sugar levels; impaired immune function; diabetes mellitus; kidney failure; chronic fatigue syndrome; arthritis; cardiovascular diseases; osteoarthritis; sleep disorders; depression; nervous system dysfunction; mental retardation; Parkinson's Disease; cancer; and even aging. Each one of us suffers from some combination of these problems. However, the more serious the problem, the greater the chances are that we will eventually succumb to it. And it doesn't matter how old you are! Most of us die prematurely because of the illnesses that plague us today. Health issues affect every person differently; therefore each person must seek treatment according to his or her individual situation. The study, published in the journal Personality and Individual Differences, found that people with Borderline Personality Disorder had a greater tendency to believe they were better than others at their jobs.

Psychologists also looked at whether this difference between men and women was related to other personality characteristics like neuroticism or agreeableness.

They say it is important for employers to keep in mind when evaluating job applicants who have borderline personality disorders because they may be less likely to fit into conventional work roles compared to the general population.

"We need to take more care when hiring individuals with BPD to ensure their personalities are properly considered," said lead author Dr. Daniel Siegel from Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine.

While previous research has suggested that people with BPD struggle in certain situations such as in relationships, Siegel says those findings did not fully explain why some people with BPD didn't perform well on these tests.

As part of the new study researchers used data collected by the National Survey of Employer-Sponsored Health Plans (NSEHAP). The survey included a variety of workplace environments including an interview process where participants took questions about their personality traits and how they might contribute to positive outcomes for the organization.

In the interviews, participants rated each of four personality variables: extraversion; openness to experience; conscientiousness; and depression severity.

Participants also completed a measure called "personality inventory of psychopathology" which assessed all of their personality traits.

Researchers then examined whether participants with BPD performed differently than the average person. They found that those with Borderline Personality Disorder showed significant differences in their scores on all four measures.

Those with Borderline Personality Disorder scored higher than average on openness and conscientiousness but lower than average on depression and neuroticism, which suggests that these traits could impede successful employment and contribute to poor social behaviors.

Siegel said there's no reason to think that these results mean that people with Borderline Personality Disorder aren't capable of working in organizations. In fact, he added they may actually be able to do better than the average employee due to their unique strengths.

These qualities include being strong thinkers and problem solvers. For example, if someone with Borderline Personality Disorder shows that they're highly analytical and problem solving, that would help them find ways to solve problems in different contexts. These skills also make them good leaders.

According to Siegel, people with personality disorders are often underestimated both within society and in their own

Thyroxine is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis, and when it fails to produce enough thyroxine (hypo) TSH rises because TSH binds more strongly to its receptor on the pituitary than does T4 [17]. Hypothyroidism can cause a range of clinical abnormalities including sleepiness, fatigue, depression, mental confusion, muscle weakness, poor concentration, appetite changes, weight loss and decreased sexual function [18]. The most common features of severe hypothyroidism are elevated body temperatures (hyperthermia), tachycardia or orthostatic intolerance. This condition occurs in 50–85% of patients with chronic autoimmune thyroid disease [19-22], whereas the incidence of severe hyperthyroidism is much lower and that may not be associated with a diagnosis of autoimmune thyroid disease [23, 24].

The role of hypothyroidism in the development of Graves' disease was first suggested by Beggs et al. [25] who demonstrated a significant association between hypothyroidism and Graves' disease in an Australian population (n = 874). Subsequent studies have also been conducted using different methods to confirm this finding. In a study from Germany involving 479 patients with Graves' disease only 5% had evidence of hypothyroidism and the median age at onset of Graves' disease was 55 years (range 35–63 years; P < 0.0001) [26]. A cohort of 793 hypothyroid patients attending a hospital in Denmark found that all hypothyroid cases were younger than 65 years [27]; however, these results cannot be extrapolated directly to the general population. In a prospective study of over 700 patients with primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PRMS) in Finland, only 11% of patients with Graves' disease met the criteria for hypothyroidism [28].

In a cross sectional study of 115 patients with Graves' disease in Japan, hypothyroidism was reported by 15% of patients with Graves' disease compared to 1% without hypothyroidism [29]. As expected from other authors, those with hypothyroidism were significantly older and had higher prevalence of psychiatric disorders (P < 0.05). These findings support the hypothesis that hypothyroidism plays a pivotal role in the pathogenesis of Graves' disease. However, the exact nature of the relationship between hypothyroidism and Graves' disease remains unclear as there has been little investigation into the possibility that hypothyroidism causes specific

My symptoms include muscle weakness, slurred speech and walking problems. I live in a small town where there are not many doctors available for MS patients. When I went to the doctor's office in May of this year, I was diagnosed with an MS that had been dormant since childhood. At first I thought I must have gotten one or two bad blows on my head but it turned out the cause is much more severe: My immune system has never developed enough tolerance for the drugs that suppress my immune system. The drugs cause me pain so intense that my knees buckle every time I walk away from them. It was hard to take pills all day long because they make me sicker each time I take them. If I don't take the drugs, I get worse and can no longer function well.

I used to work at the local mall for nearly 30 years as part of my college education. Now I am unable to do anything but sit quietly on my couch and watch TV. There seems to be nothing else I can do that will help me. I want to return to school but I know it may be too late. My disability leaves me without any hope for the future.

What should I do?

You need to keep up with your medications as prescribed by your doctor. You also need to eat healthy foods and avoid junk food. Exercise regularly (at least 3 times per week). Take vitamin supplements. Check your blood sugar levels frequently. And pay attention to the side effects of your medications, especially if you start using new ones.

How can I tell if I'm developing symptoms of MS?

Pre-Calculus I (1 credit)

The course is intended to help students who want to learn about the mathematical nature of differential equations and linear systems. Prerequisite: Upper division standing

MATH 1210 Linear Algebra, Applications and Theory 1 Credits Offered in the: Fall Winter Spring Summer

Mathematics Department

This course develops a foundation in linear algebra, including applications, theory and application. It will introduce you to the basic concepts of linear algebra, develop some useful skills in solving linear system equations using numerical methods, and give you an overview of the most widely used tools for problem solving. By the end of this course, you should have an understanding of how linear algebra relates to other branches of mathematics, such as calculus.

Prerequisites: Upper division standing

MATH 1601 Calculus 1 3 Credits Offered in the: Fall Winter Spring Summer

Math Department

Calculus 1 offers a solid introduction to the fundamental ideas and techniques of linear algebra and related areas of math. This course introduces calculus via the use of iterative approximations and sequences. The student applies these techniques to solve real-world problems and acquire more general knowledge of their application. Topics include: vector spaces, vector and matrix operations, partial derivatives, integrals over functions, time series analysis, and special functions.

Prerequisites: Upper division standing

MATH 1602 Calculus 2 3 Credits Offered in the: Fall Winter Spring Summer

Math Department

In this course, we'll cover topics in applied mathematics with an emphasis on applications in science, technology, engineering, and math, and will begin to understand advanced material such as elliptic curves and Fourier transforms. We'll also study applications of nonlinear transformations to differential equations, and consider applications of differential equations to solvers and algorithms. We will work through some examples of various types of functions; however, it's not necessary to actually write a proof of any specific result. A key theme here is to follow the proofs closely so that one does not get lost. The final project is designed to put together an exercise which asks the student to design a formal method or algorithm for solving a given set of differential equations based on the solutions of previous exercises.

Prerequisites: Upper division standing

The company's chief executive, Tim Cook, has said that Apple is making a "radical" move to create a truly mobile future where everything is connected and it will help determine how we live our lives by bringing all the devices into harmony. The new iWatch could be an attempt at getting people on board with this vision. It can connect to your iPhone wirelessly through Bluetooth or use NFC to open doors in stores as well as pay for things at checkout counters. And since it uses the same processor found in Apple Watch Series 2 (which is expected out early 2018), it should also have faster performance than the first model which debuted in 2016.

With the launch of the Apple Watch Series 3, however, Apple is moving away from its reliance on cellular connections and instead focusing on Wi-Fi connectivity. For example, when you order a meal from the restaurant app on your watch, it asks if you want to take a call before actually placing the order. If you say yes, the order gets placed using Wi-Fi and then connected via Bluetooth to the restaurant's server. If you decline to place the order, it does not send any data back to the server.

Apple Pay isn't coming to the smartwatch just yet, but there are signs that it might show up sooner rather than later. Last week, Bloomberg reported that Apple is working to add support for near field communications (NFC) chips used in newer smartphones to its existing hardware. In addition to letting users tap their iPhones to make purchases, the technology could let them perform other tasks like unlocking cars.

In June, Apple expanded its developer program to allow developers to build apps specifically for the Apple Watch. Developers can now get credit towards their applications after they submit the app to Apple's App Store.

are not well understood. The mechanism responsible for the increased susceptibility to oxidative stress is unknown but may involve a proinflammatory pathway or an immune response that is activated by infection, toxins and/or inflammation.

Nerve cells (neurons) communicate with each other via electrical impulses called synapses. In healthy tissues, neurons release neurotransmitters such as acetylcholine, glutamate, noradrenaline and serotonin into the surrounding extracellular space. These neurotransmitters act on other nerve cells, thereby creating the neural "synapse." Synaptic transmission can be broken down and re-established at any time; however, synaptic plasticity is impaired during disease conditions such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Multiple Sclerosis (MS), ALS, stroke and spinal cord injury [1]. It has been postulated that chronic activation of microglia in some cases leads to an inflammatory reaction resulting in reduced activity within neurons. Chronic infections have also been implicated as a factor contributing to the formation of microglial scar tissue in regions of the brain affected by MS [2]. This process is referred to as myelin loss [3], which increases the risk of neuronal dysfunction and subsequent neurological symptoms in MS patients. A number of studies suggest that excessive levels of oxidants may play a role in this process [4–6] and thus contribute to the pathogenesis of MS [7–9]. One study reported that mice lacking the enzyme glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px) exhibited progressive neurodegeneration upon experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). Furthermore, several animal models have demonstrated that prolonged exposure to low doses of oxygen and/or hyperbaric pressure (HBPs), which mimic toxic insults to the brain caused by infectious agents or toxin exposure, lead to the accumulation of lipid rafts in neurons [10–13].

The role of oxidative stress in neurodegenerative disorders remains poorly understood because it is difficult to demonstrate direct evidence of elevated oxidative stress. Several mechanisms have been proposed for how oxidative stress could contribute to CNS damage. The most commonly accepted theory involves increased reactive oxygen species (ROS)-mediated DNA damage, which results from the binding of free radicals (free radical scavengers, superoxide anion, hydroxyl radical, etc.) to nucleotides, especially those present in mitochondria, thus generating double strand breaks (DSBs). Such events appear to result from direct inhibition of mitochondrial respiration resulting in elevated ROS levels. Other mechanisms involve impairment of antioxidant enzymes in

This is a simple, inexpensive way to lower your glucose levels and keep blood sugar in check!

How does it work?

A single tablespoon of coconut oil contains 10 grams of fat (4% DV), which has been shown to prevent insulin resistance and the onset of metabolic syndrome. This makes coconut oil an excellent option when trying to lose weight or improving overall health. Coconut oil can also help with inflammation due to its high polyunsaturated content (3).

Coconut Oil & Diabetes Risk Reduction

In addition to being great for losing weight, we should consider using coconut oil for other health benefits as well, specifically:

Possible Protection Against Type 2 Diabetes

There have only been a few studies on coconut oil and type 2 diabetes prevention, but they suggest that low-glycemic index foods may be beneficial for preventing this disease. For example, one study found that adding 1 tbsp of coconut oil to meals reduced fasting triglyceride by 22%. Another study found that people who used avocado oil for just 6 weeks had greater reductions in blood pressure and waist circumference than did those who ate traditional oils like safflower oil or peanut butter. A study published in Nutrition Journal found that after 7 days of consuming either 20g of lard per day, 15g of olive oil or no oil at all, both group improved their glycemic control and lipid profiles. How is my ALS treated during Phase I?

During this first phase, the aim is to prevent further deterioration of the nerve fibres, which allows the patient's muscles to regain function. Sleep problems are known risk factors for MS. These include difficulties falling asleep, sleep disturbances, waking up during the night or not being able to get back to sleep, nightmares, memory loss after waking (flashbacks), poor sleep quality, and difficulty getting out of bed, even if tired. This is called insomnia. Studies have shown that people with higher levels of stress hormones (cortisol, epinephrine) are more likely to suffer from sleep problems. People who suffer from other health conditions such as depression are also at increased risk.

A study by Hwang et al, 2013, found a link between insomnia and fatigue, which may be due to the fact that many patients on a disability pension do not sleep well anyway!

Many doctors believe this is just an association; there are no strong scientific evidence to suggest that sleeping problems cause MS. However, some people with MS have reported being able to fall asleep easily when they were on medication to treat their symptoms. In addition, researchers have found that women with MS are twice as likely as men to experience daytime sleeping disorders - such as insomnia and trouble sleeping. Therefore it seems logical that these two factors could play a role in causing MS.


What should I do about my insomnia?

If you think your insomnia has started to affect your daily life then take action:

Take a rest break from work

Keep away from bright lights or any stressful activities

Limit screen use, TV watching, internet browsing, phone use, playing games etc. If you find yourself doing this regularly make sure your employer's policy is clear that this is allowed

Try to avoid driving, taking public transport, going out at night and getting involved in large social gatherings. These can all aggravate your problem

Talk to someone about trying to cure your insomnia

Avoid alcohol and drugs

If the insomnia is affecting everyday aspects of your life then consider seeing a doctor. Sometimes insomnia has been known to improve with antidepressant treatment. Ask your GP or specialist whether medication is right for you. They will be able to advise you about what treatments work best for you.

Other causes of sleepiness

Some people may develop excessive sleepiness for no apparent reason, including:

Dyskinesia - the condition where movement is impaired because of muscle spasms.

- the condition where movement is impaired because of muscle spasms. Tremor - sudden involuntary movements caused by abnormal electrical activity in parts of the brain and spinal cord.

The use of this vaccine has been in debate. The company that manufactures it, GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are both reviewing a new study by researchers at Boston University School of Medicine to see if people who take multiple sclerosis medications can safely receive the vaccine. They found some people with MS have antibodies against the part of the virus (the Langerhans cells) used in the vaccine but not others. So while many doctors agree that there is no reason to think the vaccine should be stopped, other doctors say there may be a need for an investigation or safety review before it's given more widely, particularly since the doses being used now aren't very high — about the equivalent of one shot per week on average.

How does the vaccine work?

The Langerhans cells are a type of white blood cell found all over your body; they're also called helper T cells. These help the immune system identify foreign bodies and respond to them. The vaccines uses those helper T cells as "antibody donors" — the cells that make the protective antibody are harvested from a patient with MS and then injected into another person who doesn't have MS.

Why do you recommend the HPV vaccine?

Because two types of human papillomavirus (HPV) are linked to cancers of the penis, anus, mouth, throat, vagina, rectum, oropharynx and cervical glands, according to the CDC. In fact, 90 percent of sexual partners of men diagnosed with prostate cancer will get HPV, and about 70 percent of women infected with HPV will contract cervical cancer during their lifetimes. Both kinds of HPV affect more than 16 million Americans, especially teenage girls, making it a highly prevalent sexually transmitted disease. Some studies indicate that up to 80 percent of young girls will develop pre-cancerous lesions in their genitals and oral cavity by age 21. HPV vaccination is considered to be an important preventive measure against these cancers.

What does the FDA know about the HPV vaccine?

On Feb. 4, 2009, the agency announced its first ever action regarding the HPV vaccine — requiring companies to prove the vaccine protects against two strains of HPV that cause most cases of genital warts and cervical cancer. Those regulations were later revised to include three additional types of HPV. In June 2010, GSK received a final FDA authorization for Gardasil 9, which was designed to prevent HPV6/11/16

CONCLUSIONS:

Researchers from the university analyzed data collected by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) on food sales between 1990 and 2009. They found that while Americans are more likely than ever to buy fresh fruits and veggies, the portion of calories consumed from those foods has declined in recent years. In fact, people have eaten less fruit per capita than they did in the 1960s, when USDA data first began being recorded.

The study was published online today in The Journal of Nutrition.

For the new study, researchers compared consumption trends over time for oranges, apples and pears and other common fruit and vegetable products in grocery stores across the United States. They used data from the USDA Food Surveys collected annually since 1991 and compared them to current nutrition recommendations: Eat five servings of fruits and vegetables each day; get half your daily protein intake from whole grains; limit saturated fat to 10 percent of total calories; and reduce red meat consumption to six ounces or fewer per week.

Since the early 1970s, the average American has been eating about 7.5 cups of fresh fruit and vegetables per year, but this figure fell by almost one-third during the past decade. Fruit consumption also dropped nearly nine percent among children and teens, even though their nutritional needs increase as they age. Meanwhile, red meat consumption increased by 16 percent.

"We're seeing people who are much leaner and healthier," says lead author Dr. Anne Campbell, director of the Center for Weight and Health Studies at the CU School of Public Health. "But we've never really seen declines in nutrient density, especially fruits and vegetables."

Campbell cautions that more work will need to be done to determine if changes in diet play an important role in these trends. While the average person may feel healthy when he or she eats more fruits and vegetables, there is still an underlying issue of lack of access to healthy foods.

"It seems like our culture is so focused on processed foods, convenience foods, fast food — anything that can put you into a rush or make you happy right now — that all that focus doesn't necessarily translate into healthiness," she explains.
